prime_award_base_transaction_description: Eliminating Monitor Overuse (EMO) Hybrid Effectiveness-Deimplementation Trial - PROJECT SUMMARY/ABSTRACT Deimplementing overused health interventions is an essential step in maximizing quality and minimizing waste in the United States health care system. Acute bronchiolitis is a common lung disease of young children caused by respiratory viral infection. Continuous pulse oximetry monitoring in hospitalized infants with bronchiolitis who are not receiving supplemental oxygen is an overused intervention that has persisted despite evidence that it is ineffective in this population and may cause harm. Three national guidelines now discourage continuous pulse oximetry monitoring in hospitalized infants with bronchiolitis who are not receiving supplemental oxygen. In preliminary studies, the investigators showed that continuous pulse oximetry overuse occurs in nearly half of all hospitalized infants with bronchiolitis for whom there is no monitoring indication, and there is high between-hospital variability in overuse. The overarching goal of the applicants is to determine which strategies are most effective for deimplementing overused health interventions that have the potential to harm children. The overall objective of this application is to conduct the Eliminating Monitor Overuse (EMO) SpO2 trial, a hybrid type III effectiveness-deimplementation trial with a longitudinal cluster-randomized design in 32 Pediatric Research in Inpatient Settings Network hospitals. The trial will test an unlearning deimplementation strategy (educational outreach with audit & feedback) vs. a combined unlearning + substitution deimplementation strategy (adding an electronic health record-integrated clinical pathway) on sustainability of continuous pulse oximetry monitoring deimplementation in children with bronchiolitis who are not receiving supplemental oxygen. This proposal includes three Specific Aims: (1) Compare the effects of the unlearning only strategy versus the unlearning + substitution strategy on deimplementation outcomes, (2) Identify deimplementation strategy mechanisms linked to penetration and sustainability using mixed methods, and (3) Examine the effects of deimplementation on clinical outcomes and unintended consequences. This approach is innovative because it focuses on the under-researched area of pediatric deimplementation, the experimental design reflects state-of-the-art theoretical framing of deimplementation interventions, and the primary outcome focuses on long-term sustainability of deimplementation, which is highly relevant to the public. The proposed research is significant because it will advance the science of health care delivery for a high incidence pediatric lung disease that hospitalizes 100,000 children annually, acute viral bronchiolitis. The trial will also provide new insights into the processes, mechanisms, costs, and outcomes of large, rigorously- designed deimplementation efforts.

PROJECT MANAGEMENT (YEARS 1 THROUGH 5): ÃƑÂ¢Ã¢Â€ŠÂ¬Ã‚Â¢ COMMUNICATION AND INFORMATION MANAGEMENT: DEVELOP TOOLS, SUCH AS PROJECT DIRECTORIES AND EMAIL LISTINGS, TO ENHANCE COMMUNICATION BETWEEN AND AMONG GROUPS AND INDIVIDUALS. DISTRIBUTE INFORMATION AS APPROPRIATE TO PROJECT MEMBERS.  REVIEW AND REVISE DISTRIBUTION TOOLS AS NEEDED. ÃƑÂ¢Ã¢Â€ŠÂ¬Ã‚Â¢ PROJECT MEETINGS: PARTICIPATE IN ALL PROJECT MEETINGS AND TELECONFERENCES RELATIVE TO THE DESIGN, DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF THE PROJECT. FOLLOW UP ON CRCU ACTION ITEMS AS REQUIRED.  ÃƑÂ¢Ã¢Â€ŠÂ¬Ã‚Â¢ PROJECT SUPPORT: ESTABLISH ELECTRONIC AND PAPER DIRECTORY SYSTEM THAT SERVES AS THE PROJECT REPOSITORY. THIS WILL INCLUDE ALL PROJECTS PLANS AND DOCUMENTS, REPORTS, MEETING SUMMARIES AND COMMUNICATION. ÃƑÂ¢Ã¢Â€ŠÂ¬Ã‚Â¢ SOP COMPLIANCE: ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH CRCU AND UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA SCHOOL OF MEDICINE SOPS. MAINTAIN DOCUMENTATION AS APPROPRIATE TO RECORD PROCEDURAL COMPLIANCE. ÃƑÂ¢Ã¢Â€ŠÂ¬Ã‚Â¢ MEETING LOGISTICS:  COORDINATE AND MANAGE DSMB MEETINGS INCLUDING TIMELINES FOR PRODUCTION AND SECURE DISTRIBUTION OF MEETING MATERIALS. DOCUMENT ALL PROCEEDINGS AND CREATE FINAL REPORTS. ÃƑÂ¢Ã¢Â€ŠÂ¬Ã‚Â¢ AE REPORTING:  CRCU WILL BE ALERTED TO ANY ADVERSE EVENT AND WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR WORKING WITH SITES TO COLLECT FULL REPORT AND FOLLOW-UP. ENSURE TIMELY REPORTING, TO IRBS AND ALL STAKEHOLDERS, AND MONITOR EVENT UNTIL CLOSURE. PROVIDE SUMMARY STATISTICS/TRENDS AND INFORM DSMB REPORTS. STUDY DESIGN AND DATA MANAGEMENT PROCESS DESIGN (YEAR 1):  DURING THE DESIGN PHASE OF THE STUDY, THE CRCU PROJECT TEAM WILL WORK CLOSELY WITH THE STUDY TEAM TO DEVELOP AN UNDERSTANDING OF THE OVERALL NEEDS OF THE STUDY. REQUIREMENTS GOVERNING ALL ASPECTS OF THE STUDY WILL BE IDENTIFIED. ONCE ALL PATIENT DATA TO BE COLLECTED HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED, CRCU STAFF WILL DESIGN PROCEDURES FOR MANAGEMENT OF DATA FLOW AND DATA PROCESSING. DATA MANAGEMENT SYSTEM (DMS) DESIGN, DEVELOPMENT, TESTING AND IMPLEMENTATION (YEAR 1), AND MAINTENANCE (YEARS 1 TO 5):  ÃƑÂ¢Ã¢Â€ŠÂ¬Ã‚Â¢ ANALYSIS: THE CRCU PROJECT TEAM WILL WORK CLOSELY WITH DRS. BONAFIDE AND BEIDAS AND THEIR TEAM TO DEVELOP AN UNDERSTANDING OF THE DATA COLLECTION, STORAGE, AND QUALITY ASSESSMENT NEEDS FOR THIS TRIAL. THE TEAM WILL IDENTIFY WHERE STANDARD PROCESSES AND TOOLS ARE AVAILABLE TO MEET PROJECT OBJECTIVES. THE TEAM WILL ALSO REVIEW ANY SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS DICTATED BY THE TRIAL AND WILL DEFINE METHODS AND TECHNOLOGIES TO RESOLVE PARTICULAR DESIGN CHALLENGES. CRCU STAFF WILL THEN DESIGN AND DEVELOP THE TRIAL DATABASE AND REQUIRED MODULES AS DESCRIBED BELOW. ÃƑÂ¢Ã¢Â€ŠÂ¬Ã‚Â¢ DATABASE:  ALL RESEARCH DATA FOR THIS TRIAL WILL BE STORED IN AN ELECTRONIC DATABASE THAT IS MANAGED BY THE RESEARCH TECHNOLOGIES DEPARTMENT OF THE CRCU. THE DATABASE WILL BE HOSTED ON SECURE PMACS COMPUTING SERVERS AND WILL BE RESTRICTED TO ONLY THOSE INDIVIDUALS WHO ARE AUTHORIZED TO WORK ON THE TRIAL. INDIVIDUAL USER ACCOUNTS WITH PASSWORDS WILL BE USED TO RESTRICT ACCESS TO THE DATABASE. SPECIFIC PRIVILEGE ASSIGNMENTS WITHIN THE DATABASE WILL ALSO BE EMPLOYED TO LIMIT THE TYPES OF FUNCTIONS THAT AUTHORIZED USERS CAN PERFORM TO THOSE FUNCTIONS THAT ARE APPROPRIATE FOR THEIR ROLE IN THE TRIAL. ADDITIONAL MEASURES TO PREVENT UNAUTHORIZED EXTERNAL ACCESS TO THE DATABASE ENVIRONMENT WILL BE EMPLOYED USING NETWORK FIREWALL TECHNOLOGIES. THE TEAM WILL WORK CLOSELY WITH DRS. BONAFIDE AND BEIDAS AND CDM PERSONNEL TO DESIGN, DEVELOP, AND TEST A REDCAP DATABASE TO SUPPORT THE REQUIREMENTS OF THE STUDY AND TO PROMOTE DATA SECURITY AND INTEGRITY. ELECTRONIC AUDIT TRAILS OF CHANGES TO DATABASE CONTENTS WILL BE INCORPORATED INTO THE DESIGN AND WILL CAPTURE AND RECORD THOSE CHANGES AUTOMATICALLY. IN ADDITION TO THE TRIAL DATABASE WHERE ACTUAL RESULTS WILL BE MAINTAINED, A DEVELOPMENT DATABASE WILL BE CREATED. THE DEVELOPMENT DATABASE IS A WORKING ENVIRONMENT THAT FACILITATES THE DEVELOPMENT, TESTING, TROUBLESHOOTING, ENHANCEMENT, AND TRAINING FOR THE DATA MANAGEMENT SYSTEM (DMS) WITHOUT ADVERSELY AFFECTING THE

THIS DALLAS CYBERSECURITY PROJECT WILL WILL INCLUDE THE PURCHASE OF A BACKUP SOLUTION ORCHESTRATE, AS WELL AS THE SETUP AND CONFIGURATION OF THOSE SERVICES, AZURE BLOB CLOUD STORAGE FOR THE RETENTION OF BACKUP FILES, PROFESSIONAL SERVICES FOR THE SECONDARY SITE, HARDWARE, AND AN EXPRESS ROUTE GATEWAY FIREWALL. THIS PROJECT ENSURES THAT THE OFFSITE DATA AND BACKUP PROCESSES ARE ISOLATED FROM MALICIOUS ACTIVITY OR UNAUTHORIZED ACCESS TO THE BACKUP SOLUTION AND OFF-SITE INFRASTRUCTURE.

prime_award_cfda_numbers_and_titles: 16.738: EDWARD BYRNE MEMORIAL JUSTICE ASSISTANCE GRANT PROGRAM

subaward_description: NORTEX REGIONAL PLANNING COMMISSION HARDEMAN COUNTY CYBER DEFENSE PROJECT WILL PURCHASE 2 WINDOW SERVERS, 1 VIRTURAL WINDOW SERVER, 1 FIREWALL, AND 1 UNITERRUPTIBLE POWER SUPPLY FOR HARDEMAN COUNTY. THIS PROJECT WILL ENHANCE HARDEMAN COUNTIES CYBERSECURITY BY MONITORING AND MAINTAINING THEIR SERVERS, ROUTES, AND SWITCHES THAT PROVIDES PROTECTION AND INCREASED SECURITY AGAINST TERRORIST ACTIVITY AND REDUCING THE RISK OF MALWARE ATTACK'S.

THE HOWARD COUNTY CYBERSECURITY PROJECT (HCCP) ADDRESSES THE CYBERSECURITY PORTIONS OF THE 2020 HOWARD COUNTY THIRA/SPR. THE HCCP CONTAINS FOUR INITIATIVES TO ADDRESS THIRA/SPR GAPS OF "PUBLICLY MANAGED AND/OR REGULATED CRITICAL INFRASTRUCTURE FACILITIES", "CONTINUITY OF OPERATIONS FOR CYBER SYSTEMS", "CONTROLLING ELECTRONIC ACCESS", "DETECTING MALICIOUS ACTIVITY","PROTECTIVE MEASURES", "TECHNICAL COUNTERMEASURES". THE FOUR INITIATIVES OF THE HCCP ARE A THIRD PARTY CYBERSECURITY ASSESSMENT, PHYSICAL MULTIFACTOR AUTHENTICATION TOKENS FOR VPN'S, LIVE VULNERABILITY MANAGEMENT, AND A CENTRALIZED ENDPOINT FIREWALL SYSTEM. THE PROPOSED HCCP INITIATIVES ARE A PRIORITY TO ENSURE THE COUNTY NETWORK INFRASTRUCTURE AND DEVICES ARE PROTECTED FROM DOWNTIME AND SENSITIVE DATA LOSS DUE TO MALICIOUS ACTORS.

THIS PROJECT SUPPORTS EFFORTS IN INCREASING CYBERSECURITY IN THE STATE IN CONJUNCTION WITH STATE AND COUNTY PRIORITIES.

OUR CYBERSECURITY INFRASTRUCTURE ENHANCEMENT PROJECT SPECIFICALLY DEALS WITH UPGRADING THE COUNTY'S FIREWALLS TO PROVIDE
INTRUSION DETECTION AND FAILOVER CAPABILITIES. INTRUSION DETECTION ANALYZES DATA TRAFFIC BY TYPE & BEHAVIOR TO IDENTIFY
MALICIOUS ACTIVITY ON THE NETWORK. IT ALSO IDENTIFIES AND ISOLATES OR DISABLES SUCH TRAFFIC AND ALERTS TECH SUPPORT ABOUT
THE EVENT. THIS PROVIDES NEAR REAL TIME INTERVENTION WHEN THE NETWORK IS INFILTRATED BY ""BAD ACTORS"". FAILOVER FIREWALL
CAPABILITY ENABLES RAPID DISASTER RECOVERY IN THE EVENT OFA SINGLE DEVICE OR INTERNET CONNECTION FAILS. OUR IT
INFRASTRUCTURE SUPPORTS COMMUNITY NOTIFICATIONS, E911 RESPONSE COORDINATION, ELECTIONS, PUBLICH HEALTH AND
INTELLIGENCE SHARING BETWEEN MULTIPLE LOCAL & FEDERAL LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCIES.

CYBER SECURITY - O	PROJECT/PROGRAM MISSION: 
PROJECT CONSISTS OF TRAINING OF LOCAL (CITY / COUNTY) INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY STAFF TO THE LEVEL OF ARKANSAS STRIKE TEAM CYBER SECURITY RESPONSE. COURSE WOULD CONSIST OF SEVEN (7) SPOTS WITHIN THE TRAINING PROGRAM AND WOULD BE IN-LINE WITH THE CURRENT ARKANSAS CYBER STRIKE TEAM TRAINING. PROJECT ALSO CONSISTS OF PURCHASE OF 23 LOCAL NETWORK FIREWALLS FOR INTRUSION PROTECTION OF CRITICAL INFORMATION AT LITTLE ROCK INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY HEADQUARTERS AND DISASTER RECOVERY SITE.

O	CURRENT TERRORISM PREPAREDNESS INITIATIVES: 
EQUIPPING AND TRAINING LOCAL STAFF ON CYBER SECURITY INITIATIVES SET FORTH BY CISA AND DIVISION OF INFORMATION SYSTEMS STANDARDS.

O	TERRORISM PREPAREDNESS CAPABILITY GAPS: 
THE TEAMS SHOULD RECEIVE TRAINING AND CONTINUING EDUCATION IN ORDER TO PROPERLY FOLLOW COUNTER-TERRORISM BEST PRACTICES AND EMERGING THREATS, CRITICAL PREPAREDNESS AND RESPONSE PLANS.  THE DEPARTMENT OF TRANSFORMATION AND SHARED SERVICES (TSS), DIVISION OF INFORMATION SYSTEMS(DIS), STATE CYBER SECURITY OFFICE (SCSO) FORMULATES AND DIRECTS THE TEAMS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND CYBER SECURITY RESPONSE, MITIGATION AND DISASTER RECOVERY PREPAREDNESS AND RECOVERY EFFORTS.  DIS SUPPORTS CRITICAL STATE IT INFRASTRUCTURE THAT CAN IMPACT FIRST RESPONDERS, ALL STATE EMPLOYEES, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.  THE INTENT OF THIS SUBMISSION IS TO CONTINUE EFFORTS TO ADDRESS FINDINGS IN A 2016 THIRD PARTY STATEWIDE CYBER SECURITY ASSESSMENT. THIS PROGRAM WILL IDENTIFY AND FILL CYBER SECURITY RESPONSE CAPABILITY GAPS WITHIN THE RESPONSE TEAMS.

BOMB -O	PROJECT/PROGRAM MISSION: 
THE OVERALL PROJECT MISSION IS FOR EXPLOSIVE DEVICE DETECTION AND DISABLEMENT WITHIN THE LITTLE ROCK METROPOLITAN REGION, STATEWIDE, AND NATIONALLY THROUGH EMAC DEPLOYMENTS.

O	CURRENT TERRORISM PREPAREDNESS INITIATIVES: 
CURRENT TERRORISM PREPAREDNESS INITIATIVES INCLUDES THE STAFFING AND EQUIPPING OF THE 9-PERSON LRFD BOMB SQUAD.

O	TERRORISM PREPAREDNESS CAPABILITY GAPS: 
CURRENT COMMUNICATIONS CAPABILITIES TO INCLUDE NEW PORTABLE RADIOS FOR SQUAD MEMBERS AND A NEW MOBILE RADIO FOR THE BOMB RESPONSE UNIT, BINOCULARS AND RANGE FINDERS FOR STANDOFF DISTANCE AND SAFETY PROTOCOLS, PAN STANDS AND CAP PROTECTORS FOR BOMB DISABLING MISSION AND EXPLOSIVE TRANSPORTATION, DATA SERVICE DEVICE FOR BOMB RESPONSE UNIT, 3D PRINTER FOR JUST IN TIME PRODUCTION OF RENDER SAFE MATERIALS/EQUIPMENT, UNMANNED AERIAL DRONE FOR SCENE SAFETY AND PERSONAL PROTECTIVE EQUIPMENT, AND TRAINING AND TRAVEL TO VARIOUS INTERNATIONAL/NATIONAL TRAINING CONFERENCES.

prime_awardee_business_types: Public/State Controlled Institution of Higher Education;Nonprofit with 501C3 IRS Status (Other than an Institution of Higher Education)
prime_award_base_transaction_description:
GRIDLOGIC: HARDWARE/SOFTWARE CODESIGN FOR DEEP GRID VISIBILITY AND SECURITY

Propose GridLogic, a framework for cyber-physical security by design that will impede attackers or malicious operators from taking actions that are detrimental to the electricity grid. The project has the following objectives: Develop and implement a control system capable of blocking detrimental actions or trajectory operational action by an external attacker and even in the case of an authorized insider, implement and demonstrate hardware-based data encryption as a second layer (i.e., in addition to any network-based encryption) for field control devices, develop and demonstrate deep communication network capability with anomaly detection, and develop and demonstrate AI-based, system-level cyber-physical security assessment.
subaward_description: CITY OF MARIETTA, GA WOULD LIKE TO EXPRESS ITS COMMITMENT TO PARTICIPATE PROVIDING EXPERT GUIDANCE, AND TO SERVE AS ELECTRIC UTILITY DEMONSTRATION SITE. THE CITY OF MARIETTA, GA IS COMMITED TO PROVIDE $830,984.00 OF IN-KIND COST-SHARE, WHICH INCLUDES NETWORK RESOURCES, SUCH AS SWITCHES, CABLING, FIREWALLS, VIRTUALIZATION INFRASTRUCTURE, CYBERSECURITY APPLIANCES AND EMPLOYEE EXPERTISE AND TIME. THE PROPOSED GRIDLOGIC SYSTEM WILL PROVIDE SECURITY AT THE LEVELS OF FIELD DEVICE, NETWORK, AND IDENTIFICATION OF QUESTIONABLE NETWORK/GRID STATES AND ACTIONS THAT ARE DETRIMENTAL TO THE SYSTEM OPERATIONAL OBJECTIVES, HENCE PROVIDING HIGHER LEVELS OF GRID SECURITY.

prime_award_base_transaction_description: Multi-site Validation and Application of a Consensus DSC MRI Protocol
subawardee_name: MEDICAL COLLEGE OF WISCONSIN, INC., THE
subawardee_business_types: PRIVATE UNIVERSITY OR COLLEGE,NONPROFIT ORGANIZATION,EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION
subaward_description:
MEDICAL COLLEGE OF WISCONSIN
THIS IS A TECHNIQUE DRIVEN PROJECT SO IT DOES NOT FALL UNDER THE CLINICAL PHASE TRIAL PROTOCOLS. THE PROJECT IS MONITORED AT ALL TIMES BY THE PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATORS AND/OR CO-INVESTIGATOR. THE INSTITUTIONAL IRS REVIEWS EACH PROJECT YEARLY.
ADVERSE EVENT REPORTING: ANY ADVERSE EVENT SUCH AS CONTRAST REACTION WOULD BE REPORTED TO THE IRB
UNDER THE GUIDELINES AS REQUIRED BY OUR INSTITUTION. ALL PATIENTS WILL HAVE HAD MRI EXAMS WITH CONTRAST BEFORE THEY ARE RECOMMENDED FOR OUR STUDY SO WE DO NOT ANTICIPATE HAVING A PROBLEM WITH ALLERGIC REACTIONS, BUT ARE ALWAYS PREPARED.
DATA MANAGEMENT: THE ONLY TIME INFORMATION IS ENTERED INTO THE PATIENT'S MEDICAL RECORD IS WHEN THE PATIENT HAS THE STUDY AS PART OF A REGULAR CLINICAL EXAMINATION ON A CLINICAL MRI SCANNER. ANY ASPECT OF THE EXAM THAT IS FOR RESEARCH PURPOSES ONLY IS CLEARLY MARKED AS SUCH. CONSENT FORMS ARE KEPT IN A LOCKED CABINET/AND OR LOCKED OFFICE. ANY INFORMATION USED FOR PUBLICATIONS OR SCIENTIFIC EXHIBITS IS FREE OF PATIENT IDENTIFYING INFORMATION. HARD COPIES OF THE STUDY RESULTS ARE KEPT IN LOCKED FILE CABINETS.
PATIENT DATA IS ONLY STORED ON PASSWORD-LOCKED COMPUTERS AND/OR A SERVER. THE SERVER IS PHYSICALLY
LOCATED WITHIN THE MEDICAL COLLEGE OF WISCONSIN'S CLIMATE CONTROLLED SERVER ENVIRONMENT SECURED WITH RESTRICTED ACCESS AND BIOMETRIC HAND SCANNERS. NETWORK SECURITY IS PROVIDED BY BOTH THE MCWS HARDWARE FIREWALL AND
AN INTERNAL SOFTWARE FIREWALL. THE LAB'S COMPUTERS, WHICH HAVE SECURE ACCESS TO THE SERVER, INCLUDE FOUR MACINTOSH SYSTEMS EQUIPPED FOR BASIC WORD PROCESSING AND UNIX APPLICATIONS, SUCH AS THOSE NECESSARY FOR THE POST-PROCESSING OF MRI IMAGES WITH IMAGING BIOMETRICS SOFTWARE, AFNI, FSL AND MATLAB, AND FOUR PC WORKSTATIONS RUNNING MICROSOFT WINDOWS AND/OR LINUX.

prime_award_cfda_numbers_and_titles: 11.432: NATIONAL OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC ADMINISTRATION (NOAA) COOPERATIVE INSTITUTES; 11.432: NOAA COOPERATIVE INSTITUTES; 11.440: ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES, APPLICATIONS, DATA, AND EDUCATION
subawardee_business_types: U.S. STATE GOVERNMENT,1862 LAND GRANT COLLEGE,EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION,STATE CONTROLLED INSTITUTION OF HIGHER LEARNING
subaward_description:
CASA RADAR  INTEGRATION WITH NWS FORECASTER OPERATIONS
STATEMENTOFWORK- UMASS

THE NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE IS PARTNERING WITH THE CENTER FOR COLLABORATIVE ADAPTIVE SENSING OF THE ATMOSPHERE (CASA) IN LEVERAGING THEIR FIVE-YEAR PROPOSAL FOR AN URBAN DEMONSTRATION PROJECT TO RESEARCH THE UTILITY AND IMPACT EFFUSING SHORT-WAVELENGTH POLARIMETRIC, NETWORKED RADAR AND OTHER OBSERVATIONS IN IMPROVING CONVECTIVE AND HYDROLOGIC WARNING AND NUMERICAL FORECAST PERFONNANCE IN THE FORT WORTH-DALLAS METROPOLITAN AREA THIS PARTNERSHIP PARTIALLY ADDRESSES MULTIPLE NWS STRATEGIC GOALS CONCERNING URBAN TESTBED DEVELOPMENT, DECISION SUPPORT SERVICES, CONVECTIVE INITIATION, BOUNDARY-LAYER SAMPLING, URBAN HYDROLOGY, AND WARN-ON-FORECAST, AMONGST OTHERS. THIS FIRST INSTALLMENT THE GRANT WILL BE DISTRIBUTED TO CIRA, THE COOPERATIVE INSTITUTE FOR RESEARCH IN THE ATMOSPHERE AT COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY, WHICH WILL AWARD A SUB-CONTRACT TO UMASS. UMASS RESEARCHERS WILL FOCUS ON:

I.         INTEGRATION OF CASA DATA INTO FORT WORTH WEATHER FORECAST OFFICE (FWD-
WFO) VIA AWIPS, AWIPS2
THIS PROJECT AIMS TO INTEGRATE CASA HIGH-RESOLUTION PRODUCTS/DATA-STREAMS INTO NWS PLATFORMS TO ENABLE EVALUATION OF CASA DATA BY WFO AND RFC FORECASTERS IN THEIR CURRENT OPERATING AND DECISION-MAKING ENVIRONMENT. CASA SYSTEMS PRODUCE AN EXTENSIVE AMOUNT OF DATA COMPARED TO THE CURRENT DAY WSR-880 BOTH SPATIALLY AND TEMPORALLY AND THEREFORE CAN
SERVE AS AN EXAMPLE FOR HOW HIGH RESOLUTION DATA STREAMS SHOULD BE HANDLED. TASKS INCLUDE:
1. INTEGRATION OF FOLLOWING PRODUCTS INTO AWIPS FOR USE IN THE FWD FORECAST OFFICE IN
2013: SINGLE RADAR VELOCITY, SINGLE RADAR REFLECTIVITY, MERGED COMPOSITE REFLECTIVITY;
COMPOSITE QPE.
A.   CONVERT CASA QPE INTO FONNAT THAT IS COMPATIBLE WITH AWIPS
A.   CONVERT CASA QPE INTO FONNAT THAT IS COMPATIBLE WITH AWIPS
B.  ASSIST FWD/NOAA/SRR WITH SETUP LDM FEED AT FWD.
C.   ASSIST NOAA/SRH WITH INSTALLING NETCDF CONVERTER AT FWD SO THE CASA FILES DO NOT OVERWHELM THE FIREWALL.  USE AND MODIFY EXISTING SCRIPTS AND MAKE THEM AVAILABLE TO NOAA.
D.  ASSIST FWD/NOAA/SRH IN ACQUIRING SOURCE CODE FOR CASA ENABLED DISTRIBUTION THAT WAS USED IN THE OUN OFFICE.
E.   ASSIST NOAA/FWD WITH TESTING LDAD NOTIFICATION MECHANISM TO MAKE SURE IT'S NOT GETTING BOGGED DOWN WITH ADDITIONAL LOAD. SIMULATE RADAR NETWORK OPERATIONS. SELECT SUBSET OF PRODUCTS FOR AUTO-NOTIFICATION THAT LDAD SERVER CAN HANDLE, ALL OTHER PRODUCTS MUST BE REQUESTED BY FORECASTER.

AND:

NOTE: THIS PROJECT REQUIRES THAT FWD/NOAA/SRH ALLOCATE RESOURCES TO THE TASKS ABOVE

O   MERGES CHANGES FROM CASA ENABLED BRANCH OF CODE BACK INTO TRUNK.
O   UPDATES LOCALIZATION FOR NEW DFW RADARS. UPDATES FRONT-END INTERFACE FOR NEW
DFW RADARS/PRODUCTS.
O   RUNS ATAN WITH SUPERVISOR APPROVAL.

2.  CONTINGENT UPON THE RELEASE OF AWIPS2 SOURCES TO UNIVERSITY RESEARCHERS, TESTING AND
INTEGRATION OF FOLLOWING CASA PRODUCTS INTO AWIPS2: SINGLE RADAR VELOCITY, SINGLE
 
RADAR REFLECTIVITY, MERGED COMPOSITE REFLECTIVITY; COMPOSITE QPE; 3DVAR WIND VECTOR
PRODUCTS; REAL-TIME MULTI-DOPPLER WIND VECTOR PRODUCTS.

3.  INGESTION OFCASA QPE PRODUCTS INTO FFMP HYDROLOGY MODEL. EVALUATION OF MODEL PERFORMANCE ONCE CASA DATA IS ASSIMILATED.
STAFFING: E. LYONS 3.75 MONTHS
CO-PI MICHAEL ZINK WILL MENTOR ERIC LYONS- .15 MONTHS

LL.       DATA FUSION, CONVECTIVE INITIATION AND INTENSIFICATION
IN THIS PROJECT, WE COMBINE THE STRENGTHS OF REAL-TIME, NETWORKED CASA OBSERVATIONS WITH THE STRENGTHS OF OTHER LOCAL, REAL-TIME IN-SITU OR REMOTE OBSERVATIONS TO PROVIDE INCREASED INFORMATION TO THE FORECASTER OF IMPENDING CONVECTIVE INITIATION AND GROWTH/DECAY TRENDS OF A STORM SYSTEM. THIS APPROACH PROVIDES VERY RAPID INFORMATION ON LOWER TROPOSPHERE, SMALLÃ‚Â­ SCALE FEATURES SUCH AS EMBEDDED TORNADOES, OR CIRCULATIONS ON THE LEADING EDGE OF A QUASI LINEAR CONVECTIVE SYSTEM THAT CAN HAVE SIGNIFICANT IMPACTS TO SAFETY IN DENSELY POPULATED URBAN AREAS. THIS INFORMATION CAN BE PROVIDED IN A COMPUTATIONALLY EFFICIENT MANNER, USING STANDARD SERVER RESOURCES HOUSED IN A NWS REGIONAL OFFICE. THE KEY TO CREATING TARGETED, FUSED OBSERVATIONS IS CASA'S METEOROLOGICAL COMMAND AND CONTROL (MCC). THE MCC'S RADAR CONTROL ALGORITHMS CAN DYNAMICALLY CHANGE THE SPEED, WAVEFORM, AND VOLUME COVERAGE PATTERNS FOR CASA RADARS IN RESPONSE TO AN EXTERNAL TRIGGER. THAT TRIGGER COULD BE DATA FROM ANOTHER SENSOR, REFLECTIVITY DETECTION ALGORITHMS, THE LOCATION OF BUILT INFRASTRUCTURE (SUCH AS AN ARENA), MODEL OUTPUT, OR A COMBINATION OFTRIGGERS. TASKS ARE MCC WORK RELATED TO:

Ã¢Â‚¬Â¢  DEVELOP AND TEST PRODUCTS FOR TARGETED, FUSED OBSERVATIONS (APPROX. 1-5 MINUTE UPDATES, 250M RESOLUTION) COMBINING CASA WITH NON-CASA JIGHTNING, RADAR, AND/OR SATELLITE DATA FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF SEVERE WEATHER INTENSIFICATION TREND PRODUCTS (NOWCASTS AND REAL TIME).
STAFFING: D. WESTBROOK 1.5 MONTHS

prime_award_program_activities_funding_t: 0022: NATIONAL CRIMINAL HISTORY IMPROVEMENT PROGRAM (NCHIP);0022: NATIONAL CRIMINAL RECORDS HISTORY IMPROVEMENT PROGRAM (NCHIP)
prime_awardee_name: TENNESSEE DEPARTMENT OF FINANCE AND ADMINISTRATION
prime_award_base_transaction_description: 2017 State of Tennessee National Criminal History Improvement Program
subaward_description:
THE GOAL OF THE NATIONAL CRIMINAL HISTORY IMPROVEMENT PROGRAM (NCHIP) IS TO IMPROVE THE NATION'S SAFETY AND SECURITY BY ENHANCING THE QUALITY, COMPLETENESS, AND ACCESSIBILITY OF CRIMINAL HISTORY RECORD INFORMATION AND BY INSURING THE NATIONWIDE IMPLEMENTATION OF CRIMINAL JUSTICE AND NONCRIMINAL JUSTICE BACKGROUND CHECK SYSTEMS. BJS PROVIDES DIRECT FINANCIAL AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO THE STATES TO IMPROVE CRIMINAL HISTORY AND OTHER RELATED RECORDS AND TO BUILD THEIR INFRASTRUCTURE TO CONNECT TO NATIONAL RECORD CHECK SYSTEMS BOTH TO SUPPLY INFORMATION AND TO CONDUCT THE REQUISITE CHECKS.

UNDER THIS AWARD, THE TENNESSEE DEPARTMENT OF FINANCE AND ADMINISTRATION, OFFICE OF CRIMINAL JUSTICE PROGRAMS WILL TRANSFER FUNDS TO TENNESSEE BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION PROPOSES TO USE FUNDING FROM THIS AWARD, OVER AN 18-MONTH PERIOD, FOR THE CONTINUATION OF THE CRIMINAL HISTORY RECORD IMPROVEMENT (CHRI) PROJECT. THE CRIMINAL HISTORY RECORD IMPROVEMENT PROJECT IS A STRATEGIC, MULTI-PHASED APPROACH DESIGNED TO SIGNIFICANTLY IMPROVE THE QUALITY, COMPLETENESS, AND INTERSTATE ACCESSIBILITY OF CRIMINAL HISTORY RECORD INFORMATION THAT THE TBI IS CHARGED WITH MAINTAINING.  PHASE 1 OF THE CRIMINAL HISTORY RECORD IMPROVEMENT PROJECT IS FUNDED THROUGH THE FEDERAL FISCAL YEAR 2014 AWARD AND IS CURRENTLY IN PROGRESS.  THE TBI PROPOSES TO IMPLEMENT PHASE 2 AS PART OF FUNDING FROM THE FEDERAL FISCAL YEAR 2015 AWARD.  

PHASE 2 OF THE CRIMINAL HISTORY RECORD IMPROVEMENT PROJECT CONSISTS OF TWO PROJECT ACTIVITIES.  THIS FIRST PROJECT ACTIVITY INCLUDES THE PURCHASE ADDITIONAL LIVE SCAN MACHINES FOR THE COUNTY BOOKING AGENCIES THAT INCLUDES A 12-MONTH MAINTENANCE AND SUPPORT CONTRACT AND AN UPDATED FIREWALL FOR EACH.   THE SECOND PROJECT ACTIVITY ENCOMPASSES THE REWRITE OF THE ANTIQUATED, COMPUTERIZED CRIMINAL HISTORY DEVELOPMENT CODE.

prime_award_awarding_agency_name: Department of Health and Human Services (HHS)
prime_award_base_transaction_description: EMR Adverse Drug Event Detection for Pharmacovigilance
subawardee_business_types: PRIVATE UNIVERSITY OR COLLEGE,NONPROFIT ORGANIZATION,EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION
subaward_description:
DR. BELKNAP AND THE RADAR GROUP AT NORTHWESTERN UNIVERSITY WILL EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF SOFTWARE TOOLS
DEVELOPED BY DR. YU AND HER GROUP AT THE UNIVERSITY OF MASSACHUSETTS FOR DE-DEIDENTIFICATION AND ANNOTATION OF
NARRATIVES. UPON CONFIRMATION OF AN EFFECTIVE DE-IDENTIFICATION PROCESS, THE RADAR TEAM WILL DE-IDENTIFY UP TO
1500 EHR NARRATIVES OF PATIENTS WITH HEMATOLOGICAL MALIGNANCIES. THESE DE-IDENTIFIED NARRATIVES WILL THEN BE
ANNOTATED BY THE UMASS TEAM WHO WILL ANNOTATE THE DE-IDENTIFIED NARRATIVES OUTSIDE OF NORTHWESTERN. IN
ADDITION, DR. BELKNAP AND THE RADAR GROUP WILL HELP THE DEVELOPMENT OF ADE ANNOTATION GUIDELINE, AND SERVE
AS A TIE BREAKER FOR THE ADE ANNOTATION. THIS WORK WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED OVER A PERIOD OF 2 YEARS. IN YEAR 3, THE
NU GROUP WILL THEN APPLY THE PVTK JOINTLY DEVELOPED TO VALIDATE KNOWN ADES AND TO DETECT NEW ADES SIGNALS
FROM THE EHR RECORDS WITH A PVTK INSTALLATION BEHIND THE FIREWALL OF THE NORTHWESTERN ENTERPRISE DATA
WAREHOUSE. THE NORTHWESTERN RADAR INVESTIGATORS WILL ALSO PARTICIPATE IN DATA ANALYSIS, PREPARATION OF
ABSTRACTS, SCIENTIFIC ARTICLES, & FORMAL PRESENTATION OF RESULTS.

prime_award_program_activities_funding_t: 0022: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES (0897)
prime_awardee_business_types: Nonprofit with 501C3 IRS Status (Other than an Institution of Higher Education)
prime_award_base_transaction_description: Mobile Video interpretation to Optimize Communication Across Language barriers: mVOCAL - Project Summary  Over 25 million people in the United States (US) have limited English proficiency (LEP). LEP populations face substantial barriers to high-quality healthcare, resulting in disparate outcomes such as elevated risk for serious safety events, increased costs, and decreased comprehension, satisfaction, and adherence. Professional interpretation is an evidence-based practice to improve care and mitigate these disparities. However, its use remains persistently low despite legal and regulatory mandates. Previous strategies to improve use have mainly addressed intrapersonal barriers (provider knowledge and skills, via in -person education) or the system (simplifying telephone interpreter access). Educational strategies have improved provider knowledge with unknown effect on interpreter use; systems strategies have achieved modest improvements in use. However, these strategies have lacked clearly articulated mechanisms or causal pathways, often as part of expensive, multifaceted interventions that limit precise attribution and scalability.  In this study, the investigators will compare two discrete implementation strategies for improving interpreter use, the first an enhanced education strategy targeting primarily intrapersonal barriers but delivered in a scalable format (interactive web-based educational modules), and the second targeting system barriers, with a novel focus on mobile video interpretation (mVI), accessible on providers’ own mobile devices. The study’s specific aims are: (1) Compare the effectiveness of two implementation strategies, alone and in combination, to improve use of interpretation and comprehension for LEP patients/parents seen in adult/pediatric primary care settings; (2) Explore mVI and education implementation strategies’ ability to activate putative provider-level mechanisms; and (3) Determine the incremental cost effectiveness from a healthcare organization perspective of each implementation strategy (mVI, education, both). To accomplish these aims, the investigators will conduct a Type III hybrid implementation-effectiveness study in 6 primary care clinics, using a Sequential Multiple Assignment Randomized Trial (SMART) design . Enrolled providers (total n=50) will be randomized to mVI or educational modules, in addition to standard interpreter access. After 9 months, providers with high interpreter use will continue as assigned; those with lower use will be randomized to continue as before or add the alternative implementation strategy. Providers will complete surveys and in-depth interviews to understand barriers to interpreter use, based on the Theoretical Domains Framework. LEP patients will be surveyed (n=648) and interviewed (n=75) following visits with enrolled providers to understand their experiences with communication and interpretation. Determining how these two scalable strategies, alone and in sequence, perform for improving interpreter use, how they do so, and at what cost, will provide critical insights for addressing a persistent cause of healthcare disparities.

subaward_description:
TOTAL AMOUNT OF SUBAWARD REPORTED 11/2022 WAS MISTYPED AS 663002. CORRECTED TOTAL AMOUNT OF SUBAWARD IS 633002.

THE UW SUBCONTRACT WILL INCLUDE CONTRIBUTIONS FROM THE UW DEPARTMENT OF FAMILY MEDICINE, THE DEPARTMENT OF PEDIATRICS, AND THE DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH SERVICES.
DEPARTMENT OF FAMILY MEDICINE
DR. ALLISON COLE WILL SERVE AS PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR AT THE UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON SUBCONTRACT SITE. DR. COLE AND MEMBERS OF HER RESEARCH TEAM WILL WORK CLOSELY WITH THE SEATTLE CHILDRENÃƑÂ¢Ã¢Â€ŠÂ¬Ã¢Â€ŽÂ¢S PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR AND OTHER MEMBERS OF THE SEATTLE CHILDRENÃƑÂ¢Ã¢Â€ŠÂ¬Ã¢Â€ŽÂ¢S RESEARCH TEAM TO EXECUTE THE AIMS OF THIS PROJECT. 
SPECIFICALLY, DR. COLE AND THE WWAMI REGION PRACTICE AND RESEARCH NETWORK (WPRN) COORDINATING CENTER TEAM WILL FACILITATE RECRUITING AND ENROLLING PRIMARY CARE PRACTICES IN THE MVOCAL STUDY; ASSIST WITH PROVIDER RECRUITMENT AND RETENTION EFFORTS; PROVIDE INPUT ON IMPLEMENTATION INTERVENTION STRATEGIES AND DATA COLLECTION PROCEDURES TO ENSURE STUDY FEASIBILITY; AND SERVE AS A POINT OF CONTACT FOR PARTICIPATING CLINICS AND PROVIDERS. 
UW FAMILY MEDICINE PERSONNEL WILL PARTICIPATE ACTIVELY IN PROJECT MEETINGS (IN PERSON, VIA PHONE, OR VIA ZOOM/A SIMILAR WEB-BASED PLATFORM) THROUGHOUT THE STUDY DURATION.
DEPARTMENT OF PEDIATRICS
DR. JAMES STOUT WILL SERVE AS A CO-INVESTIGATOR AT THE UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON (UW) SUBCONTRACT SITE. DR. STOUT AND MEMBERS OF HIS RESEARCH TEAM WILL WORK CLOSELY WITH THE SEATTLE CHILDRENÃƑÂ¢Ã¢Â€ŠÂ¬Ã¢Â€ŽÂ¢S PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR AND OTHER MEMBERS OF THE SEATTLE CHILDRENÃƑÂ¢Ã¢Â€ŠÂ¬Ã¢Â€ŽÂ¢S RESEARCH TEAM TO EXECUTE THE AIMS OF THIS PROJECT. 
THE UW PEDIATRICS TEAM WILL PLAN, COORDINATE, FILM, PRODUCE AND HOST VIDEO MODULES AND VIGNETTES FOR THE MVOCAL PROJECT QUALITY IMPROVEMENT (QI) PROGRAM. 
SPECIFICALLY, THE UW IMTR GROUP WILL ACCOMPLISH THE FOLLOWING: 
1. DEVELOP AN INTERACTIVE, MULTIMEDIA TUTORIAL THAT IS ACCESSIBLE FROM THE INTERNET VIA A SECURE WEBSITE TO DEMONSTRATE PROVIDER-INTERPRETER ACCESS AND COMMUNICATION SKILLS FOR BUSY PRIMARY CARE PHYSICIANS. THIS RESOURCE WILL BE VIEWED INDIVIDUALLY BY PARTICIPATING PROVIDERS AT A TIME THAT IS CONVENIENT FOR THEM, OVER APPROXIMATELY 60 MINUTES OF VIEWING TIME INCLUSIVE OF ALL FIVE MODULES. POST-TEST SCORES AND END-USER ACTIVITY WILL BE RECORDED AND REPORTED. 
2. PRODUCE FOUR ÃƑÂ¢Ã¢Â€ŠÂ¬Ã…Â€ŒBOOSTERÃƑÂ¢Ã¢Â€ŠÂ¬Ã¯Â¿Â½ 5-MINUTE VIGNETTES DEMONSTRATING ELEMENTS OF INTERPRETER ACCESS AND USE BEST PRACTICES. VIEWERS WILL THEN BE ASKED QUESTIONS ABOUT THE VIEWED MATERIALS AND BE PROVIDED FEEDBACK ON THEIR ANSWERS. POST-TEST SCORES AND END-USER ACTIVITY WILL BE RECORDED AND REPORTED. 
3. HOST AND MANAGE THE ONLINE RESOURCES ONCE ON A LEARNING MANAGEMENT SYSTEMIN THE FIELD. (SOLVING FIREWALL ISSUES, RECORDING USE, ETC.) 
4. ONCE RESOURCES ARE DEVELOPED AND PILOTED, AN APPLICATION FOR MAINTENANCE OF CERTIFICATION CREDIT FOR PRACTICE MEASUREMENT (MOC-4) WILL BE DEVELOPED. 
5. MR. BURGES, THE IMTR SOFTWARE ENGINEER, WILL TRAVEL AS NEEDED IN SUPPORT OF THE MVOCAL PROJECT. 
6. UW PEDIATRICS PERSONNEL WILL PARTICIPATE IN PROJECT MEETINGS (IN PERSON, VIA PHONE, OR VIA SKYPE/A SIMILAR WEB-BASED PLATFORM), AS REQUESTED BY THE SEATTLE CHILDRENÃƑÂ¢Ã¢Â€ŠÂ¬Ã¢Â€ŽÂ¢S RESEARCH TEAM. 
THE 60-MINUTE INTERACTIVE TRAINING TOOL AND 20 MINUTES OF BOOSTER VIGNETTES WILL BE PRODUCED OVER A 12-MONTH SCHEDULE. 
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH SERVICES
DR. PAUL FISHMAN WILL SERVE AS A CO-INVESTIGATOR AT THE UW SITE. DR. FISHMAN WILL WORK CLOSELY WITH THE SEATTLE CHILDRENÃƑÂ¢Ã¢Â€ŠÂ¬Ã¢Â€ŽÂ¢S PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR AND OTHER MEMBERS OF THE SEATTLE CHILDRENÃƑÂ¢Ã¢Â€ŠÂ¬Ã¢Â€ŽÂ¢S RESEARCH TEAM TO EXECUTE THE AIMS OF THIS PROJECT. 
DR. FISHMAN WILL TAKE THE LEAD ON ANALYSES RELATED TO THE PROJECTÃƑÂ¢Ã¢Â€ŠÂ¬Ã¢Â€ŽÂ¢S COST-EFFECTIVENESS AIM. HE WILL PROVIDE CRUCIAL INPUT ON COST-RELATED DATA SOURCES AND DATA COLLECTION DURING STUDY PLANNING, LEAD THE COST AND COST-EFFECTIVESS ANALYSES, AND SERVE AS AN ACTIVE MEMBER OF THE RESEARCH TEAM BY JOINING REGULAR TEAM MEETINGS (IN PERSON, VIA PHONE, OR VIA SKYPE/A SIMILAR WEB-BASED PLATFORM) THROUGHOUT THE STUDY PERIOD.

subaward_description:
THE UW SUBCONTRACT WILL INCLUDE CONTRIBUTIONS FROM THE UW DEPARTMENT OF FAMILY MEDICINE, THE DEPARTMENT OF PEDIATRICS, AND THE DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH SERVICES.
DEPARTMENT OF FAMILY MEDICINE
DR. ALLISON COLE WILL SERVE AS PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR AT THE UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON SUBCONTRACT SITE.  DR. COLE AND MEMBERS OF HER RESEARCH TEAM WILL WORK CLOSELY WITH THE SEATTLE CHILDRENÃƑÂ¢Ã¢Â€ŠÂ¬Ã¢Â€ŽÂ¢S PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR AND OTHER MEMBERS OF THE SEATTLE CHILDRENÃƑÂ¢Ã¢Â€ŠÂ¬Ã¢Â€ŽÂ¢S RESEARCH TEAM TO EXECUTE THE AIMS OF THIS PROJECT.
SPECIFICALLY, DR. COLE AND THE WWAMI REGION PRACTICE AND RESEARCH NETWORK (WPRN) COORDINATING CENTER TEAM WILL FACILITATE RECRUITING AND ENROLLING PRIMARY CARE PRACTICES IN THE MVOCAL STUDY; ASSIST WITH PROVIDER RECRUITMENT AND RETENTION EFFORTS; PROVIDE INPUT ON IMPLEMENTATION INTERVENTION STRATEGIES AND DATA COLLECTION PROCEDURES TO ENSURE STUDY FEASIBILITY; AND SERVE AS A POINT OF CONTACT FOR PARTICIPATING CLINICS AND PROVIDERS.
UW FAMILY MEDICINE PERSONNEL WILL PARTICIPATE ACTIVELY IN PROJECT MEETINGS (IN PERSON, VIA PHONE, OR VIA ZOOM/A SIMILAR WEB-BASED PLATFORM) THROUGHOUT THE STUDY DURATION.
DEPARTMENT OF PEDIATRICS
DR. JAMES STOUT WILL SERVE AS A CO-INVESTIGATOR AT THE UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON (UW) SUBCONTRACT SITE.  DR. STOUT AND MEMBERS OF HIS RESEARCH TEAM WILL WORK CLOSELY WITH THE SEATTLE CHILDRENÃƑÂ¢Ã¢Â€ŠÂ¬Ã¢Â€ŽÂ¢S PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR AND OTHER MEMBERS OF THE SEATTLE CHILDRENÃƑÂ¢Ã¢Â€ŠÂ¬Ã¢Â€ŽÂ¢S RESEARCH TEAM TO EXECUTE THE AIMS OF THIS PROJECT.
THE UW PEDIATRICS TEAM WILL PLAN, COORDINATE, FILM, PRODUCE AND HOST VIDEO MODULES AND VIGNETTES FOR THE MVOCAL PROJECT QUALITY IMPROVEMENT (QI) PROGRAM.
SPECIFICALLY, THE UW IMTR GROUP WILL ACCOMPLISH THE FOLLOWING: 
1. DEVELOP AN INTERACTIVE, MULTIMEDIA TUTORIAL THAT IS ACCESSIBLE FROM THE INTERNET VIA A SECURE WEBSITE TO DEMONSTRATE PROVIDER-INTERPRETER ACCESS AND COMMUNICATION SKILLS FOR BUSY PRIMARY CARE PHYSICIANS. THIS RESOURCE WILL BE VIEWED INDIVIDUALLY BY PARTICIPATING PROVIDERS AT A TIME THAT IS CONVENIENT FOR THEM, OVER APPROXIMATELY 60 MINUTES OF VIEWING TIME INCLUSIVE OF ALL FIVE MODULES. POST-TEST SCORES AND END-USER ACTIVITY WILL BE RECORDED AND REPORTED. 
2. PRODUCE FOUR ÃƑÂ¢Ã¢Â€ŠÂ¬Ã…Â€ŒBOOSTERÃƑÂ¢Ã¢Â€ŠÂ¬Ã¯Â¿Â½ 5-MINUTE VIGNETTES DEMONSTRATING ELEMENTS OF INTERPRETER ACCESS AND USE BEST PRACTICES. VIEWERS WILL THEN BE ASKED QUESTIONS ABOUT THE VIEWED MATERIALS AND BE PROVIDED FEEDBACK ON THEIR ANSWERS. POST-TEST SCORES AND END-USER ACTIVITY WILL BE RECORDED AND REPORTED. 
3. HOST AND MANAGE THE ONLINE RESOURCES ONCE ON A LEARNING MANAGEMENT SYSTEMIN THE FIELD. (SOLVING FIREWALL ISSUES, RECORDING USE, ETC.) 
4. ONCE RESOURCES ARE DEVELOPED AND PILOTED, AN APPLICATION FOR MAINTENANCE OF CERTIFICATION CREDIT FOR PRACTICE MEASUREMENT (MOC-4) WILL BE DEVELOPED. 
5. MR. BURGES, THE IMTR SOFTWARE ENGINEER, WILL TRAVEL AS NEEDED IN SUPPORT OF THE MVOCAL PROJECT. 
6. UW PEDIATRICS PERSONNEL WILL PARTICIPATE IN PROJECT MEETINGS (IN PERSON, VIA PHONE, OR VIA SKYPE/A SIMILAR WEB-BASED PLATFORM), AS REQUESTED BY THE SEATTLE CHILDRENÃƑÂ¢Ã¢Â€ŠÂ¬Ã¢Â€ŽÂ¢S RESEARCH TEAM.
THE 60-MINUTE INTERACTIVE TRAINING TOOL AND 20 MINUTES OF BOOSTER VIGNETTES WILL BE PRODUCED OVER A 12-MONTH SCHEDULE. 
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH SERVICES
DR. PAUL FISHMAN WILL SERVE AS A CO-INVESTIGATOR AT THE UW SITE.  DR. FISHMAN WILL WORK CLOSELY WITH THE SEATTLE CHILDRENÃƑÂ¢Ã¢Â€ŠÂ¬Ã¢Â€ŽÂ¢S PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR AND OTHER MEMBERS OF THE SEATTLE CHILDRENÃƑÂ¢Ã¢Â€ŠÂ¬Ã¢Â€ŽÂ¢S RESEARCH TEAM TO EXECUTE THE AIMS OF THIS PROJECT.  
DR. FISHMAN WILL TAKE THE LEAD ON ANALYSES RELATED TO THE PROJECTÃƑÂ¢Ã¢Â€ŠÂ¬Ã¢Â€ŽÂ¢S COST-EFFECTIVENESS AIM.  HE WILL PROVIDE CRUCIAL INPUT ON COST-RELATED DATA SOURCES AND DATA COLLECTION DURING STUDY PLANNING, LEAD THE COST AND COST-EFFECTIVESS ANALYSES, AND SERVE AS AN ACTIVE MEMBER OF THE RESEARCH TEAM BY JOINING REGULAR TEAM MEETINGS (IN PERSON, VIA PHONE, OR VIA SKYPE/A SIMILAR WEB-BASED PLATFORM) THROUGHOUT THE STUDY PERIOD.

prime_award_program_activities_funding_t: 0022: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES (0897)
prime_awardee_business_types: Nonprofit with 501C3 IRS Status (Other than an Institution of Higher Education)
prime_award_base_transaction_description: Mobile Video interpretation to Optimize Communication Across Language barriers: mVOCAL - Project Summary  Over 25 million people in the United States (US) have limited English proficiency (LEP). LEP populations face substantial barriers to high-quality healthcare, resulting in disparate outcomes such as elevated risk for serious safety events, increased costs, and decreased comprehension, satisfaction, and adherence. Professional interpretation is an evidence-based practice to improve care and mitigate these disparities. However, its use remains persistently low despite legal and regulatory mandates. Previous strategies to improve use have mainly addressed intrapersonal barriers (provider knowledge and skills, via in -person education) or the system (simplifying telephone interpreter access). Educational strategies have improved provider knowledge with unknown effect on interpreter use; systems strategies have achieved modest improvements in use. However, these strategies have lacked clearly articulated mechanisms or causal pathways, often as part of expensive, multifaceted interventions that limit precise attribution and scalability.  In this study, the investigators will compare two discrete implementation strategies for improving interpreter use, the first an enhanced education strategy targeting primarily intrapersonal barriers but delivered in a scalable format (interactive web-based educational modules), and the second targeting system barriers, with a novel focus on mobile video interpretation (mVI), accessible on providers’ own mobile devices. The study’s specific aims are: (1) Compare the effectiveness of two implementation strategies, alone and in combination, to improve use of interpretation and comprehension for LEP patients/parents seen in adult/pediatric primary care settings; (2) Explore mVI and education implementation strategies’ ability to activate putative provider-level mechanisms; and (3) Determine the incremental cost effectiveness from a healthcare organization perspective of each implementation strategy (mVI, education, both). To accomplish these aims, the investigators will conduct a Type III hybrid implementation-effectiveness study in 6 primary care clinics, using a Sequential Multiple Assignment Randomized Trial (SMART) design . Enrolled providers (total n=50) will be randomized to mVI or educational modules, in addition to standard interpreter access. After 9 months, providers with high interpreter use will continue as assigned; those with lower use will be randomized to continue as before or add the alternative implementation strategy. Providers will complete surveys and in-depth interviews to understand barriers to interpreter use, based on the Theoretical Domains Framework. LEP patients will be surveyed (n=648) and interviewed (n=75) following visits with enrolled providers to understand their experiences with communication and interpretation. Determining how these two scalable strategies, alone and in sequence, perform for improving interpreter use, how they do so, and at what cost, will provide critical insights for addressing a persistent cause of healthcare disparities.

prime_award_base_transaction_description: Mobile Video interpretation to Optimize Communication Across Language barriers: mVOCAL - Project Summary  Over 25 million people in the United States (US) have limited English proficiency (LEP). LEP populations face substantial barriers to high-quality healthcare, resulting in disparate outcomes such as elevated risk for serious safety events, increased costs, and decreased comprehension, satisfaction, and adherence. Professional interpretation is an evidence-based practice to improve care and mitigate these disparities. However, its use remains persistently low despite legal and regulatory mandates. Previous strategies to improve use have mainly addressed intrapersonal barriers (provider knowledge and skills, via in -person education) or the system (simplifying telephone interpreter access). Educational strategies have improved provider knowledge with unknown effect on interpreter use; systems strategies have achieved modest improvements in use. However, these strategies have lacked clearly articulated mechanisms or causal pathways, often as part of expensive, multifaceted interventions that limit precise attribution and scalability.  In this study, the investigators will compare two discrete implementation strategies for improving interpreter use, the first an enhanced education strategy targeting primarily intrapersonal barriers but delivered in a scalable format (interactive web-based educational modules), and the second targeting system barriers, with a novel focus on mobile video interpretation (mVI), accessible on providers’ own mobile devices. The study’s specific aims are: (1) Compare the effectiveness of two implementation strategies, alone and in combination, to improve use of interpretation and comprehension for LEP patients/parents seen in adult/pediatric primary care settings; (2) Explore mVI and education implementation strategies’ ability to activate putative provider-level mechanisms; and (3) Determine the incremental cost effectiveness from a healthcare organization perspective of each implementation strategy (mVI, education, both). To accomplish these aims, the investigators will conduct a Type III hybrid implementation-effectiveness study in 6 primary care clinics, using a Sequential Multiple Assignment Randomized Trial (SMART) design . Enrolled providers (total n=50) will be randomized to mVI or educational modules, in addition to standard interpreter access. After 9 months, providers with high interpreter use will continue as assigned; those with lower use will be randomized to continue as before or add the alternative implementation strategy. Providers will complete surveys and in-depth interviews to understand barriers to interpreter use, based on the Theoretical Domains Framework. LEP patients will be surveyed (n=648) and interviewed (n=75) following visits with enrolled providers to understand their experiences with communication and interpretation. Determining how these two scalable strategies, alone and in sequence, perform for improving interpreter use, how they do so, and at what cost, will provide critical insights for addressing a persistent cause of healthcare disparities.

prime_award_base_transaction_description: Drinking water contaminants and fetal loss in Northern California - PROJECT SUMMARY/ABSTRACT The objective of this R03 proposal is to characterize the rates of miscarriage and stillbirth by gestational week in a Northern California population, and to evaluate whether climate change-sensitive drinking water contaminants increase rates of miscarriage and stillbirth. We also aim to estimate the effects of a hypothetical intervention of reducing water contaminant levels on risk of fetal loss. The relationships between drinking water contaminants and risks of miscarriage and stillbirth have not been investigated in California since the early 1980s. As climate change threatens the quality of drinking water in the state, it is important to better understand how climate-sensitive drinking water contaminants affect reproductive health. There is a significant gap in research on environmental determinants of fetal loss at a population level. This is likely due to the challenges in studying early fetal loss, as existing data sources have difficulty capturing miscarriage. However, electronic health record data can help us improve our knowledge of fetal loss between 10 and 20 weeks of gestation, when many pregnant people have received a prenatal care visit but whose pregnancies would not be captured in birth records. We propose to use Sutter Health’s electronic medical records to identify pregnancies, and link participants to community water system boundaries using residential address at each clinic visit. We will then assign water contaminant levels based on the annual average contaminant levels collected from public water monitoring information at the water system level in California. The goals of this project are to 1) characterize the rate of fetal loss in a diverse California cohort, 2) evaluate the individual and mixture effects of climate-sensitive water contaminants on rates of fetal loss, and 3) assess whether reducing all water contaminants to their 50th percentiles observed in the study cohort reduces the risk of fetal loss. The research plan is supported by a strong team of investigators from UCSF, Sutter Health, UC Berkeley, and Columbia University. The investigators have a strong history of collaboration and experience working with electronic health records. They bring significant expertise in reproductive health, drinking water contaminants, climate change, and environmental justice. This research addresses a significant gap in the literature and aligns with both NIEHS’s goal to generate evidence that can be used by policymakers to improve population health, and NICHD’s goals to understand contributors to pregnancy loss and to help identify targets for effective prevention of health disparities.
subaward_description:
1. STATEMENT OF PURPOSE
ENVIRONMENTAL DETERMINANTS OF FETAL LOSS ARE NOT WELL-KNOWN. IN PARTICULAR, THE RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN
DRINKING WATER CONTAMINANTS AND FETAL LOSS BEFORE 20 WEEKS GESTATION HAVE NOT BEEN WELL-STUDIED, LIKELY
DUE TO THE DIFFICULTY OF IDENTIFYING MISCARRIAGE IN A GENERAL POPULATION. THERE IS, HOWEVER, EVIDENCE TO
SUGGEST A POTENTIAL LINK.
THIS STUDY AIMS TO EVALUATE RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN WATER CONTAMINANTS AND FETAL LOSS, AND TO CHARACTERIZE
THE PREVALENCE OF FETAL LOSS IN A NORTHERN CALIFORNIA POPULATION. THESE ANALYSES WILL BE PERFORMED WITHIN THE
SUTTER HEALTH POPULATION. SYLVIA SUDAT, PHD, WILL SERVE AS THE SITE PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR FOR THE SUTTER
HEALTH SUBCONTRACT.
2. SCOPE OF SERVICES
DR. SUDAT WILL PRIMARILY BE RESPONSIBLE FOR SOURCING AND PREPARING THE STUDY DATA FROM THE SUTTER HEALTH
EHR. SHE WILL ALSO BE RESPONSIBLE FOR IRB SUBMISSION AT THE SUTTER HEALTH SITE, AND FOR ANY PRIVACY
APPROVALS NEEDED TO TRANSFER DATA. SHE WILL ALSO CO-AUTHOR PUBLICATIONS THAT RESULT FROM THE STUDY AND
PARTNER/CONSULT WITH THE PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR ON ANALYSIS METHODOLOGY.
3. PROJECT MILESTONES
THE MILESTONES FOR DR. SUDATÃƑÂ¢Ã¢Â€ŠÂ¬Ã¢Â€ŽÂ¢S WORK WILL BE DICTATED BY THOSE OF THE OVERALL PROJECT.
4. DELIVERABLES AND ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA
DR. SUDAT WILL BE REQUIRED TO DELIVER THE STUDY DATASET UPON CONSULTATION WITH THE PI, AND AFTER THE
NECESSARY PRIVACY AND IRB APPROVALS. SHE WILL ALSO DELIVER ANY ANALYSES OR MANUSCRIPT REVIEWS ACCORDING
TO TIMELINES ESTABLISHED WITH THE PI.
5. DATA SHARING
WILL DATA BE SHARED BETWEEN INSTITUTIONS? YES
A. IF YES, IS THIS DATA HUMAN-DERIVED DATA? YES, HOWEVER SHARED DATASETS WILL BE HIPAA SAFE
HARBOR DE-IDENTIFIED PRIOR TO SHARING. ALL IDENTIFIABLE DATASETS WILL BE MAINTAINED SECURELY BEHIND
SUTTER FIREWALLS AND KEPT ON SUTTER SECURE SERVERS WITH RESTRICTED ACCESS.
B. HOW MANY RECORDS/SUBJECTS DOES THIS INVOLVE? APPROXIMATELY 200,000 SUBJECTS.
C. IF YES, PLEASE DESCRIBE WHAT IDENTIFIERS WILL BE INCLUDED WITH THE DATA. NO IDENTIFIERS WILL BE
INCLUDED WITH THE DATA.
D. IF YES, PLEASE DESCRIBE HOW DATA WILL BE TRANSMITTED BETWEEN INSTITUTIONS. THE DE-IDENTIFIED DATA
WILL BE TRANSFERRED VIA SECURE EMAIL OR OTHER METHOD AS REQUESTED AND APPROVED BY PRIVACY AND
INFORMATION SECURITY.
2. PLACE OF PERFORMANCE
THE SERVICES WILL BE PERFORMED AT THE CENTER FOR HEALTH SYSTEM RESEARCH UNDER SUTTER HEALTH LOCATED AT
2121 NORTH CALIFORNIA BLVD., SUITE 310, WALNUT CREEK, CA 94596-7340.

prime_award_program_activities_funding_t: 0001: CAS - GRANTS;OPTN: FIELD IS OPTIONAL PRIOR TO FY21
subaward_description:
YELLOWSTONE COUNTY HAS IDENTIFIED A NEED FOR IMPROVED CYBER SECURITY POLICIES AND PROCEDURES TO PROTECT OUR NETWORKS, DATA AND IT SERVICES FROM UNAUTHORIZED USE OR EXPLOITATION. TO THAT END WE PLAN TO ENGAGE ONE OR MORE INFORMATION SECURITY PROFESSIONALS TO PROVIDE AN INDEPENDENT OBJECTIVE REVIEW OF THE COUNTY'S IT SECURITY PROGRAM. THE REVIEW WOULD INCLUDE EXISTING INTERNAL, EXTERNAL AND PHYSICAL CONTROLS (OR LACK THEREOF) FOR ALL COUNTY DEPARTMENTS, INTERAGENCY CONNECTIONS AND PUBLIC-FACING SERVICES. THE PROJECT WILL CONSIST OF THREE MAJOR PHASES: SECURITY ASSESSMENT, POLICY DEVELOPMENT, AND PROCESS MANAGEMENT. POST-PROJECT ACTIVITIES THAT WILL BE FUNDED INTERNALLY WILL INCLUDE END-USER AWARENESS TRAINING, INCIDENT SIMULATIONS, RESOURCE ACQUISITION (HARDWARE/SOFTWARE/SERVICES) AND PERIODIC POLICY/PROCEDURE REVIEW. 

BY ASSESSING OUR CURRENT RESOURCES AND PRACTICES WE WILL ESTABLISH A POINT OF REFERENCE FOR BUILDING A SET OF POLICIES, TECHNICAL BEST PRACTICES AND OPERATIONS CONTINUITY PLANS. ASSESSMENT WILL FOCUS ON THE IDENTIFICATION OF EXISTING VULNERABILITIES AND THE DOCUMENTATION OF BEST PRACTICE AND STANDARDS COMPLIANCE OR NON-COMPLIANCE. SPECIFIC AREAS OF INVESTIGATION WILL INCLUDE: 

INTERNAL CONTROLS: END-USER AND DEPARTMENTAL APPROPRIATE USE STANDARDS, END-USER SECURITY AWARENESS, POLICY RELEVANCE, POLICY ENFORCEMENT, ENDPOINT COMPLIANCE SCANNING, PATCHING AND UPDATE PROCEDURES, RESOURCE ACCESS AUDITING, BACKUP, ARCHIVE AND RETENTION 

EXTERNAL CONTROLS: PERIMETER SECURITY (FIREWALLS, LOG MANAGEMENT AND ANALYSIS), MULTI-FACTOR AUTHENTICATION, PEN-TESTING, VPN ACCESS, CONTRACT/VENDOR REMOTE ACCESS AUDITING, WEB APPLICATION DEVELOPMENT 

PHYSICAL CONTROLS: PHYSICAL ACCESS RESTRICTIONS TO COMMUNICATIONS, COMPUTE AND STORAGE EQUIPMENT, SURVEILLANCE AND ACCESS AUDIT FOR HIGH SECURITY AREAS, SIGNAGE FOR EQUIPMENT AREAS PROXIMATE TO PUBLICLY ACCESSIBLE AREAS. 

THE POLICY PHASE WILL INCLUDE PARTICIPATION BY CONTRACT INFORMATION SECURITY CONSULTANT(S), COUNTY ELECTED OFFICIALS, OTHER INTERNAL FUNDING SOURCES, EXTERNAL SECURITY PARTNERS, AND IT STAFF. THE POLICIES FORMULATED IN THIS PHASE WOULD ADDRESS THE META-LEVEL DEFICIENCIES DOCUMENTED IN THE ASSESSMENT PHASE. THE WORK PRODUCTS WOULD BE FORMAL POLICY DOCUMENTS ADOPTED BY OUR BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 

THE THIRD PHASE OF THE PROJECT WILL ADDRESS TECHNICAL PLANNING AND PROCESS ISSUES. MAJOR COMPONENTS OF THIS PHASE WILL INCLUDE DOCUMENTING NEW OR IMPROVED PROCESSES RELATED THE THREE CONTROL AREAS INVESTIGATED IN THE ASSESSMENT PHASE, INCIDENT RESPONSE PLANS FOR SCENARIOS INCLUDING MALICIOUS AND NATURAL EVENTS AS WELL AS IDENTIFICATION AND PRIORITIZATION OF POST-PROJECT FUNDING REQUIREMENTS FOR IMPROVING OUR PREVENTION AND RECOVERY ABILITIES. 

THE PRIMARY GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE OUR ABILITY TO PROTECT AND RECOVER COUNTY IT RESOURCES OVER THE LONG TERM.

prime_award_base_transaction_description: SIRT6 Suppresses Pancreatic Cancer via the Oncofetal Protein Lin28b
subaward_description:
TITLE: SIRT6 SUPPRESSES PANCREATIC CANCER VIA THE ONCOFETAL PROTEIN LIN28B
PI: DR. NHAN DO
BACKGROUND
DR. RAUL MOSTOSLAVSKY FROM MGH HAS BEEN WORKING WITH LIVE MICE TO DETERMINE IF SIRT6 FUNCTIONS AS A TUMOR SUPPRESSOR. THERE HAVE BEEN SOME POSITIVE INDICATIONS THAT IT DOES SUPPRESS TUMOR ACTIVITY. DR. RAUL MOSTOSLAVSKY RECEIVED A GRANT FROM THE DOD TO STUDY WHETHER SIRT6 FUNCTIONS AS A TUMOR SUPPRESSOR IN HUMANS. THERE ARE MANY VETERANS IN THE VA WITH PANCREATIC CANCER. IF THERE IS A POSITIVE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN SIRT6 AND TUMOR SUPPRESSION, IT COULD LEAD TO THE DEVELOPMENT OF NEW THERAPIES TO HELP THIS POPULATION.
RESEARCH DESIGN
DR. RAUL MOSTOSLAVSKY HAS MADE A FORMAL DATA REQUEST TO THE PRECISION ONCOLOGY DATA REPOSITORY (PODR IRB #2085) FOR SLIDES AND A MINIMAL AMOUNT OF DATA FROM 20 PATIENTS WITH PANCREATIC CANCER. THIS REQUEST WAS REVIEWED AND ACCEPTED BY THE PODR ADVISORY COMMITTEE. THE DATA (SLIDES AND CLINICAL DATA) WILL COME FROM COHORTS A (CONSENTED AND HIPAA AUTHORIZED PARTICIPANTS) AND B (DECEASED, HIPAA WAIVED PATIENTS). TWENTY VETERANSÃ¢Â‚¬Â„¢ DATA WILL BE UTILIZED TO FULFILL THIS DATA REQUEST.
WORK TO BE ACCOMPLISHED
A) DESCRIBE THE WORK/SUPPORT THAT VA BOSTON WILL PROVIDE (YOU CAN USE BULLET POINTS). IF THERE IS A PLAN TO HIRE NEW STUDY STAFF TO ACCOMPLISH THE WORK, PLEASE SPECIFY.
SUBRECIPIENT PI AND TEAM WILL LOCATE 20 PATIENTS FROM WITHIN THE PODR WITH A DIAGNOSIS OF PANCREATIC CANCER. THE TEAM WILL LOCATE AN FFPE BLOCK OF TISSUE FROM THE VABHS PATHOLOGY DEPARTMENT FOR EACH PATIENT. THE BLOCKS WILL BE INSPECTED BY A LICENSED PATHOLOGIST FOR APPROPRIATE TUMOR PURITY. FROM EACH BLOCK 4-5 UNSTAINED SLIDES WILL BE MADE. INCLUDED WITH THE SLIDES WILL BE THE FOLLOWING DATA POINTS: TUMOR TYPE, TUMOR GRADE, SEX, AGE IF <89YO, PRIMARY VS. RECURRENT DISEASE, AND TREATMENT NAÃƑÂ¯VE OR TREATED. THE SLIDES AND DATA POINTS WILL BE DE-IDENTIFIED AND THE CROSSWALK KEPT BEHIND THE VA FIREWALL. THE SLIDES WILL BE PACKAGED INTO A SLIDE CASE AND SHIPPED TO PTE SITE PI, RAUL MOSTOSLAVSKY. THIS WORK WILL BE PERFORMED WITH OUR EXISTING STAFF, WITH ASSISTANCE FROM PATHOLOGY.
B) DESCRIBE THE WORK/SUPPORT THAT THE COMPANY WILL PROVIDE
SUBRECIPEINT WILL RECEIVE $25,000. THESE FUNDS WILL BE USED TO DEFRAY THE COST OF A PORTION OF THE PI EFFORT
AND THE HISTOLOGY TECHNICIANÃ¢Â‚¬Â„¢S TIME TO PREPARE THE SLIDES.
INFORMATION SECURITY/PRIVACY WITH AN APPROVED AND EXECUTED, COMBINED DUA AND MTA REQUIRED BY THE PRECISION ONCOLOGY DATA REPOSITORY, WE WILL SEND MGH THE FOLLOWING DE-IDENTIFIED DATA POINTS 1) PRIMARY VS RECURRENT, 2) PRETREATMENT VS POST TREATMENT, 3) TUMOR TYPE, 4) TUMOR GRADE 5) SEX 6) AGE (<89). WE HAVE THE CONCURRENCE OF
THE WEST ROXBURY PRIVACY OFFICER FOR THE TYPE OF DATA TO BE TRANSFERRED. THE DUA/MTA IS CURRENTLY BEING REVIEWED BY MGH. NO WORK WILL BE DONE ON THIS PROJECT UNTIL THE APPROPRIATE APPROVALS FOR USE OF THE REPOSITORY ARE IN PLACE.

prime_awardee_business_types: Nonprofit with 501C3 IRS Status (Other than an Institution of Higher Education)
prime_award_base_transaction_description: Impact of Medicaid ACO funding for health-related social needs on dietary quality and health
prime_award_cfda_numbers_and_titles: 93.847: DIABETES, DIGESTIVE, AND KIDNEY DISEASES EXTRAMURAL RESEARCH
subaward_description:
UNDER THIS SUBCONTRACT, THE PARTNERS POPULATION HEALTH EVALUATION AND RESEARCH TEAM AGREES TO CREATE A SET OF FIVE KEY DATASETS NECESSARY FOR THIS GRANT. THE TEAM WILL CREATE RESEARCH DE-IDENTIFIED DATASETS WHICH COMBINE MEASURES OF HEALTH CARE UTILIZATION, DEMOGRAPHICS, HEALTH RISK, PATIENT REPORTED SOCIAL RELATED SOCIAL NEEDS AND SUBSEQUENT REFERRALS TO COMMUNITY-BASED ORGANIZATIONS. DATASETS WILL BE CREATED FROM DATA THAT ARE LINKED AND STORED WITHIN THE PARTNERS ENTERPRISE DATA WAREHOUSE (EDW). THESE DATA PROVIDE A COMPLETE PICTURE OF PATIENTS' CLINICAL AND PSYCHO-SOCIAL NEED LINKED WITH HEALTH CARE UTILIZATION, COST AND PATIENT REPORTED OUTCOMES FOR PATIENTS WITHIN OUR POPULATION HEALTH RISK CONTRACTS.
THE EVALUATION AND RESEARCH TEAM WILL PROVIDE FIVE SEPARATE PULLS DATA (BASELINE, END OF YEAR 1, END OF YEAR 2, END OF YEAR 3, AND END OF YEAR 4). INCLUSION CRITERIA WILL BE DEFINED WITHIN THE FIRST SIX MONTHS OF THE GRANT, BUT WILL INCLUDE PATIENTS SCREENED FOR HEALTH RELATED SOCIAL NEEDS REGARDLESS OF RISK CONTRACT. EACH DATA PULL WILL INCLUDE PATIENT CHARACTERISTICS AND BASELINE UTILIZATION AS WELL AS UTILIZATION, SOCIAL DETERMINANT SCREENING DATA AND INFORMATION ON COMMUNITY-BASED REFERRALS AND FLEXIBLE SERVICES AVAILABLE DURING THE POST PERIOD. PATIENT DEMOGRAPHIC DATA WILL BE PULLED FROM INTEGRATION TABLES WITHIN THE EDW. BASELINE DIAGNOSES, PROCEDURES, AND ADJUSTED CLINICAL GROUPS WILL BE USED TO CHARACTERIZE THE HEALTH RISK OF PATIENTS. WHEN AVAILABLE, CENSUS DATA ON EMPLOYMENT, INCOME, AND EDUCATION WILL BE PROVIDED. FINALLY, RESPONSES TO SOCIAL DETERMINANTS OF HEALTH SCREENING ITEMS, DATE OF SCREENING, FLEXIBLE SERVICE REFERRAL INFORMATION (DATE, PROVIDER) OR REASON FOR NON REFERRAL WILL ALSO BE PROVIDED.
THE EVALUATION AND RESEARCH TEAM WILL LINK THESE DATA TO PATIENT SPECIFIC DATA OBTAINED BY THE RESEARCH TEAM CONSISTENT WITH THE IRB APPROVED PROTOCOL. ALL DATA WILL BE TRANSFERRED AND STORED BEHIND THE PARTNERS HEALTHCARE FIREWALL. ALL INVESTIGATORS ACCESSING DATA ARE REQUIRED TO ACKNOWLEDGE APPROPRIATE DATA USE POLICIES. NO DATA WILL BE SHARED WITH NON-PARTNERS RESEARCHERS WITHOUT THE EXPLICIT PRE-APPROVAL OF THE EVALUATION AND RESEARCH TEAM.

OUR PROPOSED PROJECT IS THE NEXT VITAL STEP IN CLOSING THE GAP OF OUR CYBERSECURITY DEFICIENCIES AND BETTER PROTECTING OUR NETWORK- THE NERVOUS SYSTEM TO INFRASTRUCTURE, LAW ENFORCEMENT, EMERGENCY RESPONSE SERVICES, PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICES, LEGISLATIVE AND ELECTORAL OFFICES, AS WELL AS COUNTY RESOURCE AND ASSET SYSTEMS. 

WE WOULD LIKE TO EXPAND OUR CURRENT ISE CAPABILITIES AND DEPLOY GRANULAR ACCESS CONTROL FOR WIRED AND WIRELESS NETWORK ACCESS, INTEGRATE FIREWALLS WITH ISE FUNCTIONALITY, AND EXPAND SECURE ACCESS TO ALL COUNTY EMPLOYEES- REGARDLESS OF LOCATION. CURRENTLY, THE COUNTY NETWORK DEPENDS ON PRE-SHARED KEY AUTHENTICATION FOR EMPLOYEE NETWORK CONNECTION. WE INTEND TO IMPLEMENT 802.1X AUTHENTICATION FOR WIRED, WIRELESS, AND VPN CONNECTIONS TO OUR NETWORK.

prime_award_program_activities_funding_t: 0161: CARES ACT/CORONAVIRUS EMERGENCY SUPPLEMENTAL FUNDING (CESF) PROGRAM
prime_award_base_transaction_description: Buena Park Police Department Response to COVID-19 Pandemic
subaward_description:
ALL FUNDS AWARDED UNDER THE CESF PROGRAM ($58,714) ARE TO BE USED TO PREVENT, PREPARE FOR, AND RESPOND TO THE CURRENT CORONAVIRUS PANDEMIC. WE PROPOSE TO USE THESE FUNDS TO PAY FOR THE FOLLOWING ITEMS:
Ã¢Â‚¬Â¢	ENHANCED AND ADDITIONAL PERSONAL PROTECTIVE EQUIPMENT (PPE) FOR BPPD PERSONNEL
Ã¢Â‚¬Â¢	CLEANING AND DECONTAMINATION SUPPLIES TO PREVENT COVID-19 SPREAD IN THE BPPD HEADQUARTERS AND VEHICLES
Ã¢Â‚¬Â¢	UPGRADED FIREWALL AND WIFI HOTSPOTS TO ADDRESS INADEQUATE CAPACITY IN THE CITY EMERGENCY OPERATIONS CENTER (EOC) AND TO SUPPORT DISTRIBUTED EOC OPERATIONS AS NECESSARY
Ã¢Â‚¬Â¢	PERIODIC ELECTROSTATIC SANITATION OF POLICE VEHICLES, EQUIPMENT, AND WORK AREAS

THE EXACT QUANTITIES OF NEEDED PPE AND DECONTAMINATION SUPPLIES ARE NOT YET AVAILABLE; THE COSTS AND QUANTITIES SHOWN IN THE BUDGET WORKBOOK ARE ESTIMATES BASED ON CURRENT PURCHASES.

THE BUENA PARK POLICE DEPARTMENT PLANS TO EXPEND FUNDS SOLELY WITHIN ALLOWABLE CATEGORIES AND RETAIN ALL DOCUMENTS NECESSARY TO VERIFY THAT EXPENDITURES FALL WITHIN ACCEPTABLE PARAMETERS OF THIS SUPPLEMENTAL AWARD.

subaward_description:
STANDARD LINE ITEM NAME
ACQUIRE - ADP HARDWARE

THIS ALI WILL FUND THE PURCHASE OF ONE DISPATCH SYSTEM INCLUDING AUTOMATED VEHICLE LOCATORS AND MOBILE DATA TERMINALS WHICH MAY INCLUDE COMPUTER SYSTEMS, SERVERS, ROUTERS, SWITCHES, A NETWORK FIREWALL, PHONES, CALL CENTER HEADSETS, MOBILE DATA TERMINALS (TABLET COMPUTERS), AND PRINTERS.

USEFUL LIFE
THE EXPECTED USEFUL LIFE FOR THIS ADP HARDWARE IS 5 YEARS.

TO MITIGATE AGAINST THE RISKS IDENTIFIED, THE FOLLOWING ACTIVITIES SHOULD BE COMPLETED. IMPLEMENT, PROCURE AND / OR INSTALL CYBER MEASURES SUCH AS SECURE PASSWORD MANAGEMENT AND DOCUMENT STORAGE, BACKUP PROTECTION, MULTI-FACTOR AUTHENTICATION, UPGRADE OF THE FIREWALL, WORKSTATION SECURITY MANAGEMENT AND ENDPOINT DETECTION AND RESPONSE OTHER ACTIVITIES INCLUDE THE DEVELOPMENT AND TRAINING OF CRISIS MITIGATION CURRICULUM AS IT RELATES TO INCIDENT RESPONSE AND RECOVERY. THE PARKING LOT AND DRIVEWAY SHOULD BE PROTECTED WITH PHYSICAL BARRIERS, FENCING SHOULD BE REINFORCED AT THE EAST SIDE OF THE PARKING LOT, SECURING OF ENTRIES INTO OFFICE SUITES, SENSITIVE STORAGE, AND IT CLOSETS, ADDITIONAL 8 CAMERAS SHOULD BE INSTALLED TO CLOSE EXISTING SURVEILLANCE GAPS, AND PROCUREMENT OF MOBILE 2-WAY EMERGENCY COMMUNICATION DEVICES

PARKE COUNTY SHERIFF'S DEPARTMENT, OUR 9-1-1, AND EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT DEPARTMENT HELD A GAP ANALYSIS MEETING IN WHICH WE ADDRESSED THE CORE CAPABILITY OF ACCESS CONTROL AND IDENTITY VERIFICATION. WE ALSO RECEIVED INPUT FROM OUR IT CONSULTANT. THIS PROJECT IS TO ADDRESS THE IDENTIFIED GAPS OF VULNERABILITY; END OF LIFE SERVER LICENSES, OLDER FIREWALLS, LACK OF STORAGE AND REDUNDANCY, INADEQUATE ID SYSTEM, AND THE NEED FOR 1 MORE CAMERA. WE WILL BE REPLACING OLD WINDOWS LICENSING FOR OUR SERVERS. OUR CURRENT LICENSES ARE WINDOWS SERVER 2008 WHICH WILL NO LONGER BE SUPPORTED OR RECEIVING SECURITY UPDATES AS OF 2020; AND 1 THAT IS 2003 THAT WE WILL REPLACE AS WELL. WE WILL BE UPGRADING OUR FIREWALLS TO BETTER SECURE UNWANTED ACCESS AND ADDING REDUNDANCY TO FACILITATE INFRASTRUCTURE RECOVERY IN THE EVENT ITS NEEDED. WE WILL ALSO BE ADDING STORAGE AS WE UPGRADE THE SERVERS DUE TO THE GREATER VOLUME OF DATA FROM IN-CAR CAMERAS AND BODY CAMERAS. IN ADDITION TO THESE WE HAVE IDENTIFIED THAT OUR ID BADGE SYSTEM IS A FIRST GENERATION SYSTEM. WE WILL REPLACE OUR ID BADGE SYSTEM TO IMPROVE ACCESS CONTROL AND IDENTITY VERIFICATION TO OUR INFRASTRUCTURE, OUR COUNTY, AND OUR INCIDENT SCENES.

prime_award_base_transaction_description: Innovative methods to reduce racial and ethnic disparities in suicide risk prediction - Suicide death rates in the United States have increased 35% since 1999. In 2018, there were over 48,000 suicide deaths, and an estimated 1.4 million adults attempted suicide. In response, health systems are adopting suicide risk prediction models to guide delivery of suicide prevention interventions. Suicide prediction models estimated from health care records may perpetuate current disparities in health care access, quality, and outcomes. Suicide prediction models may not accurately identify high-risk patients from all racial and ethnic groups. Suicide rates vary by race and ethnicity, and both the highest and lowest rates are seen in traditionally underserved populations. Suicide rates are highest among American Indians and Alaskan Natives (22.1 per 100,000 people) and lowest in Asian and Pacific Islander, Black, and Hispanic populations (7.0-7.4 per 100,000 people) compared to 18.0 per 100,000 people for White non-Hispanics. Differences in performance of suicide risk prediction models across racial and ethnic subgroups have three possible sources. First, predictors of suicide risk may be measured with error, and this error may be different for racial and ethnic subgroups. Second, suicide attempts and deaths may be misclassified, and misclassification rates may differ by race and ethnicity. Third, the association between predictors and outcomes may vary by race and ethnicity, i.e., risk modification. Existing methods for estimating prediction models are not designed to address racial and ethnic disparities in performance. Estimation procedures focus on optimizing performance across the entire population, not within subgroups, and performance in less prevalent subgroups has little impact on overall accuracy. While machine learning methods, like random forest, explore interactions between predictors and race or ethnicity, suicide attempt and death are rare events, which limits the information available to identify race- and ethnicity-specific risk factors. There is also insufficient guidance on sample size calculations for prediction studies. We will develop novel statistical methods for random forest models that reduce racial and ethnic disparities in performance of suicide prediction models by addressing gaps in current methods. Aim 1 will develop new procedures for prediction model estimation that maximize predictive performance within racial and ethnic subgroups, rather than maximizing average performance across the entire population. Aim 2 will integrate methods to adjust for differential outcome misclassification in prediction model estimation and evaluation. Aim 3 will design sample size calculations to determine if a study is able to accurately predict outcomes within racial and ethnic subgroups. We will use existing data on suicide risk factors and outcomes for 15 million outpatient mental health, 10 million primary care, and 2 million emergency department visits from the NIMH- funded Mental Health Research Network to implement our methods and estimate suicide prediction models for each setting that accurately identify patients at highest risk of suicide across all races and ethnicities.
subawardee_business_types: U.S. LOCAL GOVERNMENT,EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION,STATE CONTROLLED INSTITUTION OF HIGHER LEARNING
subaward_description:
"	THE UW STUDY TEAM INCLUDES DR. NOAH SIMON, SUBAWARD PI, AND A TBN RESEARCH ASSISTANT (RA) WHO WILL BE A PHD STUDENT IN THE UW DEPARTMENT OF BIOSTATISTICS. DR. SIMON WILL ASSIST IN DEVELOPMENT OF TARGET FUNCTIONS THAT OPTIMIZE PREDICTIVE ACCURACY WITHIN
RACIAL AND ETHNIC SUBGROUPS (AIM 1). TO ACCOMPLISH THIS WORK, DR. SIMON WILL PARTICIPATE IN REGULAR TEAM MEETINGS AND WILL REVIEW
STATISTICAL CODE AS WELL AS AGGREGATE DATA OUTPUT REGARDING PREDICTION MODEL PERFORMANCE.

THE RA WILL COLLABORATE ON METHODS DEVELOPMENT AND WILL BE THE PRIMARY ANALYST FOR IMPLEMENTATION OF AIMS 1 AND 2. TO ACCOMPLISH THIS WORK, THE RA WILL BECOME A MEMBER OF THE KPWHRI WORKFORCE THROUGH A STUDENT INTERNSHIP AND WILL ACCESS STUDY DATA ONLY WITHIN THE KPWHRI FIREWALL. NO STUDY DATA WILL BE TRANSFERRED TO THE UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON. AS A MEMBER OF THE KPWHRI WORKFORCE THE RA WILL BE SUBJECT TO KPWHRI RESEARCH POLICIES AND PROCEDURES GOVERNING THE CONDUCT OF THE STUDY. THE RA WILL PARTICIPATE IN REGULAR TEAM MEETINGS BETWEEN UW AND KPWHRI AND WILL PARTICIPATE IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF DISSEMINATION PRODUCTS AS DESCRIBED IN THE RESEARCH STRATEGY INCLUDING OPEN-SOURCE STATISTICAL CODE AND SOFTWARE AND MANUSCRIPTS FOR PEER REVIEW."

subaward_description: THE TOWN OF PROSPERÃƑÂ¢Ã¢Â€ŠÂ¬Ã¢Â€ŽÂ¢S ZTNA IMPLEMENTATION PROJECT WILL IMPLEMENT AND ADD THE ZERO TRUST NETWORK ACCESS (ZTNA) PLATFORM TO THE CURRENT FIREWALL PLATFORM WHICH PROVIDES SECURE REMOTE ACCESS TO APPLICATIONS AND SERVICES BASED ON DEFINED ACCESS CONTROL POLICIES ENHANCING THE TOWNÃƑÂ¢Ã¢Â€ŠÂ¬Ã¢Â€ŽÂ¢S NETWORK CYBER SECURITY.

subaward_description: EL PASO COUNTY'S IT - CYBERSECURITY ASSESSMENT PROJECT WILL PROVIDE CONTRACTUAL SERVICES TO IMPLEMENT A LOG MANAGEMENT SYSTEM (LMS) FOR FIREWALLS AND CONDUCT PENETRATION TESTING OF THE COUNTY'S NETWORK TO ENHANCE THE CYBERSECURITY POSTURE AND REDUCE EXPLOITABLE VULNERABILITIES THAT CAN JEOPARDIZE THE COMPUTER SYSTEM'S AVAILABILITY.

THE STATE OF MONTANAÃ¢Â‚¬Â„¢S INFORMATION AND DATA SYSTEMS EXPERIENCE NEAR PERPETUAL ATTACKS FROM A VARIETY OF MALICIOUS ACTORS AND THREATS VIA THE INTERNET ON A DAILY BASIS.  AS ATTACKS AND TECHNIQUES HAVE EVOLVED, SECURITY BEST-PRACTICES SUGGEST THE IMPLEMENTATION OF FIREWALLS, INTRUSION DETECTION AND PREVENTION, WEB-FILTERING, ANTI-MALWARE, ETC.  FOR ALL OF THESE ADVANCEMENTS IN NETWORK PERIMETER DEFENSES, SADLY THE ONE WEAK-LINK IN THE CHAIN IS US Ã¢Â‚¬Â€Œ THE HUMAN.
FOR ALL THE MONEY THAT THE STATE OF MONTANA HAS INVESTED IN INFORMATION SECURITY, ZERO-DAY THREATS ARISE ON A FREQUENT BASIS.  COUPLED WITH NATION-STATE ACTORS, HACKTIVISTS, AND CYBER-TERRORISTS, THE MINDSET HAS CHANGED FROM Ã¢Â‚¬Å“IFÃ¢Â‚¬Ï¿½ TO Ã¢Â‚¬Å“WHENÃ¢Â‚¬Ï¿½ CONCERNING THE INEVITABILITY OF A DATA BREACH.  WITH AN IN-HOUSE CYBER FORENSICS TOOL, THE STATE INFORMATION SYSTEMS SECURITY OFFICEÃ¢Â‚¬Â„¢S INCIDENT RESPONSE PLAN IS ENHANCED WITH THE ABILITY TO COLLECT DIGITAL EVIDENCE IN A METHOD THAT KEEPS IT INTACT AND USABLE IN REGARDS TO A CRIMINAL INVESTIGATION OR INTERNAL AUDIT.  THE GOAL OF CYBER FORENSICS IS ACCURACY.  INCIDENT INVESTIGATIONS MUST FOLLOW STRICT GUIDELINES TO ENSURE MAXIMUM ACCURACY SHOULD A CYBER-INCIDENT GO TO COURT AS WELL AS MAINTAIN PROPER CHAIN-OF-EVIDENCE TO PROTECT FROM DATA SPOILAGE.
INCIDENT RESPONSE AND HANDLING IS LIKE PUTTING TOGETHER A PUZZLE.  IN ORDER TO SOLVE A PUZZLE, ONE MUST HAVE ALL THE PIECES.  CYBER FORENSICS SUPPLIES A CRITICAL AND CURRENTLY-MISSING PIECE OF THAT PUZZLE.  THE NEED TO BE ABLE TO SIFT THROUGH PAST EVENTS ON A DEVICE IS GREAT, ESPECIALLY IN INSTANCES OF A DATA BREACH, WHERE THE AVERAGE BREACH GOES 400+ DAYS BEFORE BEING DISCOVERED.  A CYBER FORENSICS TOOL COULD ALSO BE USED IN SCENARIOS OTHER THAN A DATA BREACH.  HUMAN RESOURCE INVESTIGATIONS, FRAUD, LITIGATION, DATA AUDITINGÃ¢Â‚¬Â€?THESE ARE JUST A FEW EXAMPLES WHERE CYBER FORENSICS CAN REVEAL QUESTIONABLE OR MALICIOUS CONDUCT WITHIN OUR ORGANIZATION.
THE CYBER-FORENSICS TOOL THAT THE STATE WOULD LIKE TO USE IS GUIDANCE SOFTWAREÃ¢Â‚¬Â„¢S ENCASE V. 7 ENTERPRISE.  WITH THIS PRODUCT, A CYBER-FORENSICS EXAMINER WOULD BE ABLE TO ANALYZE MULTIPLE COMPUTERS FROM A CENTRAL LOCATION WITHOUT DISRUPTING ANY BUSINESS.  BEING ABLE TO PULL A DISK IMAGE OVER THE WIRE IS IDEAL WHEN IT COMES TO DEALING WITH DATA BREACHES, ESPECIALLY AS THE BREACH IS OCCURRING.  THE ENCASE ENTERPRISE TOOL IS ABLE TO PULL VOLATILE (MEMORY-RESIDENT) DATA FROM MULTIPLE MACHINES ACROSS THE NETWORK.  DISCRETELY PULLING THIS INFORMATION FROM A WORKSTATION ALLOWS FOR DATA PRESERVATION THAT COULD BE A KEY PIECE OF EVIDENCE FOR A LITIGATION CASE.  AND THE DATA IS PRESERVED IN AN EVIDENCE FILE FORMAT THAT IS COURT-ACCEPTED.

subaward_description:
HUMANA WILL ASSIST DR GURWITZ AND DR SINGH AT UMASS CHAN MEDICAL SCHOOL AND DR LI AT THE HARVARD PILGRIM HEALTH CARE INSTITUTE TO ACCOMPLISH AIM 1 : TO DEVELOP AND VALIDATE AN ALGORITHM, EMPLOYING HEALTH CARE ADMINISTRATIVE CLAIMS DATA, FOR IMPORTANT SAFETY-RELATED EVENTS RELATING TO ANTI-AMYLOID THERAPIES INCLUDING ARIA.
THE STUDY WILL UTILIZE THE INFRASTRUCTURE CREATED BY THE SENTINEL SYSTEM AT HUMANA.1 (SEE LETTER OF SUPPORT FROM RICHARD PLATT, MD) FOR THE STUDY. THE ELECTRONIC DATA USED WILL BE ACCESSED, MAINTAINED, AND PROTECTED, AS PART OF A ÃƑÂ¢Ã¢Â€ŠÂ¬Ã…Â€ŒDISTRIBUTED SYSTEMÃƑÂ¢Ã¢Â€ŠÂ¬Ã¯Â¿Â½ IN THE EXISTING SECURE ENVIRONMENT AND HUMANA WILL RETAIN PHYSICAL AND OPERATIONAL CONTROL OVER THEIR ELECTRONIC HEALTH DATA BEHIND THEIR INSTITUTIONAL FIREWALLS. THE DATA ARE ALREADY TRANSFORMED INTO THE SENTINEL COMMON DATA MODEL, WHICH FACILITATES THE EXECUTION OF STANDARDIZED ANALYTIC QUERIES DISTRIBUTED BY THE SENTINEL OPERATIONS CENTER, WHICH IS BASED AT HARVARD PILGRIM HEALTH CARE INSTITUTE. THIS SYSTEM WILL PROTECT THE PRIVACY AND CONFIDENTIALITY OF INDIVIDUAL-LEVEL HEALTH INFORMATION.
IN PARTNERSHIP WITH HARVARD PILGRIM HEALTH CARE INSTITUTE AND UMASS CHAN MEDICAL SCHOOL THE ADMINISTRATIVE DATA SET AT HUMANA WILL BE QUERIED TO SELECT A COHORT OF PATIENTS WITH AD BASED ON A CLAIMS-BASED ALGORITHM ADAPTED FROM THE ONE USED IN THE D-PRESCRIBE-AD STUDY. AS NO SPECIFIC ICD-10-CM DIAGNOSIS CODES ARE CURRENTLY AVAILABLE FOR ARIA, THE TEAM WILL FIRST DEVELOP SEVERAL CLAIMS-BASED ALGORITHMS FOR ARIA IN CONSULTATION WITH OUR EXPERT CONSULTANT ON NEURORADIOLOGY BASED ON EXISTING DIAGNOSIS CODES MOST REFLECTIVE OF ARIA. USING THE CLAIMS-BASED ALGORITHM, HUMANA WILL SELECT POTENTIAL CASES OF ARIA IN THE ADMINISTRATIVE HEALTH DATA AMONG THE COHORT OF PATIENTS WITH AD. HUMANA WILL RUN STANDARD QUERIES DEVELOPED BY THE HARVARD PILGRIM HEALTH CARE INSTITUTE TO DESCRIBE THE PARTICIPANT CHARACTERS ( DEMOGRAPHICS, RACE AND ETHNICITY, AGE, SEX) AND COMORBIDITY SCORES TO DESCRIBE THE SAMPLE SELECTED FOR STUDY. THE OUTPUT OF QUERIES WILL BE SHARED WITH THE OPERATIONS CENTER VIA A SECURE NETWORK PORTAL.
HUMANA WILL CONTACT RESPECTIVE HEALTHCARE PROVIDERS TO REQUEST MEDICAL CHARTS OF THESE SELECTED PATIENTS FOR REVIEW. HUMANA WILL RETRIEVE RECORDS, INCLUDING BRAIN MRI AND CT SCAN REPORTS, OVER A PERIOD OF TIME EXTENDING FROM 30 DAYS BEFORE TO 30 DAYS AFTER THE DATE OF THE RELEVANT DIAGNOSIS OF ARIA. HUMANA INTENDS TO USE MEDVIEWHEALTH, A VENDOR TO CONTACT MEDICAL PROVIDERS AND SOURCE MRI AND CT REPORTS.
RECORDS WILL BE DEIDENTIFIED TO PROTECT THE PRIVACY OF PARTICIPANTS AND SHARED BY HUMANA WITH THE TEAM AT THE UMASS CHAN MEDICAL SCHOOL UNDER A DATA USE AGREEMENT. HUMANA WILL REQUEST RECORDS FOR 150 PATIENTS AND ANTICIPATE RETREIVAL OF 100 CHARTS WITH COMPLETE INFORMATION. ADJUDICATION WILL OCCUR AT UMASS CHAN MEDICAL SCHOOL.

prime_award_base_transaction_description: New Award DE-CR0000016, GridDeep:  AI-Integrated Physics-based Attack Resilient Proactive System for Distribution Automation and DER Monitoring and Control Applications
subaward_description: EPRI SEEKS TO LEVERAGE ITS RESEARCH EXPERIENCE IN INTEGRATION OF SIEM AND OPENDERMS TECHNOLOGIES WITHIN UTILITY ENVIRONMENTS AND EXTEND THIS EXPERTISE FOR DER INTEGRATION. THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS TASK IS TO DEMONSTRATE PRACTICAL IMPLEMENTATION OF SIEM, OPENDERMS, AND INTRUSION DETECTION AND PREVENTION TECHNOLOGIES TO REALIZE RAPID INCIDENT RESPONSE FOR DERS. SUBTASKS ACROSS PHASE 1 AND PHASE 2 INCLUDE: PHASE 1 SUBTASKS (R&D): -TASK 6: DESIGN & DEVELOP CYBER-PHYSICAL INTRUSION DETECTION/PREVENTION (IDS/IPS) AND INTEGRATION WITH SIEM & OPENDERMS - THIS TASK INCLUDES DEVELOPMENT OF WEB-APPLICATION FIREWALL (WAF) AND INTRUSION DETECTION AND PREVENTION SYSTEMS (IDS/IPS) TECHNOLOGY FOR DER COMMUNICATIONS, INCLUDING IEEE 2030.5/SEP2 AND DNP3 WITH DER PROFILES. WAF AND IDS/IPS TECHNOLOGY WILL COORDINATE WITH SIEM TECHNOLOGIES TO DEMONSTRATE PRACTICAL BOUNDARY PROTECTION AND INCIDENT RESPONSE PROCESSES FOR UTILITIES INTEGRATING DERS. -TASK 8: TESTBED-BASED INTEGRATION, TESTING, EVALUATION, AND SCALED SYSTEM-LEVEL VERIFICATION UNDER TESTBED ENVIRONMENT - EPRI SEEKS TO SUPPORT ISU'S LABORATORY TESTING WITH INTEGRATION OF ITS OPENDERMS PLATFORM WITHIN THEIR TESTBED ENVIRONMENT. SUPPORT WILL BE PROVIDED TO INTEGRATE OPENDERMS WITH ITS CYBER-PHYSICAL SECURITY SITUATIONAL AWARENESS AND INTRUSION DETECTION AND MITIGATION PLATFORMS AND MACHINE LEARNING, MODEL-BASED ALGORITHMS. PHASE 2 (DEMONSTRATION): -TASK 9, TASK 10, AND TASK 11: TESTBED, SMALL-SCALE FIELD TESTING, AND UTILITY-SCALE FIELD TESTING - EPRI WILL ASSIST ISU IN ITS DEMONSTRATIONS ACROSS TASK 9-11, SPECIFICALLY FOR DEMONSTRATION COMPONENTS INVOLVING IDS/IPS, WAF, AND OPENDERMS TECHNOLOGIES. THE DEMONSTRATION WILL SHOWCASE COORDINATION OF RESEARCH AND TECHNOLOGIES DEVELOPED IN PHASE 1, INCLUSIVE OF SIEM, IEEE 2030.5 WAF/IPS/IDS, AND AI/ML ALGORITHMS DEVELOPED IN OTHER PROJECT TASKS. -TASK 12 AND TASK 13: EPRI SEEKS TO COORDINATE WITH ISU TO PERFORM COST-BENEFIT AND ECONOMIC ANALYSIS OF SECURITY SOLUTIONS IT HAS DEVELOPED AS PART OF THIS PROJECT, TO DEMONSTRATE VALUE FOR UTILITIES AND BTM DER OWNERS AND CUSTOMERS. ADDITIONALLY, EPRI SEEKS TO WORK WITH ISU TO DEVELOP A PLAN FOR PRODUCTION, COMMERCIALIZATION, AND MARKET SUSTAINABILITY FOR TECHNOLOGIES DEVELOPED.

BOMB SQUAD SUSTAINMENT, MOBILE COMMAND VEHICLES, HAZMAT RESPONSE SUSTAINMENT, REGIONAL PLANNING, CRITICAL INFRASTRUCTURE PROTECTION, ENHANCING CYBERSECURITY, INDIVIDUAL FIRST AID/TRAUMA KITS AND TRAINING AIDS, VEHICLE TAG READER, K9 EXPLOSIVES TRAINING AIDS, TACTICAL UNIT EQUIPMENT, LE TRAINING AND AWARENESS, OEM INTEROPERABLE COMMUNICATIONS, EMERGENCY PLANNER, MCAC, LE HELICOPTER HOIST, CBRNE- TACTICAL TECHNICAL RESCUE GEAR, COMMUNITY RISK REDUCTION, CYBERSECURITY PROGRAM- FIREWALL, PREPAREDNESS PROGRAM
PURCHASE FIREWALLS TO INCREASE CYBERSECURITY ENHANCEMENT
