The breadth and depth of capabilities provided by the OOI provide transformative scientific and educational opportunities for the community at large. OOI manages and operates five ocean arrays located at scientifically strategic locations in the open ocean (Global Arrays), shelf waters (Coastal Arrays), and on the seabed (Cabled Array). The Global Irminger Sea Array (off Greenland) provides physical, biological, and chemical measurements of the water column. It captures mesoscale variability and air-sea fluxes in a region of documented deep-water formation, which impacts the Atlantic meridional overturning circulation and changes in ocean heat transport. The Station Papa Array (Gulf of Alaska) quantifies water column properties and mesoscale variability in a region of longstanding scientific interest for studies ranging from ocean circulation and air-sea fluxes to carbon cycling and biological productivity amongst others. In 2024, the Pioneer Array will be relocated to the Mid-Atlantic Bight where it will enable new science and educational opportunities in a high-energy continental shelf environment. Its design will address the influence of the strong western boundary current in this part of the Atlantic as well as terrestrial freshwater inputs to the biologically productive and diverse ecosystems found there. The Regional Cabled Array brings high-power and high-bandwidth capacity, which allows real-time, two-way communications with the oceans. It will continue to provide new insights into interlinked seismic, volcanic, and hydrothermal processes operating off the Oregon coast, the flux of methane from the seafloor, and the seafloor biosphere. The Endurance Array provides interdisciplinary observations within the coastal upwelling region of the Oregon and Washington coasts, provides observations of the eastern boundary current regime at both short and longer, climate-relevant time scales that lead to new insights into shelf/slope nutrient exchange, air-sea property exchange, carbon cycling, and ocean acidification. This renewal award to Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution (WHOI), for continued operations and management, builds upon the accomplishments of the initial award and incorporates new operational and outreach changes in response to community input. WHOI, the University of Washington (UW), and Oregon State University (OSU) will continue to provide scientific and technical management and operation and maintenance for the next phase of the Ocean Observatories Initiative. The organizational structure of the initial award will be retained with the Program Management Office (PMO) residing at WHOI under the direction of the National Science Foundation. Each of the three institutions will continue to maintain the marine and computing assets for which they are currently responsible; WHOI will operate the Pioneer Array, and the two Global Arrays in the Irminger Sea and at Station Papa, UW will operate the Regional Cabled Array, and OSU will operate the Endurance Array and the Cyberinfrastructure systems, including data ingestion and delivery. Performance metrics for OOI include quantification of scientific output, program management, systems performance, data usage, data quality, and community engagement. This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.- Subawards are planned for this award.
subawardee_business_types: U.S. STATE GOVERNMENT,1862 LAND GRANT COLLEGE,EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION,STATE CONTROLLED INSTITUTION OF HIGHER LEARNING,VETERINARY COLLEGE,SCHOOL OF FORESTRY
subaward_description:
COASTAL ENDURANCE ARRAY:  **MANAGEMENT** INCLUDES ENGINEERING OVERSIGHT AND THE MAINTENANCE AND OPERATION OF ARRAY ASSETS, MANAGEMENT AND PILOTING OF GLIDERS AND SYSTEM HEALTH MONITORING OF UNCABLED ENDURANCE ARRAY INFRASTRUCTURE, AND DESIGN CONFIGURATION MANAGEMENT OF THE AS DEPLOYED TECHNICAL DATA PACKAGE. ADDITIONALLY, THIS CATEGORY INCLUDES THE DATA TEAM. THE DATA TEAM PROVIDES QUALITY ASSURANCE AND QUALITY CONTROL OF OOI DATA AND WORKS WITH CYBERINFRASTRUCTURE STAFF ON DELIVERING QUALITY DATA THROUGH OOIÃƑÂ¯Ã‚Â¿Ã‚Â½S WEBSITE WITH APPROPRIATE METADATA AND ANNOTATIONS. **REFURBISHMENT**  INCLUDES COASTAL SURFACE MOORINGS, COASTAL PROFILER MOORINGS, COASTAL SURFACE PIERCING PROFILERS, AND COASTAL GLIDERS. EACH OF THE PLATFORMS REFERENCED ABOVE HAS AN ACTIVITIES-BASED ESTIMATE DEFINING BUILD, INTEGRATE AND TEST COSTS FOR SYSTEMS AND SUBSYSTEMS DEFINED BY THE PROJECT. THE ACTIVITIES-BASED ESTIMATES ARE CONSISTENT WITH ACTUAL YEARLY EXPENDITURES IN THE OOI PROGRAM FROM OOI 2.0 WITH APPROPRIATE ADJUSTMENTS TO OSUÃƑÂ¯Ã‚Â¿Ã‚Â½S CURRENT INSTITUTIONAL RATES AND INDIRECT COST STRUCTURE. **CRUISE** INCLUDE DEPLOYMENTS AND RECOVERIES OF THE ENDURANCE ARRAY PLATFORMS. IT INCLUDES BOTH SHIPBOARD AND NON-SHIPBOARD LABOR SUPPORT. SHIPBOARD LABOR IS BASED ON THE SHIP TIME AND STAFFING NEEDED TO DEPLOY AND RECOVER ENDURANCE ARRAY PLATFORMS. NON-SHIPBOARD LABOR INCLUDES PLANNING, PRE/POST CRUISE PACK, MOBILIZATION OF MOORINGS AND GLIDERS, POST CRUISE DEMOBILIZATION, EQUIPMENT MAINTENANCE, AND SAMPLE PROCESSING.

DATA CENTER: THE OOI DC PROVIDES STORAGE, COMPUTATION, BACKUP, DISASTER RECOVERY, AND CLOUD-LIKE ACCESS FOR THE OOI PROGRAM DATA. THE OOI 2.0 DATA CENTER CONSISTS OF FIVE RACKS THAT HOUSE 5 AND 7-NODE VXRAIL CLUSTERS THAT RUN THE PRODUCTION AND DEVELOPMENT SOFTWARE ENVIRONMENTS, RESPECTIVELY; A 3.8 PB ISILON STORAGE CLUSTER; A ML3 BACKUP TAPE LIBRARY AND 3 ASSOCIATED R440 SERVERS; A 28-NODE C6420 CASSANDRA CLUSTER; A 20-NODE C6420 CLUSTER FOR THE DATA EXPLORER AND JUPYTERHUB ENVIRONMENTS; 2 PALO ALTO FIREWALLS; AND 14 NETWORK SWITCHES. CONSISTENT WITH THE ANNUAL WORK PLAN (AWP), THE DATA CENTER WILL BE REFRESHED IN PYVI TO CONSIST OF FIVE RACKS THAT HOUSE POWERPROTECT CYBER RECOVERY VAULT AND DATA DOMAIN APPLIANCES; A 24-NODE CASSANDRA CLUSTER; A 16-NODE VXRAIL CLUSTER; 2 CORE NETWORK SWITCHES; 2 PALO ALTO FIREWALLS; AND AN 8 PB ISILON STORAGE CLUSTER. ADDITIONALLY, AN 8 PB ELASTIC CLOUD STORAGE (ECS) CLUSTER WILL BE LOCATED IN THE CASCADE DIVIDE DATA CENTER IN BEND, OREGON. THIS ECS CLUSTER WILL PROVIDE A REMOTE, OFFSITE COPY OF THE RAW DATA.

prime_award_base_transaction_description: Research Infrastructure: Management and Operations of the Ocean Observatories Initiative (OOI 2.5) -The Ocean Observatories Initiative (OOI) is a community-inspired and community-serving research observatory. Its mission is to safely operate and maintain sophisticated arrays of instruments and associated infrastructure that collect, archive, and distribute quality oceanic and marine atmospheric data to the ocean and Earth science communities. OOI measurements provide comprehensive insights into the Earth, ocean, and atmosphere for scientists, educators, students, laypersons, industry, and policymakers. OOI data and derived products improve our understanding of the processes that impact climate variability, ecosystems, fisheries, geohazards, and the subseafloor environment, which in turn advance the capabilities of decision-makers charged with the stewardship of ocean resources. Common and open access to OOI data and resources fosters partnerships between international academic and non-academic organizations. All OOI data are backed up by documented procedures and metadata, distributed freely to users via a common web portal (at www.oceanobservatories.org), and archived. OOI?s open data policies support early career scientists and investigators as well as an array of educational programs. The breadth and depth of capabilities provided by the OOI provide transformative scientific and educational opportunities for the community at large. OOI manages and operates five ocean arrays located at scientifically strategic locations in the open ocean (Global Arrays), shelf waters (Coastal Arrays), and on the seabed (Cabled Array). The Global Irminger Sea Array (off Greenland) provides physical, biological, and chemical measurements of the water column. It captures mesoscale variability and air-sea fluxes in a region of documented deep-water formation, which impacts the Atlantic meridional overturning circulation and changes in ocean heat transport. The Station Papa Array (Gulf of Alaska) quantifies water column properties and mesoscale variability in a region of longstanding scientific interest for studies ranging from ocean circulation and air-sea fluxes to carbon cycling and biological productivity amongst others. In 2024, the Pioneer Array will be relocated to the Mid-Atlantic Bight where it will enable new science and educational opportunities in a high-energy continental shelf environment. Its design will address the influence of the strong western boundary current in this part of the Atlantic as well as terrestrial freshwater inputs to the biologically productive and diverse ecosystems found there. The Regional Cabled Array brings high-power and high-bandwidth capacity, which allows real-time, two-way communications with the oceans. It will continue to provide new insights into interlinked seismic, volcanic, and hydrothermal processes operating off the Oregon coast, the flux of methane from the seafloor, and the seafloor biosphere. The Endurance Array provides interdisciplinary observations within the coastal upwelling region of the Oregon and Washington coasts, provides observations of the eastern boundary current regime at both short and longer, climate-relevant time scales that lead to new insights into shelf/slope nutrient exchange, air-sea property exchange, carbon cycling, and ocean acidification. This renewal award to Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution (WHOI), for continued operations and management, builds upon the accomplishments of the initial award and incorporates new operational and outreach changes in response to community input. WHOI, the University of Washington (UW), and Oregon State University (OSU) will continue to provide scientific and technical management and operation and maintenance for the next phase of the Ocean Observatories Initiative. The organizational structure of the initial award will be retained with the Program Management Office (PMO) residing at WHOI under the direction of the National Science Foundation. Each of the three institutions will continue to maintain the marine and computing assets for which they are currently responsible; WHOI will operate the Pioneer Array, and the two Global Arrays in the Irminger Sea and at Station Papa, UW will operate the Regional Cabled Array, and OSU will operate the Endurance Array and the Cyberinfrastructure systems, including data ingestion and delivery. Performance metrics for OOI include quantification of scientific output, program management, systems performance, data usage, data quality, and community engagement. This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.- Subawards are planned for this award.

prime_award_base_transaction_description: ENHANCING REGIONAL INFRASTRUCTURES FOR EARLY CASE CAPTURE OF PEDIATRIC AND YOUNG
prime_award_cfda_numbers_and_titles: 93.283: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION_INVESTIGATIONS AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
subawardee_business_types: NONPROFIT ORGANIZATION,EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION,STATE CONTROLLED INSTITUTION OF HIGHER LEARNING
subaward_description:
THIS PROJECT IS FOCUSED ON IDENTIFYING CANCER CASES WITHIN THE SPECIFIED POPULATION USING OBSERVATIONAL DATA SHARED WITHIN A HEALTH INFORMATION EXCHANGE. TO PERFORM THIS TASK, KNOWLEDGE OF THE VARIETY OF DIFFERENT CLINICAL DATA TYPES SHARED WITHIN THE EXCHANGE AND KNOWLEDGE OF THE INFORMATIONAL CONTENT AND CHARACTERISTICS OF THE DATA BEING EXCHANGED ARE NECESSARY. ALSO IMPORTANT IN THIS PROCESS IS THE ABILITY TO DEVELOP BUSINESS RULES AND FILTERS TO SPECIFICALLY IDENTIFY THE PARTICULAR CLINICAL CASES OF INTEREST. 

DR. GRANNIS WILL WORK WITH THE STAKEHOLDERS IN THIS PROJECT TO IDENTIFY APPROPRIATE DATA SOURCES FROM WHICH CANCER CASES CAN BE IDENTIFIED. THESE INCLUDE SOURCES SUCH AS PATHOLOGY REPORTS AND ELECTRONIC TRANSACTIONS CONTAINING DIAGNOSES SPECIFIC FOR CANCER. ADDITIONALLY DR. GRANNIS WILL PROVIDE GUIDANCE REGARDING PARTICULAR STRATEGIES FOR IDENTIFYING, FILTERING, AND TRANSMITTING CLINICAL RESULTS OF INTEREST TO THE APPROPRIATE PUBLIC HEALTH STAKEHOLDERS. HE WILL ALSO PROVIDE OVERSIGHT OF THE SOFTWARE DEVELOPER WITH THE PROJECT COORDINATOR.

DR. SHAUN GRANNIS IS RECOGNIZED AS AN INTERNATIONAL EXPERT IN DESIGNING HEALTH INFORMATION EXCHANGE DATA FLOWS WITH PRACTICAL EXPERIENCE EXPANDING THE NATION'S MOST COMPREHENSIVE AND LONGEST TENURED HEALTH INFORMATION EXCHANGE, THE INDIANA NETWORK FOR PATIENT CARE. HE HAS ALSO ARCHITECTED THE NATION'S LARGEST AND LONGEST-RUNNING AUTOMATED ELECTRONIC PUBLIC HEALTH CASE DETECTION SYSTEM, WHICH OPERATES WITHIN THE HEALTH INFORMATION EXCHANGE. 

INDIANA UNIVERSITY, REGENSTRIEF INSTITUTE WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR DEVELOPING THE METHODS FOR IDENTIFYING AND FILTERING PATH REPORTS FROM INDIANAÃ¢Â‚¬Â„¢S PRODUCTION HEALTH INFORMATION EXCHANGE (HIE) FOR ROUTING TO THE KY CANCER REGISTRY.  THIS WILL REQUIRE MORE THAN A SINGLE DEVELOPER FOR BUILDING AN INTERFACE.  THIS WILL ALSO REQUIRE STRONG INPUT FROM A SUBJECT MATTER EXPERT (SME) FOR GUIDANCE ON THE RULES FOR EXTRACTING THE CORRECT PATH REPORTS FROM THE HIE. THEY WILL ALSO BE RESPONSIBLE FOR NAVIGATING THE INTERNAL INFRASTRUCTURE, REQUIRING EFFORT FROM SEVERAL SYSTEM ENGINEERS TO CREATE A PATHWAY FOR ROUTING THE IDENTIFIED REPORTS FROM THE INITIAL EXTRACT THROUGH DMZS, FIREWALLS, ETC TO THE FINAL INTERFACE THAT BRIDGES THE INPC AND KENTUCKY CANCER REGISTRY.  

REGENSTRIEF  INSTITUTE, INC. WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR THE OVERALL COORDINATION OF THE PROJECT AS WELL AS DEVELOPING INFRASTRUCTURE AND METHODS FOR EXTRACTING KEY CONCEPTS.  REGENSTRIEF WILL SHARE LESSONS, PROCESSES, TECHNIQUES, AND SOFTWARE DEVELOPED UNDER THE AUSPICES OF THIS GRANT WITH THE COLLABORATION TEAM, THE CDC, AND OTHER STATE REGISTRIES. PUBLICATIONS, REPORTS, ETC ARE ALSO VERY NORMAL WORK PRODUCTS FOR REGENSTRIEF AND THEY WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THOSE AND TAKE THE LEAD ON SOME AS THE PROJECT UNFOLDS.

THE PROJECT COORDINATOR WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR THE DAY-TO-DAY COORDINATION OF THE PROJECT, INCLUDING REPORTING, TASK MANAGEMENT, AND GENERAL OVERSIGHT. THE PROJECT COORDINATOR WILL WORK CLOSELY WITH THE PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR TO ENSURE THE PROJECT IS SUCCESSFUL AND ALL DEADLINES ARE MET. 

THE SYSTEMS ENGINEER I WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR DEVELOPING THE INFRASTRUCTURE WITHIN THE HIE TO DELIVER ALL CANCER E-PATH REPORTS FOR KENTUCKY RESIDENTS TO THE KENTUCKY CANCER REGISTRY AND THE DEVELOPMENT/REFINEMENT OF ALGORITHMS AND OPEN SOURCE APPLICATIONS TO EXTRACT KEY CONCEPTS FROM PATHOLOGY REPORTS AND OTHER ELECTRONIC SOURCES FOR PEDIATRIC CASES.

DR. GRANNIS WILL WORK WITH THE STAKEHOLDERS IN THIS PROJECT TO IDENTIFY APPROPRIATE DATA SOURCES FROM WHICH CANCER CASES CAN BE IDENTIFIED. THESE INCLUDE SOURCES SUCH AS PATHOLOGY REPORTS AND ELECTRONIC TRANSACTIONS CONTAINING DIAGNOSES SPECIFIC FOR CANCER. ADDITIONALLY DR. GRANNIS WILL PROVIDE GUIDANCE REGARDING PARTICULAR STRATEGIES FOR IDENTIFYING, FILTERING, AND TRANSMITTING CLINICAL RESULTS OF INTEREST TO THE APPROPRIATE PUBLIC HEALTH STAKEHOLDERS. HE WILL ALSO PROVIDE OVERSIGHT OF THE SOFTWARE DEVELOPER WITH THE PROJECT COORDINATOR.

DR. SHAUN GRANNIS IS RECOGNIZED AS AN INTERNATIONAL EXPERT IN DESIGNING HEALTH INFORMATION EXCHANGE DATA FLOWS WITH PRACTICAL EXPERIENCE EXPANDING THE NATION'S MOST COMPREHENSIVE AND LONGEST TENURED HEALTH INFORMATION EXCHANGE, THE INDIANA NETWORK FOR PATIENT CARE. HE HAS ALSO ARCHITECTED THE NATION'S LARGEST AND LONGEST-RUNNING AUTOMATED ELECTRONIC PUBLIC HEALTH CASE DETECTION SYSTEM, WHICH OPERATES WITHIN THE HEALTH INFORMATION EXCHANGE. 

INDIANA UNIVERSITY, REGENSTRIEF INSTITUTE WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR DEVELOPING THE METHODS FOR IDENTIFYING AND FILTERING PATH REPORTS FROM INDIANAÃ¢Â‚¬Â„¢S PRODUCTION HEALTH INFORMATION EXCHANGE (HIE) FOR ROUTING TO THE KY CANCER REGISTRY.  THIS WILL REQUIRE MORE THAN A SINGLE DEVELOPER FOR BUILDING AN INTERFACE.  THIS WILL ALSO REQUIRE STRONG INPUT FROM A SUBJECT MATTER EXPERT (SME) FOR GUIDANCE ON THE RULES FOR EXTRACTING THE CORRECT PATH REPORTS FROM THE HIE. THEY WILL ALSO BE RESPONSIBLE FOR NAVIGATING THE INTERNAL INFRASTRUCTURE, REQUIRING EFFORT FROM SEVERAL SYSTEM ENGINEERS TO CREATE A PATHWAY FOR ROUTING THE IDENTIFIED REPORTS FROM THE INITIAL EXTRACT THROUGH DMZS, FIREWALLS, ETC TO THE FINAL INTERFACE THAT BRIDGES THE INPC AND KENTUCKY CANCER REGISTRY.  

REGENSTRIEF  INSTITUTE, INC. WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR THE OVERALL COORDINATION OF THE PROJECT AS WELL AS DEVELOPING INFRASTRUCTURE AND METHODS FOR EXTRACTING KEY CONCEPTS.  REGENSTRIEF WILL SHARE LESSONS, PROCESSES, TECHNIQUES, AND SOFTWARE DEVELOPED UNDER THE AUSPICES OF THIS GRANT WITH THE COLLABORATION TEAM, THE CDC, AND OTHER STATE REGISTRIES. PUBLICATIONS, REPORTS, ETC ARE ALSO VERY NORMAL WORK PRODUCTS FOR REGENSTRIEF AND THEY WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THOSE AND TAKE THE LEAD ON SOME AS THE PROJECT UNFOLDS.

THE PROJECT COORDINATOR WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR THE DAY-TO-DAY COORDINATION OF THE PROJECT, INCLUDING REPORTING, TASK MANAGEMENT, AND GENERAL OVERSIGHT. THE PROJECT COORDINATOR WILL WORK CLOSELY WITH THE PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR TO ENSURE THE PROJECT IS SUCCESSFUL AND ALL DEADLINES ARE MET. 

THE SYSTEMS ENGINEER I WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR DEVELOPING THE INFRASTRUCTURE WITHIN THE HIE TO DELIVER ALL CANCER E-PATH REPORTS FOR KENTUCKY RESIDENTS TO THE KENTUCKY CANCER REGISTRY AND THE DEVELOPMENT/REFINEMENT OF ALGORITHMS AND OPEN SOURCE APPLICATIONS TO EXTRACT KEY CONCEPTS FROM PATHOLOGY REPORTS AND OTHER ELECTRONIC SOURCES FOR PEDIATRIC CASES.

prime_awardee_name: OHIO OFFICE OF CRIMINAL JUSTICE SERVICES
prime_award_base_transaction_description: The Edward Byrne Memorial Justice Assistance Grant (JAG) Program allows states to support a broad range of activities to prevent and control crime based on their own state and local needs and conditions. Grant funds can be used for state and local initiatives, technical assistance, training, personnel, equipment, supplies, contractual support, and information systems for criminal justice or civil proceedings, including for any one or more of the following program areas: 1) law enforcement programs; 2) prosecution and court programs; 3) prevention and education programs; 4) corrections and community corrections programs; 5) drug treatment and enforcement programs; 6) planning, evaluation, and technology improvement programs; 7) crime victim and witness programs (other than compensation); 8) mental health programs and related law enforcement and corrections programs, including behavioral programs and crisis intervention teams; and 9) implementation of state crisis intervention court proceedings and related programs or initiatives, including but not limited to: mental health courts; drug courts; veterans courts; and extreme risk protection order programs.
prime_award_cfda_numbers_and_titles: 16.738: EDWARD BYRNE MEMORIAL JUSTICE ASSISTANCE GRANT PROGRAM; 16.750: SUPPORT FOR ADAM WALSH ACT IMPLEMENTATION GRANT PROGRAM
subaward_description: WE HAVE A CLEAR AND CONCISE PLAN OF IMPLEMENTATION FOR THIS PROJECT. WE PLAN TO SEPARATE FROM ONE NETWORK AND CREATE A NEW NETWORK IF AWARDED THE FUNDING. WE WOULD INSTALL ENCLOSED AND CLIMATE-CONTROLLED EQUIPMENT RACKS TO HOUSE OUR INFRASTRUCTURE. WE WOULD UPDATE OUR UPS GIVING US A RELIABLE BACK UP SYSTEM SHOULD WE LOSE POWER. WE WILL REPLACE OUR ANTIQUATED PHONE AND NETWORK LINES TO NEW UP TO DATE CAT 5E PHONE AND NETWORK. WE WILL INSTALL FIFTY-ONE NEW WORKSTATIONS. WE WILL INSTALL FOUR UP-TO-DATE FIREWALL'S GIVING EACH NETWORK TWO (2) FIREWALLS. WE WILL UPGRADE OUR INTERNET SERVICE AND FIBER OPTIC OPTION TO ACT AS A REDUNDANT INTERNET SOURCE. WE WILL UPGRADE OUR EXTERIOR LIGHTING MODULE. BY UPGRADING THE NECESSARY INFRASTRUCTURE, IT WILL PROTECT THE CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION OF HUNDREDS OF INDIVIDUALS WE ENCOUNTER DAILY AND STORE THEIR INFORMATION FOR LAW ENFORCEMENT PURPOSES. IT WILL ALSO ALLOW OUR AGENCY TO CONTINUE FUNCTIONING AS THE CHIEF LAW ENFORCEMENT ENTITY IN THE COUNTY AND AID IN REMAINING NBIRS COMPLIANT DAILY. THE TARGET POPULATION WILL BE AFFECTED BY THE PROBLEM BY HAVING THEIR PERSONAL INFORMATION AT RISK FOR EXPOSURE. THE TARGET POPULATION RISKS HAVING PHONE CALLS DROPPED DURING EMERGENCIES, NOT HAVING REPORTS AVAILABLE TO THEM DURING PUBLIC RECORDS REQUESTS, FACE SAFETY RISKS DURING EXCHANGES, FACE DELAYED RESPONSES FROM DEPUTIES DUE TO DELAYED NETWORK RESPONSES AND MOST OF ALL THEY FACE THE LACK OF TRANSPARENCY OUR AGENCY STRIVES TO PROVIDE TO THEM. THE TARGET POPULATION OUR AGENCY PRIMARILY SERVES ARE THE RESIDENTS OF JEFFERSON COUNTY. ACCORDING TO THE UNITED STATES CENSUS BUREAU, JEFFERSON COUNTY HAD APPROXIMATELY 64,789 RESIDENTS IN 2021. JEFFERSON COUNTY IS IN THE FOCUS OF THE CURRENT OIL AND GAS EXPLORATION. THIS IN RETURN BRINGS A LARGE AMOUNT OF TRANSIENT AND MIGRATORY WORKERS TO THE COUNTY. JEFFERSON COUNTY HAS A UNITED STATES ROUTE AND NUMEROUS STATE ROUTES DISSECTING THE COUNTY, SERVING AS A PRIMARY THROUGHWAY FOR TRANSPORTATION BETWEEN COLUMBUS AND PITTSBURGH. PITTSBURGH, A MAJOR CITY, LIES WITHIN 40 MILES OF JEFFERSON COUNTY. JEFFERSON COUNTY ALSO HAS NUMEROUS BUSINESSES IN THE MEDICAL, GROCERY, RETAIL, LAW, CONSTRUCTION, INDUSTRIAL AND OTHER TYPES OF WORK FIELDS THAT CONTRIBUTE TO THE TRANSIENT AND MIGRATORY WORKERS. JEFFERSON COUNTY IS DIVERSIFIED IN ETHNICITY. JEFFERSON COUNTY HAS 91.4% WHITE OR CAUCASIAN POPULATION, 5.5% BLACK OR AFRICAN AMERICAN, 0.2% AMERICAN INDIAN AND 0.5% ASIAN. ACCORDING TO THE OCJS VIOLENT AND PROPERTY CRIME STATISTICS, IN JEFFERSON COUNTY, IN 2017, THERE WAS A VIOLENT CRIME RATE OF 110 TO 100,000 AND A PROPERTY CRIME RATE OF 1,937 TO 100,000. IN JEFFERSON COUNTY, THERE ARE SIX (6) SCHOOL DISTRICTS WITH MULTIPLE SCHOOL BUILDINGS, APPROXIMATELY 4 HOTELS, TWO (2) COLLEGE CAMPUSES, TWO (2) LARGE ENERGY PRODUCTION PLANTS, A LOCK AND DAM FOR FOSSIL FUELS AND GOOD TRANSPORTATION MANAGED BY THE COAST GUARD, THREE (3) LARGE PRODUCTION PLANTS, DISTRIBUTION CENTERS, AN INDUSTRIAL PARK WITH NUMEROUS BUSINESSES, A MALL, AND NUMEROUS OTHER BUSINESSES. THE INFRASTRUCTURE, BUSINESSES, TRANSIENT POPULATION, DIVERSE POPULATION AND SETTLED POPULATION ARE AN EXAMPLE OF THE TARGET POPULATION OUR AGENCY SERVES.

prime_award_awarding_agency_name: Department of Health and Human Services (HHS)
prime_award_funding_agency_name: Department of Health and Human Services (HHS)
prime_awardee_business_types: Nonprofit with 501C3 IRS Status (Other than an Institution of Higher Education)
prime_award_base_transaction_description: Multilevel Interventions to Increase Adherence to Lung Cancer Screening - ABSTRACT Screening for lung cancer has the potential for a profound public health benefit. Lung cancer is the leading cause of US cancer morbidity and mortality for both men and women, responsible for more deaths than breast, cervical, colorectal, and prostate cancers combined. Annual screening with low-dose computed tomography (LDCT) reduced lung cancer mortality by 20%. Successful population-based screening requires continuous monitoring to adherence repeat screening in high risk adults to achieve similar results. Repeat annual screening is necessary for early detection of lung cancer. Baseline or first LDCT scans detect prevalent lung cancer, when subsequent screening detects new nodules. However, adherence to screening is low, ranging at 28-38% from centers nationally. Multilevel interventions, which target patients, clinicians, and healthcare systems, offer a promising framework to address the gaps in lung cancer screening to achieve guideline- recommended lung cancer screening. Our mixed-methods pilot study with KPWA stakeholders two critical components to improve adherence to repeat screening: providing education for patients on lung cancer screening, and offering reminders for on-time return to screening. We developed two novel patient-centered interventions using principles of human-centered design to address these needs: 1) Patient Voices Video that incorporates patient testimonials to acknowledge receipt of screening, a tailored reminder of time due for next scan, and reassurance to reduce fear of screening and role of loved ones to support health choices; and 2) Stepped Reminders, that directly reminds patients when their next scan is due. Both interventions are facilitated by a health system electronic health record (EHR) build to track patients for population health management and a clinically-embedded medical assistant to deliver interventions. The goal of this proposal is to test these two interventions relative to usual care to promote adherence to repeat screening in a pragmatic cluster randomized trial enrolling 1775 adult KPWA members, who complete a screening LDCT in 2022-2025 across 34 KPWA primary care clinics in a 2x2 factorial-designed study. Study arms include: a) Stepped Reminders alone; b) Patient Voices Video alone; c) both interventions; or d) usual care. To address our goals, our specific aims are to: 1) Compare effectiveness of two multilevel interventions relative to usual care in improving (a) rates of adherence to lung cancer screening, (b) patient-centered outcomes; and (c) clinic outcomes; and 2) Determine the patient-, clinician-, and system-level factors that influence changes in adherence to inform lung cancer screening programs. To date, no randomized clinical trial has evaluated strategies to improve adherence to lung cancer screening in US populations with multilevel strategies. We will move the field forward by providing effective, scalable interventions to improve lung cancer screening adherence to achieve the population-based mortality benefits promised by large clinical trials that motivated screening guidelines.

prime_award_base_transaction_description: Using Large-Scale Network Data to Measure Social Returns and Improve Targeting of Crime-Reduction Interventions -Many randomized experiments have tested whether policies surrounding punishment, work, and education can prevent criminal behavior. Evaluations of prevention programs typically assume that one individual?s behavior does not affect anyone else?s. If individuals exposed to crime intervention transmit their improvements in skills, beliefs, or time use to their peers, ignoring these spillovers could understate or alternatively overstate an intervention?s total impact. This project will document how changes in criminal behavior spread through social networks by combining four existing experiments with measures of social networks derived from multiple sources of administrative data. It will quantify the direct and indirect effects of these violence-reduction interventions on participants and their peers. The results will generate a better understanding of the overall effect of each program, as well as the role of peers in shaping criminal decision-making more broadly. The project will provide actionable information on how to effectively target crime prevention programs in the future by describing whom program operators should serve to maximize net crime reduction benefits. The results will also help to establish the US as global leader in crime reducing policies. This project will estimate the effects of social networks on crime intervention programs. Estimating social spillovers faces two key challenges: measuring social networks and causally identifying peer effects. This research addresses the first challenge by combining population-wide administrative police and school records in Chicago to capture different kinds of social connections. The PIs solve the second challenge by combining the network information with exogenous variation in crime and violence generated by four existing RCTs in Chicago, all focusing on low income youth. Using these data, the PIs will construct the social network between individuals at the time each intervention was randomly assigned. The random variation from the RCTs will allow the PIs to test whether and how treatment changes behavior?both via direct participation and via indirect exposure to treated peers?as well as which types of social ties matter. The PIs will test for heterogeneity in peer effects based on demographic, criminal history, and network characteristics of individuals to help understand and model how social interactions generate criminal decisions. Finally, the PIs will us the model to evaluate alternative targeting strategies for future RCTs. The results of this research project will provide important inputs into policies to decrease crime and thus improve public safety in the US. The results will also help to establish the US as global leader in crime reducing policies. This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

THE UNIVERSITY OF CHICAGO WILL MATCH AND PROVIDE THE DATA FOR THIS PROJECT VIA ITS MASTER DATASHARING AGREEMENTS AND PROJECT-SPECIFIC APPROVALS WITH THE CHICAGO POLICE DEPARTMENT AND
CHICAGO PUBLIC SCHOOLS. IT WILL PROVIDE THE SECURE COMPUTING ENVIRONMENT NECESSARY TO COMPLY
WITH THE TERMS OF THE DATA-SHARING AGREEMENTS, AND ENSURE THE ANALYST IS PROPERLY TRAINED IN
CONFIDENTIALITY AND HUMAN SUBJECTS PROTECTIONS.
CO-INVESTIGATOR MONICA BHATT (PHD, UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN, EDUCATION POLICY) WILL WORK WITH
UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN CO-PIS SARA HELLER (PHD, UNIVERSITY OF CHICAGO, PUBLIC POLICY) AND
ASHLEY CRAIG (PHD, HARVARD UNIVERSITY, ECONOMICS). DR. BHATT IS A SENIOR RESEARCH DIRECTOR AT
THE UNIVERSITY OF CHICAGO CRIME LAB AND EDUCATION LAB. SHE WILL SUPERVISE THE PROVISION OF
STUDY DATA, PROVIDE EXPERTISE ON THE USE OF ADMINISTRATIVE CHICAGO PUBLIC SCHOOLS AND CHICAGO
POLICE DEPARTMENT DATA, AND ENSURE ALL PROJECT-SPECIFIC DATA AND HUMAN SUBJECTS PERMISSIONS AT
THE UNIVERSITY OF CHICAGO ARE IN PLACE.
TWO TBN GRADUATE STUDENTS WILL SERVE AS AN ANALYST ON THE PROJECT. UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF THE
PIS, THEY WILL CLEAN AND ANALYZE THE DATA, GENERATE RESULTS TABLES AND FIGURES, AND ASSIST WITH
MANUSCRIPT PREPARATION.

subaward_description:
WORK WILL COMMENCE AT THIS SITE IN THE FIRST YEAR OF THE PROJECT WHERE WE WILL COLLECT A CORPUS OF CLINICAL NOTES GENERATED BY SPEECH RECOGNITION FROM THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO'S NETWORK OF EMERGENCY DEPARTMENTS. IN THE END OF THE FIRST YEAR AND BEGINNING OF THE SECOND YEAR, WE WILL DEVELOP A CLASSIFICATION SCHEMA FOR THESE ERRORS AND CONDUCT ERROR ANALYSIS. THIS WILL BE ASSISTED BY THE USE OF ANNOTATION OF CLINICAL TEXT FROM DISCHARGED SUMMARIES, OUTPATIENT CLINIC NOTES AND EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT (ED) NOTES USING AN ANNOTATOR PROGRAM. WE WILL COMPLETE THE KNOWLEDGE BASE DEVELOPMENT AT THE END OF THE SECOND YEAR AND START DEVELOPMENT OF THE NLP TOOL (REDIT) IN YEAR 3. BOTH MACHINE LEARNING AND KNOWLEDGE-BASED METHODS BE INTEGRATED INTO THE NLP TOOL. CLINICAL TEXT
DOCUMENTS WILL BE OBTAINED FROM BRIGHAM AND WOMEN'S HOSPITAL AND UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO FOR THE SYSTEM TRAINING AND TESTING PURPOSES. DR. GOSS WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR OBTAINING THESE DOCUMENTS FROM THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO AND DR. ZHOU FROM BWH. ALL DOCUMENTS WILL BE DEIDENTIFIED AND SECURILY STORED BEHIND THE HOSPITAL FIREWALL.
IN THE LAST YEAR, WE WILL FORMALLY EVALUATE THE PERFORMANCE OF OUR NLP TOOL FOR IDENTIFYING SR ERRORS. THIS WILL INVOLVE GENERATION OF A TRAINING AND TESTING SET. STATISTICAL ANALYSIS WILL BE CARRIED OUT BY DR. ZHOU AND DR. GOSS. UPON COMPLETION, THE RESULTS WILL BE DISCUSSED AND OUR KNOWLEDGE BASE AND METHODS DISTRIBUTED VIA OPEN SOURCE LICENSE FOR NON-COMMERCIAL USE.

subaward_description:
EACH RBR CONTRIBUTES UNIQUE ASSETS, INNOVATIVE TECHNOLOGICAL CAPABILITIES AND/OR.HIV-RELATED RESEARCH EXPERTISE THAT COMPLEMENT AND ENHANCE ECH OF THE OTHER RBRS, THUS CREATING A NEW AHD NOVEL ACSR ENTERPRISE RESOURCE WITH SUPERIOR ABILITY TO KEEP ABREAST OF THE CHANGING EPIDEMIC AND SUPPORT THE EVOLVING NEEDS OF THE HIV-MALIGNANCY RESEARCHERS.
Ã‚Â·THE OVERALL AIMS OF THE NEW ACSR'S RBRS EMPLOY SHARED AND VALIDATED PROCEDURES THAT EXIST WITHIN THE CURRENT ACSR AND ARE BEING TRANSFERRED TO THE _NEW ACSR. THESE WILL BE ADOPTED BY ALL RBRS AS DETAILED BELOW. EACH RBR ALSO HAS ITS OWN SECTION DETAILING UNIQUE LEADERSHIP, STRUCTURE, TECHNICAL CAPABILITIES, AND SERVICES. THE AIMS OF THE 4 NEW ACSR RBRS ARE CONSISTENT WITH THE AIMS OF THE ACSR ENTERPRISE AND IN GENERAL TERMS ARE:      '
AIM 1: BUILD OR UPDATE RBR INFRASTRUCTURE TO INCLUDE STATE OF THE ART BIOSPECIMEN REPOSITORIES, AND THE CREATION OF A REGIONAL OPERATIONS OFFICE (ROO). THIS INFRASTRUCTURE WILL SUPPORT: A) THE ACQUISITION, CURATION, MAINTENANCE AND DISBURSEMENT OF BIOSPECIMENS BY THE RBR AND; B) THE ADMINISTRATIVE AND DATA MANAGEMENT FUNCTIONS OF THE ROO THAT W111 ENSURE A HIGH FUNCTIONING AND PRODUCTIVE BIOBANKING ENTERPRISE TO PROVIDE A SPECTRUM OF QUALITY ANNOTATED QIOSPECIMENS TO SCIENTIFIC INVESTIGATORS STUDYING HIV RELATED MALIGNANCY.
AIM 2: INSTITUTE AND IMPLEMENT ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES AND PROTOCOLS, MANAGE AND MAINTAIN CLINICAL AND SPECIMEN DATA, AND FACILITATE COMMUNICATIONS WITH THE CODCC UNDER THE DIRECTION OF THE RBR REGIONAL OPERATIONS OFFICE ESTABLISHED UNDER AIM1.
THE CODCC HAS BEEN IN PLACE SINCE 2002 AND HAS FACILITATED THE INTERACTIONS BETWEEN RBRS AND THE ACSR DATABASE GROUP, NOW TERMED CITS. THE PROCEDURES BY WHICH RBR DATABASE MANAGERS, NOW IN THE NEW ACSR ROO, INPUT AND TRACK SPECIMENS AND CLINICAL DATA WILL BE ADOPTED BY ALL 4 SITES. SIMILARLY, THE FUNCTION OF RBRS WILL CONFORM TO TH.!3 OVERALL PRACTICES DEFINED IN THE CURRENT ACSR MANUAL OF OPERATIONS (MOO).

AIM 3: ACQUIRE, PROCESS, CURATE, AND MAINTAIN A DIVERSE COLLECTION OF HIGH QUALITY BIOSPECIMENS TO DISBURSE TO INVESTIGATORS CONDUCTING HIV-RELATED MALIGNANCY RESEARCH.
ALL OF THE RBRS WILL CONFORM WITH THE GENERAL FUNCTIONS DEFINED IN THE MOO AND SOP AS ABOVE AND WILL INTERACT WITH THE COOCC AND THE CITS AS DEFINED IN THE CODCC SECTION OF THIS APPLICATION.

BAYLOR COLLEGE OF MEDICINE HOUSTON. TX REGIONAL BIOSPECIMEN REPOSITORX ( BCM RBRL

PATIENT POPULATION.WITH 4,092,459 RACIALLY AND ETHNICALLY DIVERSE INHABITANTS, HARRIS COUNTY,' WHERE HOUSTON IS LOCATED, IS THE THIRD MOST POPULOUS COUNTY IN THE U.S. AT THE END OF 2010, APPROXIMATELY .19,733 PEOPLE WERE LIVING WITH HIV OR AIDS IN HARRIS COUNTY. THIS NUMBER IS COMPARABLEÃ‚Â·TO THE HIV POSITIVE POPULATION OF SAN FRANCISCO (23,075) AND RANKS HARRIS COUNTY NUMBER EIGHT IN THE COUNTRY IN TERMS OF CITIZENS AFFECTED.

HEALTH CARE FACILITIES AND PROVIDERS. THE THOMAS STREET.HEALTH CENTER (TSHC), THE FIRST FREEÃ‚Â­ STANDING HIV CLINIC IN THE COUNTRY, IS OPERATED BY HARRIS HEALTH (FORMERLY THE HARRIS COUNTY HOSPITAL DISTRICT). THE TSHC IS THE FOCAL POINT OF HARRIS HEALTH'S HIV PROGRAMS AND IS LOCATED APPROXIMATELY 5 MILES FROM THE TEXAS MEDICAL CENTER (TMC) LN DOWNTOWN HOUSTON. OVER 100 STAFF MEMBERA PROVIDE CARE TO APPROXIMATELY 5,549 (28%) OF THE 19,733 PEOPLE LIVING WITH HIV WHO RESIDE IN HOUSTON/HARRIS COUNTY. TSHC CARES PRIMARILY FOR LOW INCOME PATIENTS; 61% OF THE
 

PATIENTS ARE AFRICAN AMERICAN, 21% ARE HISPANIC (MOSTLY WHITE), AND 17% Ã‚Â·-ARE WHITE NON HISPANICS. FORTY-NINE PERCENT OF TSCH PATIENTS WERE INFECTED BY HETEROSEXUAL TRANSMISSION, 29% BY MSM CONTACT, 8% IOU, AND 12% "OTHER". BEN TAUB GENERAL HOSPITAL (BTGH), IN THE TEXAS MEDICAL CENTER, IS WHERE THE  MAJORITY OF THESE PATIENTS RECEIVE INPATIENT CARE WHEN NEEDED. THE TEXAS MEDICAL CENTER HARRIS HEALTH SMITH CLINIC IS THE LOCATION FOR OUTPATIENT ONCOLOGY CARE INCLUDING CHEMOTHERAPY AND RADIATION THERAPY; ANOTHER 850 PEOPLE LIVING WITH HIV ARE CARED FOR AT THE MICHAEL E. DEBAKEY VAMC (MEDVAMC}, ALSO LO'CATED IN THE TMC. THESE CLINICAL SITES ARE OVERSEEN BY THE DAN L DUNCAN CANCER CENTER (DLDCC) AT BCM AND STAFFED BY BCM PHYSICIANS. DR. ELIZABETH CHIAO, WHO IS BOARD CERTIFIED IN INFECTIOUS DISEASE AND MEDICAL ONCOLOGY, PRACTICES AT BQTH TSHC AND THE - BEN TAUB HOSPITAL AND HAS AN NCI FUNDED RESEARCH PROGRAM IN HIV-ASSOCIATED ANAL MALIGNANCIES. DR. CHIAO HAS PUBLISHED IN THE AREA OF AIDS-RELATED MALIGNANCIES AND IS THE BCM PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR FOR THE AIDS MALIGNANCY CONSORTIUM AND THE TEXAS NEUROAIDS RESEARCH CENTER. DR. CHIAO WILL COORDINATE THE BCM RBR EFFORTS THROUGH HARRIS HEALTH FOCUSING ON RECRUITMENT AND PATIENT FOLLOW-UP. DR MARTHA MIMS, CHIEF OF. HEMATOLOGY AND ONCOLOGY AT BCM WILL COORDINATE AND FACILITATE RECRUITMENT AND SAMPLE ACQUISITION AT THE HOSPITAL SITES AND THE TMC HARRIS HEALT!;I SMITH CLINIC.

HIV-RELATED RESEARCH ACTIVITIES AT BCM. THE NIH FUNDED BCM-UT HOUSTON CENTER FOR AIDS RESEARCH (CFAR) IS PART OF A NATIONWIDE NETWORK OF AIDS RESEARCH CENTERS AND IS DESIGNED TO SUPPORT AND FACILITATE MULTIDISCIPLINARY AIDS-RELATED RESEARCH AT BOTH BCM AND THE UT HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER. THE CFAR HAS BEEN LOCATED AT BCM SINCE 1991; THE PARTNERSHIP WITH THE UT AT HOUSTON WAS ESTABLISHED IN 2005. TSHC IS THE CORE OF THE CLINICAL HIV RESEARCH EFFORT AT BCM AND IS THE DESIGNATED AIDS CLINICAL TRIALS GROUP SITE IN HOUSTON, AS WELL AS THE MAIN AIDS MALIGNANCY CONSORTIUM SITE. THE BCM RBR SITE HAS A DATABASE OF 484 INDIVIDUALS WITH HIV WHO HAVE BEEN DIAGNOSED WITH CANCER AND HAVE BEEN EVALUATED OR TREATED IN THE HARRIS HEALTH SYSTEM. SEVERAL TISSUE MICROARRAYS OF AIDS-RELATED MALIGNANCIES HAVE BEEN MADE OR ARE UNDER CONSTRUCTION WITHIN THE DLDCC HUMAN TISSUE ACQUISITION CORE INCLUDING SEVENTEEN ANAL CANCERS, TEN BREAST CANCERS, TEN LUNG, OVER TWENTY CERVICAL CANCERS, EIGHT GASTRIC CANCERS, FIFTEEN HEPATOCELLULAR CARCINOMAS, TWELVE OROPHARYNGEAL CANCERS AND NEARLY THIRTY HODGKIN LYMPHOMAS. CLINICAL DATA HAS BEEN COLLECTED ON ALL SPECIMENS INCLUDED IN THE TMAS. THE BCM LYMPHOMA SPORE HAS ACTIVELY PROMOTED INVESTIGATION INTO HIV INFECTIONASSOCIATED LYMPHOMAS INCLURNNG A RECENT SEQUENCING STUDY COMPARING BURKITT LYMPHOMA IN HIV POSITIVE AND HIV NEGATIVE SUBJECTS WHICH IS NEARING COMPLETION. THIS STUDY INCLUDES SAMPLES OBTAINED FTOM THE ACSR.

TISSUE Ã‚Â·BANKING INFRASTRUCTURE.  THE DAN L. DUNCAN CANCER CENTER IS A NCI-DESIGNATED CANCER CENTER. RESOURCES FROM THE NCI CORE GRANT AND BCM HAVE ENABLED US TO INITIATE BANKING OF FRESH CANCER AND ADJCENT BENIGN TISSUES AT ALL BCM AFFILIATED HOSPITALS, INCLUDING THE BEN TAUB GENERAL HOSPITAL AND THE MICHAEL E. Ã‚Â·DEBAKEY VAMC VIA THE HUMAN TISSUE ACQUISITION AND PATHOLOGY (HTAP} CORE RESOURCE. PERSONNEL ARE DEPLOYED AT BOTH INSTITUTIONS TO CONSENT PATIENTS AND ASSIST WITH FRESH TISSUE QOLLECTION USING AN ESTABLISHED CONSENT PROCESS
 

Ã‚Â·AND PATHOLOGY STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES. DR. MICHAEL LTTMANN IS A BOARD CERTIFIED PATHOLOGIST AND THE DIRECTOR OF THE HTAP CORE. HE HAS MORE THAN TWENTY YEARS' EXPERIENCE IN TISSUE BANKING AND EXTENSIVE EX.PERIENCE WITH HIV RELATED MALIGNANCH S. AS THE RBR DIRECTOR, HE WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR OVERALL DIRECTION OF THIS RBR. THE MEDVAMC HAS ESTABLISHED AN ARCHIVE OF TWENTY YEARS OF PARAFFIN-EMBEDDED TISSUE BLOCKS, WHICH CONTAINS MORE THAN  140,000 INDIVIDUAL  CASES  THAT  CAN BE LINKED TO  CLINICAL FOLLOW-UP  DATA THROUGH  A
COMPREHENSIVE ELECTRONIC MEDICAL RECORD. TEN YEARS OF PARAFFIN BLOCKS ARE ALSO AVAILABLE FROM BTGH. BOTH OF THESE PROGRAMS.HAVE BEEN USED TO BUILD MULTIPLE TISSUE MICROARRAYS WITH LINKED CLINICAL FOLLOWMUP. THE PHY.SICAL TISSUE BANK IS SUPPORTED BY A COMPREHENSIVE INFORMATICS GROUP LED BY DR. LAUREN BECNEL. THE HTAP INFORMATICS INFRASTRUCTURE INCLUDING SOFTWARE AND ASSOCIATED SUPPORT WILL BE ADAPTED TO SUPPORT THE ASCR EFFORT.

SUMMARY OF CLINICAL INFRASTRUCTURE: THE BCM RBR IS ACTIVELY INVOLVED IN THE CARE OF A LARGE, ETHNICALLY DIVERSE HIV POSITIVE PATIENT POPULATION. WE HAVE THE CLINICAL, PATHOLOGICAL AND
INFORMATICS EXPERTISE AND INFRASTRUCTURE TO CONTRIBUTE SUBSTANTIALLY TO THE ACSR EFFORT. OF NOTE, ORS. CHIAO, MIMS, LTTMANN AND BECNEL HAVE WORKED TOGETHER IN VARIOUS COLLABORATIVE EFFORTS,
,FACILITATING THE SMOOTH OPERATIONS OF THIS RBR SITE.

OPERATIONS OF THE BCM RBR. THE INITIAL STEP IN FRESH TISSUE COLLECTION IS IDENTIFICATION OF PATIENTS AT EACH OF OUR CLINICAL SITES WITH DAILY SURGICAL SCHEDULES ARE ALSO EVALUATED FOR POTENTIAL TISSUE DONORS. PATIENTS ARE APPROACHED FOR TISSUE DONATION BY DEDICATED PATIENT TISSUE ADVOCATES USING OUR EXISTING IRB APPROVED CONSENT THAT PERMITS ROUTINE IMMUNOHISTOCHEMISTRY TESTING OF SAMPLES AS WELL AS ADVANCED GENOMIC TESTING AND WHOLE GENOME SEQUENCING. UNDER THE DIRECTION OF SITE PATHOLOGISTS OR PATHOLOGY ASSISTANTS, PATIENT TISSUE ADVOCATES COLLECT FRESH TISSUE, FLUIDS AND/OR BLOOD FROM CONSENTED PATIENTS. TMOR AND NORMAL TISSUES ARE SNAP FROZEN
IN LIQUID NITROGEN. SECTIONS FOR MOLECULAR  ANALYSIS ARE SEPARATED  BY "MIRROR" TISSUE SECTIONS
SUBMITTED FOR FORMALIN FIXATION AND PARAFFIN EMBEDDING FOR IDENTIFICATION OF TISSUE TYPE, PERCENTAGE OF TUMOR/TUMOR NUCLEI AND NECROSIS. A FORMALIN-FIXED PARAFFIN EMBEDDED (FFPE) SAMPLE WITH A MIRROR IMAGE FROZEN TISSUE:IS.PREPARED BY STANDARD TECHNIQUES. THE FFPE SAMPLE IS SENT TO THE RESEARCH HISTOLOGY LABORATORY, WHERE A AN H& E SLIDE IS REVIEWED BY A PATNOLOGLST WHO MAKES A DIAGNOSIS BASED ON ACCEPTED CLINICAL PRACTICE FOR EACH TUMOR TYPE, THE PATHOLOGIST RECORDS THE PERCENT OF TUMOR VERSUS NORMAL NUCLEI AND THE PERCENT NECROSIS PRESENT IN THE SECTION SEMI-QUANTITATIVELY OR BY IMAGE ANALYSIS.

THE BCM RBR UTILIZES A TWODIMENSIONAL BARCODING SYSTEM TO CATALOG ALL TISSUES AND SERA. THE BAR COQE MATERIAL IS CERTIFIED TO WITHSTAND FROZEN  (-BOC) TEMPERATURES  WITHOUT SEPARATING.
INFORMATION CAN BE READ WITHOUT HANDLING THE SPECIMENS WHICH HELPS ENSURE CONTINUOUS RNA QUALITY. ALL FREEZERS T)AVE REDUNDANT, EMERGENCY POWER IN THE EVENT OF A PRIMAR}T POWER FAILURE. FREEZERS HAVE A MONITORED ALARM SYSTEM WHICH SOUNDS AND AUTOMATICALLY TELEPHONES 3 PREÃ‚Â­ DEFINED PERSONNEL IF THE TEMPERATURE RISES ABOVE -65C, OR DROPS BELOW -90C. AS ADDITIONAL BACKMUP, THERE IS AN EMERGENCY SYSTEM OF C02 TANKS THAT DISPERSE C02 INTO THE TRE:EZER IF THE
 

REGIONAL BIOSPECIMEN REPOSITORIES (RBRS)

TEMPERATURE RISES ABOVE A SET POINT. IF THE FREEZER TEMPERATURE CONTINUES TO RISE, ACTION IS TAKEN TO PRESERVE THE TISSUES - A SPARE EMPTY, COLD 'FREEZER IS KEPT IN RESERVE AT ALL TIMES- OUR PROCEDURES YIELD HIGH QUALITY TISSUE SUITABLE FOR RNA ANALYSIS AND WE HAVE SUCCESSFULLY SUBMITTED MULTIPLE QUALIFIED TISSUE SAMPLES TO THE CANCER GENOME ATLAS PROJECT, WHICH HAS HIGHLY STRINGENT STANDARDS FOR TISSUE INTEGRITY, SIZE AND PERCENT VIABLEÃ‚Â·TUMOR. ALL SOP FOR HIV TISSUES WILL BE HARMONIZED Ã‚Â·WITH ACSR SOP AND THE MOO. FOLLOWING CONSENT AND TISSUE COLLECTION, PATIENT TISSUE ADVOCATES RECORD ALL CLINICAL, DEMOGRAPHIC AND PATHOLOGICAL INFORMATION REAL TIME INTO THE.INFORMATICS DATABASE.

A SECOND MAJOR EFFORT OF THE BCM RBR WILL BE TO CONSTRUCT TISSUE MICROARRAYS (TMAS) USING FFPE TISSUES FROM HIV + PATIENTS TREATED AT DLDCC SITES UNDER EXISTING !RB-APPROVED PROTOCOLS. PATIENTS ARE IDENTIFIED BY SYSTEMATIC EXAMINATION OF MEDICAL RECORDS AND TUMOR REGISTRIES, AND BLOCKS ARE COLLECTED Ã‚Â·BY PATIENT TISSUE ADVOCATES. TMAS ARE CONSTRUCTED BY EXPERIENCED DLDCC PATHOLOGY CORE PERSONNEL UNDER THE GUIDANCE OF DR. TTTMANN, WHO REVIEWS
AND MARKS TUMOR AND NORMAL REGIONS ON SLIDES FROM EACH BLOCK FOR INCLUSION ON THE TMA.
LINKED CLINICAL,DEMOGRAPHIC, PATHOLOGICAL AND OUTCOME DATA WILL BE GATHERED AND LINKED IN A DEÃ‚Â­ IDENTIFIED MANNER TO EACH CASE ON THE ARRAY. PATIENT TISSUE ADVOCATES  AND THE SITE PROJECT
I
COORDINATOR WILL DEVOTE CONSIDERABLE EFFORT TO OBTAINING CLINICAL FOLLOW-UP ON PATIENTS DONATING
FRESH FROZEN TISSUE, OR WHO HAVE BEEN INCLUDED IN TMAS AND THIS INFORMATIQN WILL BE ENTERED INTO THE DATABASE ON A CONTINUOUS BASIS.

DATA WILL BE ENTERED  INTO THE ACSR DATABASE, ACQUIRE (HTTPS:L/ACQUIRE.RESEARCH.BCM.EDU), A MODULAR SYSTEM THAT SECURELY COMMUNICATES WITH OTHE'R SYSTEMS, UTILIZES COMMON DATA ELEMENTS (CDES) TO ENSURE MEANINGFUL DATA EXCHANGE, RESTRICT DATA ACCESS TO APPROPRIATE PERSONNEL AND SUPPORT A VARIETY OF FEATURES INCLUDING SPECIMEN ACQUISITION, CLINICAL AND PATHOLOGICAL ANNOTATION, GENERATION OF REPORTS AND SHIPPING DOCUMENTS, SPECIMEN DATA DISTRIBUTION OVERSIGHT MANAGEMENT, AND MAINTENANCE OF HIGH DATA QUALIFY BY ALERTING BIOBANK
STAFF OF OUTSTANDING TASKS FOR SPECIMENS. THE BCM INFORMATICS GROUP  WILL DETERMINE WHAT CUSTOMIZATIONS TO OUR DATABASE TO SUPPORT ACSR BIOBANKING, DATA EXTRACTION AND MANAGEMENT, OVERSIGHT AND REPORTING ACTIVITIES OUTLINED IN ACSR SOP/MOO. THESE NEEDS WILL BE PRIORITIZED AND ASSIGNED TO SOFTWARE "BUILDS," THAT ARE RELEASED EVERY 8-12 WEEKS OVER THE ENTIRE FUNDING
PERIOD. ALL BCM SYSTEMS UTILIZE ENCRYPTED PASSWORDS WITH VIRTUAL ACCESS LIMITED BY THE BCM FIREWALL. SERVERS  ARE HOUSED IN A HIPAA-COMPLIANT TIER ILL DATA CENTER WITH 24-HOUR ON-SITE SECURITY; ACCESS IS LIMITED TO AUTHORIZED PERSONNEL WITH CARD-BASED ENTRY TO THE ENCLOSED AREA. DATA ARE BACKED UP NIGHTLY TO  OFFSITE NETAPP APPLIANCES WITH LONG-TERM  STORAGE ON TAPE; SOFTWARE IS VERSIONED WITHIN A SUBVERSION REPOSITORY AND BACKED UP BIWEEKLY.

prime_award_awarding_agency_name: Department of Health and Human Services (HHS)
prime_award_funding_agency_name: Department of Health and Human Services (HHS)
prime_award_cfda_numbers_and_titles: 93.393: CANCER CAUSE AND PREVENTION RESEARCH; 93.395: CANCER TREATMENT RESEARCH
subawardee_business_types: PRIVATE UNIVERSITY OR COLLEGE,NONPROFIT ORGANIZATION,EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION
subaward_description:
EACH RBR CONTRIBUTES UNIQUE ASSETS, INNOVATIVE TECHNOLOGICAL CAPABILITIES AND/OR.HIV-RELATED RESEARCH EXPERTISE THAT COMPLEMENT AND ENHANCE ECH OF THE OTHER RBRS, THUS CREATING A NEW AHD NOVEL ACSR ENTERPRISE RESOURCE WITH SUPERIOR ABILITY TO KEEP ABREAST OF THE CHANGING EPIDEMIC AND SUPPORT THE EVOLVING NEEDS OF THE HIV-MALIGNANCY RESEARCHERS.
Ã‚Â·THE OVERALL AIMS OF THE NEW ACSR'S RBRS EMPLOY SHARED AND VALIDATED PROCEDURES THAT EXIST WITHIN THE CURRENT ACSR AND ARE BEING TRANSFERRED TO THE _NEW ACSR. THESE WILL BE ADOPTED BY ALL RBRS AS DETAILED BELOW. EACH RBR ALSO HAS ITS OWN SECTION DETAILING UNIQUE LEADERSHIP, STRUCTURE, TECHNICAL CAPABILITIES, AND SERVICES. THE AIMS OF THE 4 NEW ACSR RBRS ARE CONSISTENT WITH THE AIMS OF THE ACSR ENTERPRISE AND IN GENERAL TERMS ARE:      '
AIM 1: BUILD OR UPDATE RBR INFRASTRUCTURE TO INCLUDE STATE OF THE ART BIOSPECIMEN REPOSITORIES, AND THE CREATION OF A REGIONAL OPERATIONS OFFICE (ROO). THIS INFRASTRUCTURE WILL SUPPORT: A) THE ACQUISITION, CURATION, MAINTENANCE AND DISBURSEMENT OF BIOSPECIMENS BY THE RBR AND; B) THE ADMINISTRATIVE AND DATA MANAGEMENT FUNCTIONS OF THE ROO THAT W111 ENSURE A HIGH FUNCTIONING AND PRODUCTIVE BIOBANKING ENTERPRISE TO PROVIDE A SPECTRUM OF QUALITY ANNOTATED QIOSPECIMENS TO SCIENTIFIC INVESTIGATORS STUDYING HIV RELATED MALIGNANCY.
AIM 2: INSTITUTE AND IMPLEMENT ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES AND PROTOCOLS, MANAGE AND MAINTAIN CLINICAL AND SPECIMEN DATA, AND FACILITATE COMMUNICATIONS WITH THE CODCC UNDER THE DIRECTION OF THE RBR REGIONAL OPERATIONS OFFICE ESTABLISHED UNDER AIM1.
THE CODCC HAS BEEN IN PLACE SINCE 2002 AND HAS FACILITATED THE INTERACTIONS BETWEEN RBRS AND THE ACSR DATABASE GROUP, NOW TERMED CITS. THE PROCEDURES BY WHICH RBR DATABASE MANAGERS, NOW IN THE NEW ACSR ROO, INPUT AND TRACK SPECIMENS AND CLINICAL DATA WILL BE ADOPTED BY ALL 4 SITES. SIMILARLY, THE FUNCTION OF RBRS WILL CONFORM TO TH.!3 OVERALL PRACTICES DEFINED IN THE CURRENT ACSR MANUAL OF OPERATIONS (MOO).

AIM 3: ACQUIRE, PROCESS, CURATE, AND MAINTAIN A DIVERSE COLLECTION OF HIGH QUALITY BIOSPECIMENS TO DISBURSE TO INVESTIGATORS CONDUCTING HIV-RELATED MALIGNANCY RESEARCH.
ALL OF THE RBRS WILL CONFORM WITH THE GENERAL FUNCTIONS DEFINED IN THE MOO AND SOP AS ABOVE AND WILL INTERACT WITH THE COOCC AND THE CITS AS DEFINED IN THE CODCC SECTION OF THIS APPLICATION.

BAYLOR COLLEGE OF MEDICINE HOUSTON. TX REGIONAL BIOSPECIMEN REPOSITORX ( BCM RBRL

PATIENT POPULATION.WITH 4,092,459 RACIALLY AND ETHNICALLY DIVERSE INHABITANTS, HARRIS COUNTY,' WHERE HOUSTON IS LOCATED, IS THE THIRD MOST POPULOUS COUNTY IN THE U.S. AT THE END OF 2010, APPROXIMATELY .19,733 PEOPLE WERE LIVING WITH HIV OR AIDS IN HARRIS COUNTY. THIS NUMBER IS COMPARABLEÃ‚Â·TO THE HIV POSITIVE POPULATION OF SAN FRANCISCO (23,075) AND RANKS HARRIS COUNTY NUMBER EIGHT IN THE COUNTRY IN TERMS OF CITIZENS AFFECTED.

HEALTH CARE FACILITIES AND PROVIDERS. THE THOMAS STREET.HEALTH CENTER (TSHC), THE FIRST FREEÃ‚Â­ STANDING HIV CLINIC IN THE COUNTRY, IS OPERATED BY HARRIS HEALTH (FORMERLY THE HARRIS COUNTY HOSPITAL DISTRICT). THE TSHC IS THE FOCAL POINT OF HARRIS HEALTH'S HIV PROGRAMS AND IS LOCATED APPROXIMATELY 5 MILES FROM THE TEXAS MEDICAL CENTER (TMC) LN DOWNTOWN HOUSTON. OVER 100 STAFF MEMBERA PROVIDE CARE TO APPROXIMATELY 5,549 (28%) OF THE 19,733 PEOPLE LIVING WITH HIV WHO RESIDE IN HOUSTON/HARRIS COUNTY. TSHC CARES PRIMARILY FOR LOW INCOME PATIENTS; 61% OF THE
 

PATIENTS ARE AFRICAN AMERICAN, 21% ARE HISPANIC (MOSTLY WHITE), AND 17% Ã‚Â·-ARE WHITE NON HISPANICS. FORTY-NINE PERCENT OF TSCH PATIENTS WERE INFECTED BY HETEROSEXUAL TRANSMISSION, 29% BY MSM CONTACT, 8% IOU, AND 12% "OTHER". BEN TAUB GENERAL HOSPITAL (BTGH), IN THE TEXAS MEDICAL CENTER, IS WHERE THE  MAJORITY OF THESE PATIENTS RECEIVE INPATIENT CARE WHEN NEEDED. THE TEXAS MEDICAL CENTER HARRIS HEALTH SMITH CLINIC IS THE LOCATION FOR OUTPATIENT ONCOLOGY CARE INCLUDING CHEMOTHERAPY AND RADIATION THERAPY; ANOTHER 850 PEOPLE LIVING WITH HIV ARE CARED FOR AT THE MICHAEL E. DEBAKEY VAMC (MEDVAMC}, ALSO LO'CATED IN THE TMC. THESE CLINICAL SITES ARE OVERSEEN BY THE DAN L DUNCAN CANCER CENTER (DLDCC) AT BCM AND STAFFED BY BCM PHYSICIANS. DR. ELIZABETH CHIAO, WHO IS BOARD CERTIFIED IN INFECTIOUS DISEASE AND MEDICAL ONCOLOGY, PRACTICES AT BQTH TSHC AND THE - BEN TAUB HOSPITAL AND HAS AN NCI FUNDED RESEARCH PROGRAM IN HIV-ASSOCIATED ANAL MALIGNANCIES. DR. CHIAO HAS PUBLISHED IN THE AREA OF AIDS-RELATED MALIGNANCIES AND IS THE BCM PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR FOR THE AIDS MALIGNANCY CONSORTIUM AND THE TEXAS NEUROAIDS RESEARCH CENTER. DR. CHIAO WILL COORDINATE THE BCM RBR EFFORTS THROUGH HARRIS HEALTH FOCUSING ON RECRUITMENT AND PATIENT FOLLOW-UP. DR MARTHA MIMS, CHIEF OF. HEMATOLOGY AND ONCOLOGY AT BCM WILL COORDINATE AND FACILITATE RECRUITMENT AND SAMPLE ACQUISITION AT THE HOSPITAL SITES AND THE TMC HARRIS HEALT!;I SMITH CLINIC.

HIV-RELATED RESEARCH ACTIVITIES AT BCM. THE NIH FUNDED BCM-UT HOUSTON CENTER FOR AIDS RESEARCH (CFAR) IS PART OF A NATIONWIDE NETWORK OF AIDS RESEARCH CENTERS AND IS DESIGNED TO SUPPORT AND FACILITATE MULTIDISCIPLINARY AIDS-RELATED RESEARCH AT BOTH BCM AND THE UT HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER. THE CFAR HAS BEEN LOCATED AT BCM SINCE 1991; THE PARTNERSHIP WITH THE UT AT HOUSTON WAS ESTABLISHED IN 2005. TSHC IS THE CORE OF THE CLINICAL HIV RESEARCH EFFORT AT BCM AND IS THE DESIGNATED AIDS CLINICAL TRIALS GROUP SITE IN HOUSTON, AS WELL AS THE MAIN AIDS MALIGNANCY CONSORTIUM SITE. THE BCM RBR SITE HAS A DATABASE OF 484 INDIVIDUALS WITH HIV WHO HAVE BEEN DIAGNOSED WITH CANCER AND HAVE BEEN EVALUATED OR TREATED IN THE HARRIS HEALTH SYSTEM. SEVERAL TISSUE MICROARRAYS OF AIDS-RELATED MALIGNANCIES HAVE BEEN MADE OR ARE UNDER CONSTRUCTION WITHIN THE DLDCC HUMAN TISSUE ACQUISITION CORE INCLUDING SEVENTEEN ANAL CANCERS, TEN BREAST CANCERS, TEN LUNG, OVER TWENTY CERVICAL CANCERS, EIGHT GASTRIC CANCERS, FIFTEEN HEPATOCELLULAR CARCINOMAS, TWELVE OROPHARYNGEAL CANCERS AND NEARLY THIRTY HODGKIN LYMPHOMAS. CLINICAL DATA HAS BEEN COLLECTED ON ALL SPECIMENS INCLUDED IN THE TMAS. THE BCM LYMPHOMA SPORE HAS ACTIVELY PROMOTED INVESTIGATION INTO HIV INFECTIONASSOCIATED LYMPHOMAS INCLURNNG A RECENT SEQUENCING STUDY COMPARING BURKITT LYMPHOMA IN HIV POSITIVE AND HIV NEGATIVE SUBJECTS WHICH IS NEARING COMPLETION. THIS STUDY INCLUDES SAMPLES OBTAINED FTOM THE ACSR.

TISSUE Ã‚Â·BANKING INFRASTRUCTURE.  THE DAN L. DUNCAN CANCER CENTER IS A NCI-DESIGNATED CANCER CENTER. RESOURCES FROM THE NCI CORE GRANT AND BCM HAVE ENABLED US TO INITIATE BANKING OF FRESH CANCER AND ADJCENT BENIGN TISSUES AT ALL BCM AFFILIATED HOSPITALS, INCLUDING THE BEN TAUB GENERAL HOSPITAL AND THE MICHAEL E. Ã‚Â·DEBAKEY VAMC VIA THE HUMAN TISSUE ACQUISITION AND PATHOLOGY (HTAP} CORE RESOURCE. PERSONNEL ARE DEPLOYED AT BOTH INSTITUTIONS TO CONSENT PATIENTS AND ASSIST WITH FRESH TISSUE QOLLECTION USING AN ESTABLISHED CONSENT PROCESS
 

Ã‚Â·AND PATHOLOGY STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES. DR. MICHAEL LTTMANN IS A BOARD CERTIFIED PATHOLOGIST AND THE DIRECTOR OF THE HTAP CORE. HE HAS MORE THAN TWENTY YEARS' EXPERIENCE IN TISSUE BANKING AND EXTENSIVE EX.PERIENCE WITH HIV RELATED MALIGNANCH S. AS THE RBR DIRECTOR, HE WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR OVERALL DIRECTION OF THIS RBR. THE MEDVAMC HAS ESTABLISHED AN ARCHIVE OF TWENTY YEARS OF PARAFFIN-EMBEDDED TISSUE BLOCKS, WHICH CONTAINS MORE THAN  140,000 INDIVIDUAL  CASES  THAT  CAN BE LINKED TO  CLINICAL FOLLOW-UP  DATA THROUGH  A
COMPREHENSIVE ELECTRONIC MEDICAL RECORD. TEN YEARS OF PARAFFIN BLOCKS ARE ALSO AVAILABLE FROM BTGH. BOTH OF THESE PROGRAMS.HAVE BEEN USED TO BUILD MULTIPLE TISSUE MICROARRAYS WITH LINKED CLINICAL FOLLOWMUP. THE PHY.SICAL TISSUE BANK IS SUPPORTED BY A COMPREHENSIVE INFORMATICS GROUP LED BY DR. LAUREN BECNEL. THE HTAP INFORMATICS INFRASTRUCTURE INCLUDING SOFTWARE AND ASSOCIATED SUPPORT WILL BE ADAPTED TO SUPPORT THE ASCR EFFORT.

SUMMARY OF CLINICAL INFRASTRUCTURE: THE BCM RBR IS ACTIVELY INVOLVED IN THE CARE OF A LARGE, ETHNICALLY DIVERSE HIV POSITIVE PATIENT POPULATION. WE HAVE THE CLINICAL, PATHOLOGICAL AND
INFORMATICS EXPERTISE AND INFRASTRUCTURE TO CONTRIBUTE SUBSTANTIALLY TO THE ACSR EFFORT. OF NOTE, ORS. CHIAO, MIMS, LTTMANN AND BECNEL HAVE WORKED TOGETHER IN VARIOUS COLLABORATIVE EFFORTS,
,FACILITATING THE SMOOTH OPERATIONS OF THIS RBR SITE.

OPERATIONS OF THE BCM RBR. THE INITIAL STEP IN FRESH TISSUE COLLECTION IS IDENTIFICATION OF PATIENTS AT EACH OF OUR CLINICAL SITES WITH DAILY SURGICAL SCHEDULES ARE ALSO EVALUATED FOR POTENTIAL TISSUE DONORS. PATIENTS ARE APPROACHED FOR TISSUE DONATION BY DEDICATED PATIENT TISSUE ADVOCATES USING OUR EXISTING IRB APPROVED CONSENT THAT PERMITS ROUTINE IMMUNOHISTOCHEMISTRY TESTING OF SAMPLES AS WELL AS ADVANCED GENOMIC TESTING AND WHOLE GENOME SEQUENCING. UNDER THE DIRECTION OF SITE PATHOLOGISTS OR PATHOLOGY ASSISTANTS, PATIENT TISSUE ADVOCATES COLLECT FRESH TISSUE, FLUIDS AND/OR BLOOD FROM CONSENTED PATIENTS. TMOR AND NORMAL TISSUES ARE SNAP FROZEN
IN LIQUID NITROGEN. SECTIONS FOR MOLECULAR  ANALYSIS ARE SEPARATED  BY "MIRROR" TISSUE SECTIONS
SUBMITTED FOR FORMALIN FIXATION AND PARAFFIN EMBEDDING FOR IDENTIFICATION OF TISSUE TYPE, PERCENTAGE OF TUMOR/TUMOR NUCLEI AND NECROSIS. A FORMALIN-FIXED PARAFFIN EMBEDDED (FFPE) SAMPLE WITH A MIRROR IMAGE FROZEN TISSUE:IS.PREPARED BY STANDARD TECHNIQUES. THE FFPE SAMPLE IS SENT TO THE RESEARCH HISTOLOGY LABORATORY, WHERE A AN H& E SLIDE IS REVIEWED BY A PATNOLOGLST WHO MAKES A DIAGNOSIS BASED ON ACCEPTED CLINICAL PRACTICE FOR EACH TUMOR TYPE, THE PATHOLOGIST RECORDS THE PERCENT OF TUMOR VERSUS NORMAL NUCLEI AND THE PERCENT NECROSIS PRESENT IN THE SECTION SEMI-QUANTITATIVELY OR BY IMAGE ANALYSIS.

THE BCM RBR UTILIZES A TWODIMENSIONAL BARCODING SYSTEM TO CATALOG ALL TISSUES AND SERA. THE BAR COQE MATERIAL IS CERTIFIED TO WITHSTAND FROZEN  (-BOC) TEMPERATURES  WITHOUT SEPARATING.
INFORMATION CAN BE READ WITHOUT HANDLING THE SPECIMENS WHICH HELPS ENSURE CONTINUOUS RNA QUALITY. ALL FREEZERS T)AVE REDUNDANT, EMERGENCY POWER IN THE EVENT OF A PRIMAR}T POWER FAILURE. subaward_description:
THE OVERARCHING FUNCTION OF A DCC IS TO PROVIDE THE LEADERSHIP TO ENSURE OPTIMAL
COLLABORATION AMONG THE TRIAL ELEMENTS SO THAT THE SCIENTIFIC OBJECTIVES OF THE STUDY CAN
BE ATTAINED IN A TIMELY AND ETHICAL MANNER AND THAT THE SAFETY OF HUMAN SUBJECTS IS
ASSURED. THIS IS ACCOMPLISHED BY MEANS OF OPEN AND CONSISTENT COMMUNICATION
CONCERNING PROGRESS, AS WELL AS PROBLEMS AS THEY MAY ARISE IN ANY MULTISITE TRIAL.
VEHICLES FOR COMMUNICATION INCLUDE: PI MEETINGS, TRAINING MEETINGS, CONFERENCE CALLS
AND E-MAIL WITH STUDY PERSONNEL, COMMUNICATION BETWEEN THE DCC AND SITE RAÃ¢Â‚¬Â„¢S, AND
MONTHLY FEEDBACK CONCERNING TRIAL PROGRESS.
DR AGRAS WILL DIRECT THE OVERALL ACTIVITIES OF THE DCC. HOWEVER, IT IS IMPORTANT TO
BUILD A FIREWALL BETWEEN DR AGRAS, WHO WILL INTERACT WITH CLINICAL SITE PIÃ¢Â‚¬Â„¢S AND STAFF, AND
THE BLINDED STUDY DATA. HENCE, MS BRYSON (DATA MANAGER) WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR THE
BLINDED DATA SET WORKING WITH DR KRAEMER WHO WILL SUPERVISE THE OVERALL FUNCTIONING OF
THE DATABASE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM AND WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR CONSULTATION REGARDING THE
DESIGN OF THE TRIAL AND ANALYSIS OF THE DATA. THIS SYSTEM HAS WORKED WELL PREVIOUSLY WITH
DR AGRAS BEING BLIND TO THE RESULTS OF THE TRIAL UNTIL ALL THE PIÃ¢Â‚¬Â„¢S OF THE PARTICULAR TRIAL WERE
UNBLINDED, YET LEAVING HIM ABLE TO FUNCTION AS OVERALL PI FOR THE DCC. DCC PERSONNEL WILL
WORK WITH THE CLINICAL SITES PROVIDING UNBLINDED DATA FOR STUDY MANAGEMENT PURPOSES AND
WILL ALSO PROVIDE REGULAR REPORTS AS REQUESTED (INCLUDING BLINDED DATA) TO THE STUDY
DSMB.
DRS AGRAS WILL ATTEND ALL PI MEETINGS, AND MS BRYSON AND DR JO WILL ATTEND WHEN
THEIR SPECIFIC EXPERTISE IS REQUIRED. MORE DETAILED TRIAL MANAGEMENT AND DECISION-MAKING
WILL BE MADE VIA E-MAIL AND IN REGULARLY SCHEDULED TELEPHONE CONFERENCE CALLS. THIS IS A
COST-EFFECTIVE METHOD OF COMMUNICATION, REVIEWING PROGRESS IN SPECIFIC AREAS, AND
PROBLEM-SOLVING. THESE CALLS WILL BE HELD AT WEEKLY INTERVALS DURING THE PLANNING AND
EARLY TREATMENT PHASES OF THE TRIAL, AND THEN AT MONTHLY INTERVALS WHEN THE STUDY IS
PROGRESSING SATISFACTORILY.
DEVELOPMENT OF THE STUDY OPERATING PROTOCOL. THIS INVOLVES WORKING WITH THE PIÃ¢Â‚¬Â„¢S,
AND ALL STAFF MEMBERS AT THE CLINICAL SITES. THE PROTOCOL IS BASED ON THE FINAL APPROVED
DESIGN OF THE STUDY, AND PROVIDES DETAILED DIRECTION TO THE CLINICAL CENTERS REGARDING
RECRUITMENT OF PARTICIPANTS, SCREENING PARTICIPANTS, RULES FOR ENTRY, EXCLUSION, AND
WITHDRAWAL OF PARTICIPANTS, ASSESSMENT OF PARTICIPANTS (AT EACH OF THE DIFFERENT
ASSESSMENT POINTS), AND DATA COLLECTION. IN ADDITION, PROCEDURES FOR DEALING WITH
QUESTIONS REGARDING TRIAL MANAGEMENT ARE OUTLINED, AS WELL AS HUMAN SUBJECTS ISSUES,
SAFETY PRECAUTIONS, AND THE MANAGEMENT OF EMERGENT CLINICAL SITUATIONS. PROTOCOL DRAFTS
WILL BE CIRCULATED TO EACH OF THE CLINICS FOR REVIEW BY THE PI'S, ASSESSORS, AND RA'S.
FEEDBACK FROM THE SITES WILL BE DISCUSSED IN TELEPHONE CONFERENCE CALLS, WHICH SHOULD
INCLUDE RA'S FROM EACH OF THE CENTERS. THE PROTOCOL MUST BE COMPLETED AND APPROVED
BEFORE PARTICIPANTS ARE ENTERED TO THE STUDY. PROTOCOL AMENDMENTS FOLLOWING COMPLETION
OF THE FINAL STUDY PROTOCOL MUST BE APPROVED BY THE DCC AND PIÃ¢Â‚¬Â„¢S.
DEVELOPMENT OF THE CENTRAL DATABASE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM.
DEVELOPMENT OF THE DATABASE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM WILL OCCUR CONTEMPORANEOUSLY WITH
THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE STUDY PROTOCOL AND OPERATIONS MANUAL, ALTHOUGH FINALIZATION OF
THE DATABASE MUST AWAIT COMPLETION OF THE STUDY PROTOCOL. WHEN THE DATABASE HAS BEEN
DEVELOPED IT WILL BE TESTED BY COLLECTING DATA FROM THE PRACTICE PARTICIPANTS AT EACH OF THE
CLINICAL SITES. WE WOULD ANTICIPATE HAVING THE DATABASE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM READY FOR
TESTING 3-MONTHS AFTER THE BEGINNING OF FUNDING.

THE CITY OF ORANGE'S CYBERSECURITY PROJECT WILL PURCHASE MANAGED NETWORK FIREWALL SERVICES AND DATA BACK-UP SERVICES.  THIS FUNDING WILL ENABLE THE CITIES OF ORANGE, WEST ORANGE, PINEHURST, BRIDGE CITY, AND VIDOR TO HAVE THEIR INTERNET ENTRY POINTS MONITO

prime_award_program_activities_funding_t: 0022: NATIONAL CRIMINAL RECORDS HISTORY IMPROVEMENT PROGRAM (NCHIP)
prime_award_base_transaction_description: FY 2016 Guam Criminal History Improvement Project
subawardee_name: OFFICE OF THE ATTORNEY GENERAL GUAM
subaward_description: THE PURPOSE OF THIS SUBAWARD IS TO ENSURE THAT CRIMINAL HISTORY DATA SHARING IS FACILITATED AMONG LOCAL LAW ENFORCEMENT ENTITIES. THE JUDICIARY OF GUAM (JOG), THE OFFICE OF THE ATTORNEY GENERAL (OAG) AND OTHER LOCAL CRIMINAL JUSTICE PARTNERS ARE WORKING TO DIGITIZE AND INTEGRATE RECORDS WITHIN OUR RESPECTIVE DATABASES FOR SHARED ACCESS VIA GUAM'S VIRTUAL COMPUTERIZED CRIMINAL HISTORY SYSTEM. TO SUPPORT THIS EFFORT, JOG IS ADMINISTERING THIS SUBAWARD TO OAG TO PROCURE 15 COMPUTER WORKSTATIONS IN ORDER FOR ITS PROSECUTION SECTION TO DIGITIZE CASE DOCUMENTS INTO ITS PROSECUTION CASE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM. OAG WILL ALSO PROCURE A FIREWALL DEVICE TO PREVENT INTRUSION AND DISRUPTION OF ITS WIDE AREA NETWORK RESOURCES.

THE CITY OF SAN ANGELO'S CYBER SECURITY PROJECT WILL FUND NETWORKS COMPUTER NETWORK FIREWALLS FOR CITY OF SAN ANGELO, FIRE AND POLICE DEPARTMENTS. THIS REPLACEMENT EQUIPMENT WILL HELP SECURE THE NETWORK DATA AND ENHANCE THE CITY'S ABILITY TO PROTECT THE CITY FROM CYBERATTACKS.

THE CITY OF WESLACO'S FIREWALL PROJECT WILL PROVIDE A FIREWALL AND NETWORK CYBERSECURITY PROTECTIONS FOR THE CITYÃƑÂ¯Ã‚Â¿Ã‚Â½S NETWORK. THE FIREWALL AND CYBERSECURITY PROTECTIONS WILL HELP PREVENT THE DENIAL OR DISRUPTION OF ESSENTIAL SERVICES, INCLUDING UTILITIES, PUBLIC HEALTH, FINANCE, OR LAW ENFORCEMENT NETWORKS.

prime_award_awarding_agency_name: Institute of Museum and Library Services (IMLS)
prime_award_awarding_sub_agency_name: The Institute of Museum and Library Services
subaward_description: TO UPDATE OUR OUTDATED INFRASTRUCTURE, TO FULLY UTILIZE OUR CURRENT BROADBAND AND REPLACE OR UPDATE WINDOWS XP MACHINES. ADD OR UPDATE THE WIRELESS LAN CONTROLLER,RECEIPT PRINTER, ETHERNET SMART SWITCH, TRIPP LITE WALLMOUNT RACK,COOLING FAN, SURGE PROTECTOR, ROUTER/FIREWALL.

prime_award_disaster_emergency_fund_code: AAJ: Emergency P.L. 118-50;Q: Not Designated Nonemergency/Emergency/Disaster/Wildfire Suppression
subaward_description:
BASED ON A CYBERSECURITY RISK ASSESSMENT AND A CISA VULNERABILITY ASSESSMENT, RIVER CITY CHURCH WILL CONDUCT A SECURITY UPGRADE PROJECT TO MITIGATE VULNERABILITIES THAT LEAVE IT SUSCEPTIBLE TO DESTRUCTION, INCAPACITATION, OR EXPLOITATION BY A TERRORIST OR OTHER EXTREMIST ATTACK.  RIVER CITY CHURCH WILL COMPLETE PROJECTS TO UPGRADE NETWORK/INFRASTRUCTURE TO ENHANCE CYBERSECURITY, TO REPLACE METAL-FRAMED GLASS DOORS WITH KEY CYLINDER LOCKS, AND TO INSTALL A CARD-READER ACCESS CONTROL SYSTEM. 
RIVER CITY CHURCH IS PROMINENTLY LOCATED AT THE CORNER OF BECK LANE AND US 231, NEAR THE MAJOR INTERSECTION OF IN-25 AND US 231.  THE LARGE CAMPUS INCLUDES A BUILDING WITH A HIGH-PROFILE CROSS ON TOP THAT CAN BE SEEN FROM A DISTANCE AND SEVERAL SMALLER CROSSES ON THE OUTSIDE WALLS,  CLEARLY IDENTIFYING THE BUILDING AS A CHRISTIAN HOUSE OF WORSHIP.  JUST A FEW MINUTES FROM PURDUE UNIVERSITY AIRPORT AND PURDUE UNIVERSITY, THE CHURCH'S PROXIMITY AND VISIBILITY COULD MAKE IT A POTENTIAL TARGET. 
IN 2023, RIVER CITY CHURCH RECEIVED A PHONE CALL THREATENING TO KILL TWO CHURCH STAFF MEMBERS AT THE LAFAYETTE CAMPUS (THE LAFAYETTE CAMPUS IS THE SUBJECT OF THIS GRANT PROPOSAL).  ANOTHER NEARBY RIVER CITY CHURCH CAMPUS SUFFERED A BREAK-IN ATTEMPT RESULTING IN BROKEN WINDOWS ON THE PARSONAGE. THESE ATTACKS AGAINST RIVER CITY CHURCH CAMPUSES ARE JUST TWO EXAMPLES OF THE RISING NUMBER OF WIDESPREAD ACTS OF VIOLENCE AGAINST CHURCHES. 
VULNERABILITIES REVEALED BY RISK ASSESSMENT INCLUDE EXTERIOR DOORS HAVING DOUBLE HANDLES THAT COULD BE TIED TOGETHER, DOORS ARE MOSTLY METAL-FRAMED GLASS, NO IT INFRASTRUCTURE IN PLACE TO SUPPORT A FIREWALL, NO SECURITY CAMERA SYSTEM IN PLACE.
THE CONTINUITY OF CARE WOULD BE DISRUPTED FOR 141 CHILDREN WHO ATTEND ADVENTURE STATION, THE DAYCARE/PRESCHOOL IN THE RIVER CITY CHURCH FACILITY.  DEPENDING ON THE NATURE OF THE ATTACK, THE LIVES OF THESE CHILDREN AND THE TEACHING STAFF COULD BE IN DANGER.  POTENTIAL LOSS OF LIFE FOR CLOSE TO 800 PEOPLE WHO ATTEND CHURCH SERVICES WEEKLY AT RIVER CITY CHURCH, OR LOSS OF CONNECTION WITH THEIR CHURCH COMMUNITY IF THE BUILDING OR SYSTEMS ARE DISRUPTED OR DESTROYED.

prime_award_disaster_emergency_fund_code: AAJ: Emergency P.L. 118-50;Q: Not Designated Nonemergency/Emergency/Disaster/Wildfire Suppression
subawardee_business_types: NONPROFIT ORGANIZATION,COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION,COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION OWNED FIRM
subaward_description:
WE AIM TO PROVIDE FACILITY HARDENING ACTIVITIES TO REDUCE THE VULNERABILITY OF TENANTS AND STAFF AT MEMORIAL PLACE I.  TARGET HARDENING INVESTMENTS WILL INCLUDE ACCESS CONTROL POLICIES AND SECURED ENTRY; INCREASED LIGHTING; COMPLIANT CAMERA SYSTEMS, AND UPGRADED SECURITY SYSTEMS BOTH PHYSICAL AND ELECTRONIC TO INCLUDE A NEW FIREWALL/NETWORK.
WE PROVIDE AFFORDABLE HOUSING TO MARGINALIZED AND LOW-MODERATE INCOME PEOPLE IN OUR COMMUNITY.  MEMORIAL PLACE I IS LOCATED IN A LOW INCOME NEIGHBORHOOD.  THERE ARE 16 FAMILY UNITS ON-SITE CONSISTING OF 3 & 4 BEDROOM UNITS.  SOME OF OUR TENANTS HAVE CHALLENGING BACKGROUNDS SUCH AS HOMELESSNESS, VICTIMS OF DOMESTIC VIOLENCE AND MAY HAVE HAD CRIMINAL BACKGROUNDS MAKING IT DIFFICULT TO EARN HIGHER WAGE-EARNING JOBS OR TO EVEN BREAK FREE FROM PREVIOUS NEGATIVE RELATIONSHIPS.
DUE TO CHALLENGING BACKGROUNDS AND SITUATIONS OF OUR TENANTS ALONG WITH POOR COVERAGE OF THE PROPERTY WE ARE IN NEED OF SECURITY UPGRADES.  UPGRADES WILL ALLOW US TO LIMIT CRIMINAL ACTIVITIES AND CONTINUE TO PROTECT & RESPOND IN A MORE ROBUST WAY TO PROTECT NOT JUST OUR TENANTS BUT OUR NEIGHBORS WHICH INCLUDE A CHILDCARE FACILITY IMMEDIATELY WEST THAT HAS CHILDCARE OPERATING HOURS UNTIL MIDNIGHT.  THIS WILL HELP US TO INCREASE OUR COMMUNITY PRESENCE AS A KNOWN LOCAL & STATE LEADER.
MEMORIAL PLACE I IS LOCATED IN THE PROMISE ZONE WHICH HAS HIGHER INCIDENCES OF NEED AND ADVERSE ISSUES AFFECTING THE POPULATIONS IN AND AROUND THE NEIGHBORHOOD.  THE NEIGHBORHOOD HAS LOW-MODERATE INCOME EARNERS; LOW HOMEOWNERSHIP; LOW-PERFORMING SCHOOLS, AND LITTLE TO NO SMALL BUSINESS ACTIVITIES WHICH OFTEN PERPETUATES CYCLES OF CRIMINAL ACTIVITY.  THREATS OF VIOLENCE INCLUDING SHOOTINGS, SHOTS FIRED, STOLEN VEHICLES, THEFT, HOMELESSNESS, AND PROXIMITY TO DOWNTOWN HAS MADE US A SOFT TARGET.
AN ATTACK WOULD DEVASTATE AND SET US BACK TREMENDOUSLY FROM THE 30 YEARS OF WHICH WE'VE POURED INTO THE COMMUNITY.  AN ATTACK WOULD CAUSE IRREPARABLE DAMAGE TO THE MANY PEOPLE WE SERVE AND COULD CAUSE A LARGE NUMBER OF INJURIES OR CASUALTIES AS WE SERVE OVER 200 TOTAL FAMILIES.  ADDITIONALLY, WE HAVE HAD AN INCREASE OF HOMELESS PERSONS WALKING AND UTILIZING OUR HOUSING WITH HOMELESSNESS BEING UP 12% FROM THE YEAR BEFORE.  WE WOULD NOT BE PREPARED TO HANDLE THE IMMEDIATE CRISIS WITH OUR TENANTS.

subaward_description:
THE HOSPITAL FOR SICK CHILDREN (ÃƑÂ¢Ã¢Â€ŠÂ¬Ã…Â€ŒSICKKIDSÃƑÂ¢Ã¢Â€ŠÂ¬Ã¯Â¿Â½)


SCOPE OF WORK

THE HOSPITAL FOR SICK CHILDREN (ÃƑÂ¢Ã¢Â€ŠÂ¬Ã…Â€ŒSICKKIDSÃƑÂ¢Ã¢Â€ŠÂ¬Ã¯Â¿Â½) WILL FUNCTION AS THE DATA CORE UNDER THE LEADERSHIP OF DR. GABRIELLE DEVEBER, EXPANDING THE CURRENT INTERNATIONAL PEDIATRIC STROKE STUDY (IPSS) AND VASCULAR EFFECTS OF INFECTION IN PEDIATRIC STROKE (VIPS I) DATABASES AND WEB-BASED REDCAP DATA ENTRY SYSTEMS TO ACCOMMODATE VIPS II-SPECIFIC DATA.

THE DATABASE RESIDES AT SICKKIDS, AS AN EXTENSION OF THE IPSS DATABASE, AND THE DATA CORE TEAM WILL CONSIST OF THOSE RESPONSIBLE FOR ALL ASPECTS OF CREATING, MODIFYING AND MAINTAINING THE DATABASES. THE INITIAL IPSS DATABASE AND WEB-BASED DATA ENTRY SYSTEMS WERE DEVELOPED WITH A SMALL GRANT FROM A CHILD NEUROLOGY SOCIETY/CHILD NEUROLOGY FOUNDATION TO FOSTER MULTICENTER COLLABORATION. FUNDS FROM VIPS I EXPANDED THE SYSTEM TO INCLUDE ADDITIONAL DATA FIELDS SPECIFIC TO UNDERSTANDING VASCULAR INFECTION IN PEDIATRIC STROKE AS WELL AS TO INCLUDE QUALITY ASSURANCE FEATURES AND PROCEDURES SUCH AS DOUBLE DATA ENTRY.

THE VIPS II DATA CORE TEAM WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR IMPROVING AND MAINTAINING THE AUTOMATED REPORTS AND DATA ARRAYS FOR TRACKING ENROLLMENT AND FOLLOW-UP; MANAGING AND RUNNING QUALITY CONTROL PROCEDURES AND EDIT CHECKS; AND ENSURING SECURITY AND DISASTER RECOVERY.


RESOURCES DESCRIPTION 

THE CLINICAL RESEARCH LABORATORY AT SICKKIDS UNDER THE LEADERSHIP OF DR. GABRIELLE DEVEBER INCLUDES EIGHT FULL TIME RESEARCH STAFF INCLUDING A DATA ANALYST AND DATA ADMINISTRATOR, ALL HOUSED IN RESEARCH OFFICES AT THE CHILD HEALTH EVALUATIVE SCIENCES (CHES) PROGRAM IN THE SICKKIDSÃƑÂ¢Ã¢Â€ŠÂ¬Ã¢Â€ŽÂ¢ RESEARCH INSTITUTE (RI).

REDCAP DATA WILL BE STORED ON A SECURE SERVER AT SICKKIDS. THE SECURITY, MANAGEMENT AND BACKUP OF ELECTRONIC RESEARCH DATA ARE PROVIDED CENTRALLY BY THE SICKKIDS RESEARCH I.T. (RIT) DEPARTMENT. SICKKIDS RIT IS A CORE FACILITY WITHIN THE RI OF SICKKIDS, MANAGING THE RESEARCH DATA CENTRE THAT CURRENTLY INCLUDES APPROXIMATELY 50 SERVERS CONTAINING APPROXIMATELY 500 TERABYTES OF DATA. THIS DATA IS BACKED UP WITH 4 TAPE LIBRARIES. BACKUPS ARE CURRENTLY STORED ONSITE EITHER IN THE DATA CENTRE AND/OR IN A ROOM LOCATED IN A SEPARATE FIRE ZONE. SERVERS ARE LOCATED IN A CENTRALLY MANAGED, CLIMATE CONTROLLED, AND SECURED DATA CENTRE LOCATED WITHIN THE HOSPITAL. PHYSICAL ACCESS TO THE DATA CENTRE IS RESTRICTED AND CONTROLLED BY THE RIT DEPARTMENT.

AT THE SERVER LEVEL, ALL DATA IS PROTECTED FROM HARDWARE FAILURE THROUGH DISK RAIDING. DATA IS BACKED UP TO TAPE NIGHTLY FOR DISASTER RECOVERY. ENTERPRISE CLASS MANAGEMENT TOOLS ENSURE DATA INTEGRITY. PROACTIVE MONITORING OF RESOURCE UTILIZATION ENSURES THAT ALL OF THE DATA IS HIGHLY AVAILABLE AND PROTECTED BEFORE PROBLEMS OCCUR. RIT MAINTAINS THE SERVERS WITH THE LATEST SECURITY PATCHES. FIREWALL RULES RESTRICT ACCESS TO PRE-APPROVED COMPUTERS. ALL DATA TRANSMISSION IS ENCRYPTED BETWEEN THE SERVER AND CLIENT AT 265BIT (SSL).

prime_award_disaster_emergency_fund_code: AAJ: Emergency P.L. 118-50;Q: Not Designated Nonemergency/Emergency/Disaster/Wildfire Suppression
subawardee_name: DISTRICT OF EVANSVILLE OF THE SOCIETY OF ST. VINCENT DE PAUL, INC
subaward_description:
THE MAIN GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO HARDEN THE FACILITY'S SECURITY INFRASTRUCTURE. THIS WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH THE PURCHASE AND INSTALLATION OF ALARM SENSORS AT ALL POINTS OF ACCESS, AS THERE CURRENTLY EXISTS NOTHING MORE THAN KEYED ENTRIES. THERE ARE NO ALARMS ON ANY OF OUR ACCESS POINTS TO THE THRIFT STORE. ADDITIONALLY, WE WILL PURCHASE AND INSTALL VIDEO CAMERAS AND DIGITAL VIDEO RECORDING DEVICES BOTH INSIDE AND OUTSIDE THE STORE TO DOCUMENT ANY ACTUAL ATTACK UPON OUR EMPLOYEES, VOLUNTEERS, CUSTOMERS, OR THE INDIVIDUALS WE SERVE. CURRENTLY THERE IS AN INSUFFICIENT NUMBER OF CAMERAS ON THE OUTSIDE OF THE BUILDING, AND NO CAMERA IN OUR MAIN OFFICE WHERE ASSETS ARE RETAINED BEFORE THE DAILY DEPOSIT.
WE WILL PURCHASE AND INSTALL HARDWARE AND SOFTWARE NEEDED TO COMMUNICATE AN ACTIVE ATTACK OR THREAT OF ATTACK TO ALL INDIVIDUALS ON OUR PREMISES AS THERE IS CURRENTLY NO COMMUNICATION SYSTEM OTHER THAN INTERNET ACCESS, AND LANDLINE AND CELLULAR PHONES.
WE WILL COUNTER CYBER-ATTACK THREATS THROUGH THE PURCHASE AND INSTALLATION OF MALWARE AND ANTI-VIRUS SOFTWARE. THIS WILL HELP DETER THE LOSS OF IDENTIFYING INFORMATION ABOUT THE INDIVIDUALS WE SERVE, PASSWORDS TO FINANCIAL INFORMATION, AND/OR SIMILAR THREATS THAT WOULD JEOPARDIZE OR INTERRUPT OUR CHARITABLE ACTIVITIES. CURRENTLY WE HAVE NO SOFTWARE OR PROCESSES IN PLACE. IN ADDITION, WE WILL PURCHASE AND INSTALL A COMMERCIAL GRADE FIREWALL TO PROVIDE PROTECTION AGAINST OUTSIDE CYBER ATTACKERS BY SHIELDING OUR COMPUTERS FROM MALICIOUS NETWORK TRAFFIC. CURRENTLY THERE IS ONLY A PERSONAL FIREWALL PROTECTION ON OUR COMPUTERS AT THE THRIFT STORE.
WE WILL PURCHASE AND INSTALLATION BETTER OUTDOOR LIGHTING TO PROVIDE THE BEST CHANCE OF BEING ABLE TO IDENTIFY POTENTIAL ATTACKERS ON OUR FACILITY BETWEEN DUSK AND DAWN. CURRENT LIGHTING AND CAMERAS DO NOT PROVIDE SUFFICIENT MEANS TO DO SO.
FINALLY, WE WILL PURCHASE AND INSTALL A PHYSICAL ACCESS CONTROL SYSTEM TO ALLOW OUR EMPLOYEES AND VOLUNTEERS TO PREVENT ACCESS TO OUR FACILITIES AND THE PEOPLE WITHIN FROM UNAUTHORIZED PERSONNEL AND ATTACK.
THE SOCIETY OF ST. VINCENT DE PAUL IS AN INTERNATIONAL CHARITABLE ORGANIZATION FOUNDED IN PARIS IN 1833. THE ORGANIZATION BEGAN IN THE EVANSVILLE AREA IN 1882. OUR THRIFT STORE BENEFITS THOSE IN NEED THROUGH LOW OR NO-COST ESSENTIAL ITEMS. MANY WE SERVE SUFFER FROM VARIOUS FORMS OF MENTAL ILLNESS, OR SUBSTANCE ABUSE. BY SERVING ALL WITHOUT REGARD TO RACE, COLOR, CREED, IDENTITY OR ORIENTATION, WE ARE VULNERABLE TO DOMESTIC TERRORISM AGAINST THE POOR, THE IMMIGRANT, AND MINORITY GROUPS.
AS THE COMBINATION OF SUBSTANCE ABUSE, MENTAL HEALTH ISSUES AND POVERTY CONTINUE TO INCREASE IN OUR NATION AND CITY, SPECIFICALLY, SO TOO DO THE POSSIBILITIES OF AN ATTACK UPON OUR EMPLOYEES, VOLUNTEERS, CUSTOMERS AND THE POOR. IN AND AROUND THE BUILDING EXIST MULTIPLE POINTS OF ENTRY WITH ONLY LIMITED MEASURES OF ACCESS CONTROL, VIDEO COVERAGE, ALARMS, MASS COMMUNICATION SYSTEMS AND LIGHTING. VOLUNTEERS ARE ELDERLY OR TEENAGERS. AN ATTACK WOULD DEVASTATE OUR ABILITY TO SERVE THE NEEDIEST.
ST. VINCENT DE PAUL'S THRIFT STORE SERVES MANY OF OUR UNHOUSED CITIZENS, AND CUSTOMERS WHO ARE ONLY ABLE TO ACQUIRE CLOTHES AND FURNITURE (INCLUDING BEDS) ON VOUCHER. THE THRIFT STORE IS LOCATED IN A LOW-INCOME, HIGH-CRIME AREA OF THE CITY. THE STORE EMPLOYS OVER 15 INDIVIDUALS AND OFFERS VOLUNTEER/SERVICE OPPORTUNITIES TO MANY. A DEVASTATING TERRORIST ATTACK AGAINST THIS ORGANIZATION WOULD HAVE FAR-REACHING CONSEQUENCES TO THE THOUSANDS OF RESIDENTS FACING FINANCIAL HARDSHIPS.

prime_award_disaster_emergency_fund_code: AAJ: Emergency P.L. 118-50;Q: Not Designated Nonemergency/Emergency/Disaster/Wildfire Suppression
subawardee_name: DISTRICT OF EVANSVILLE OF THE SOCIETY OF ST. VINCENT DE PAUL, INC
subaward_description:
THE EVANSVILLE ST. VINCENT DE PAUL FOOD PANTRY IS LOCATED IN THE HEART OF THE POOREST NEIGHBORHOOD IN THE CITY AND CURRENTLY HAS INADEQUATE MEANS OF PROVIDING SUFFICIENT SAFEGUARDS FOR EMPLOYEE, VOLUNTEER AND CLIENT PROTECTION. THIS PROJECT IS INTENDED TO HARDEN THE PHYSICAL SECURITY INFRASTRUCTURE OF OUR FOOD PANTRY THROUGH THE ACQUISITION AND INSTALLATION OF AUDIO/VIDEO RECORDING EQUIPMENT; ALARM SENSORS AT ALL POINTS OF ACCESS; HARDWARE AND SOFTWARE NEEDED TO COMMUNICATE AN ACTIVE ATTACK OR THREAT OF ATTACK; MALWARE AND ANTI-VIRUS SOFTWARE TO WARD OFF THREAT OF ATTACK, THE LOSS OF IDENTIFYING INFORMATION ABOUT OUR CLIENTS, PASSWORDS TO FINANCIAL INFORMATION, AND/OR SIMILAR THREATS; A FIREWALL TO PROVIDE PROTECTION AGAINST OUTSIDE CYBER ATTACKERS BY SHIELDING OUR COMPUTERS FROM MALICIOUS NETWORK TRAFFIC; BETTER OUTDOOR LIGHTING TO PROVIDE THE BEST CHANCE OF BEING ABLE TO IDENTIFY POTENTIAL ATTACKERS ON OUR FACILITY BETWEEN DUSK AND DAWN; AND PHYSICAL ACCESS CONTROL SYSTEMS TO ALLOW OUR EMPLOYEES AND VOLUNTEERS TO PREVENT ACCESS TO OUR FACILITIES AND THE PEOPLE WITHIN FROM UNAUTHORIZED PERSONNEL.
SERVING NEARLY 20,000 INDIVIDUALS ANNUALLY, THE ST. VINCENT DE PAUL FOOD PANTRY IS LOCATED IN A FOOD DESERT WITHIN ONE OF THE POOREST NEIGHBORHOODS IN THE CITY. THIS HIGH-CRIME AREA IS PRONE TO GANG-RELATED VIOLENCE. A MAJORITY OF THOSE WE SERVE SUFFER FROM VARIOUS FORMS OF MENTAL ILLNESS, OR SUBSTANCE ABUSE. BY SERVING ALL WITHOUT REGARD TO RACE, COLOR, CREED, IDENTITY OR ORIENTATION, WE ARE VULNERABLE TO DOMESTIC ACTS OF TERRORISM AGAINST THE POOR, THE IMMIGRANT, AND THE MINORITY.
THE SOCIETY OF ST. VINCENT DE PAUL IS A MEMBER ORGANIZATION OF THE SOUTHWEST INDIANA COALITION OF ORGANIZATIONS ACTING IN DISASTER (SWICOAD), MEETING QUARTERLY WITH OTHER NONPROFIT AND GOVERNMENT AGENCIES TO PREPARE FOR NATURAL DISASTER RESPONSE. THE EVANSVILLE DISTRICT OF ST. VINCENT DE PAUL HAS THE SPECIFIC RESPONSIBILITY OF COORDINATING THE ACQUISITION, STORAGE AND DISTRIBUTION OF REPLACEMENT FURNITURE IN ANY POSSIBLE FUTURE DISASTER. 
AS THE COMBINATION OF SUBSTANCE ABUSE, MENTAL HEALTH ISSUES AND FOOD INSECURITY CONTINUE TO INCREASE, SO TOO DO THE POSSIBILITIES OF AN ATTACK UPON OUR VOLUNTEERS AND THOSE WHO ARE SERVED BY OUR FOOD PANTRY. IN AND AROUND THE BUILDING EXIST MULTIPLE POINTS OF ENTRY WITH NO MEASURES OF ACCESS CONTROL. CURRENTLY WE HAVE INSUFFICIENT MEANS OF DOCUMENTING A TERRORIST ATTACK, EITHER INSIDE OR OUTSIDE THE BUILDING. MOST OF OUR VOLUNTEERS ARE IN THEIR 70S AND 80S.
CURRENT SECURITY CAMERA SYSTEM IS INADEQUATE TO CAPTURE AND DOCUMENT ANY POSSIBLE ATTACK ON THE BUILDING OR ITS OCCUPANTS. THERE ARE NO ACCESS CONTROLS ON ANY OF THE POINTS OF ENTRY. THERE EXIST NO VIDEO CAPABILITIES INSIDE THE BUILDING, THUS NO WAY OF DOCUMENTING ATTACKS ONCE INSIDE. STAFF INSIDE THE BUILDING DO NOT HAVE A CLEAR VIEW OF ANYONE ENTERING THE BUILDING. AN INADVERTENTLY UNLOCKED DOOR WOULD ALLOW IMMEDIATE ACCESS TO ANYONE. THERE IS NO SILENT ALARM SYSTEM TO ALERT THE POLICE.
OUR FOOD PANTRY SERVES MORE INDIVIDUALS ANNUALLY THAN ANY OTHER FOOD PANTRY IN THE EVANSVILLE AREA. IT IS LOCATED IN AN IMPOVERISHED AREA OF THE CITY CONSIDERED TO BE A FOOD DESERT SERVING MANY WITHOUT TRANSPORTATION. TH FOOD PANTRY IS ALSO THE LOCATION FOR THE ST. VINCENT DE PAUL CALL CENTER WHERE VOLUNTEERS RECEIVE AND DISTRIBUTE REQUESTS FOR FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE WITH RENT, UTILITIES, WATER AND SEWER BILLS, PRESCRIPTION MEDICATION HELP, AND A HOST OF NEEDS. AN ATTACK WOULD DISRUPT MANY LIVES.
